title: Diner's Journal
description: Consultant Buys the Shop

title: Taylor Gives Coaches His Support
description: Lawrence Taylor talked today about The Program. Not the movie, but the seemingly new and improved New York Giants. He gave Coach Dan Reeves and his staff another stamp of approval. Unlike last season, he doesn't foresee any player mutinies. Unlike last year, when things started going bad and players began bad-mouthing the coaches at every turn, Taylor thinks that a sudden string of losses wouldn't trigger a rush of complaints.

title: Sarajevo May Be Settling Into Stalemate
description: Sporadic artillery bursts from Serbian positions exploded around Sarajevo today, but there was no sign of a major assault despite warnings from Serbian nationalists that they would resume their bombardments when the Muslim-led Government rejected an international peace plan.

title: FIELDCREST CANNON HOLDERS END BLOCK TO ACQUISITION
description: Fieldcrest Cannon Inc. said yesterday that shareholders who had sued to block the company from acquiring the Amoskeag Company have dropped their attempt to block the $140 million purchase. In a letter from the shareholders' lawyers to Vice Chancellor Carolyn Berger of the Delaware Chancery Court, the plaintiffs said they would be unable to prove that the company and its investors would suffer from the merger. The suit was filed in August, just four days after Fieldcrest agreed to purchase all of Amoskeag's 3.44 million shares outstanding for $40 each.

title: Murdoch Gets The Post Out Despite Strike
description: Three days after a strike stopped its presses, Rupert Murdoch's New York Post roared back to life last night, with a new issue of the paper on New York streets and a new victory against newspaper unions on Mr. Murdoch's resume.

title: 18 Inspectors Arrested on Bribe Charges
description: New York City investigators arrested 18 current and former plumbing inspectors yesterday on charges that they extorted dozens of payoffs from plumbing contractors in return for expedited inspections and quicker city approvals at construction sites.

title: Welfare Fingerprinting Becomes Law in Suffolk
description: Despite possible state opposition, Suffolk County Executive Robert J. Gaffney signed into law today a measure that will require fingerprinting for welfare recipients.

title: David Halvorsen; Editor, 60
description: David E. Halvorsen, former editor of The San Francisco Examiner, died on Wednesday at his home in San Francisco six months after diagnosis of an incurable brain tumor. He was 60.

title: The Limp Blimp Bashing Castro
description: Will Congress finally ground the blimp in the Florida Keys that relays TV programs to Cuba, where they get the most dismal ratings? The balloon is operable only in fair weather, its signal is easily jammed by the Castro regime and its broadcasts are beamed only from 3:30 A.M. to 6 A.M. to avoid violating global agreements.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Protest then, protest now . . . KATE PIERSON, a vocalist with the B-52's, the campy rock group, and seven other members of People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals, an animal-rights organization, were arrested yesterday in the offices of Vogue magazine, where they were marching with bullhorns and pasting antifur slogans on the walls.

title: NO OUTSIDE REVIEW IN THE BROWN CASE
description: Attorney General Janet Reno said today that she would not appoint an independent prosecutor to investigate accusations by a Vietnamese businessman that Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown agreed to be paid $700,000 in exchange for his help in lifting a trade embargo against Vietnam.

title: Lillian Vernon Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
Snapshots From Mets' Blight Album
description: The Shea Stadium clubhouse was being unpacked and unloaded. Evacuated, really. But for the Mets, of course, there were some things that couldn't be buried deep enough in bags -- images, memories, singular snapshots of comedy or despair or embarrassment.

title: U.S. Blockade of Workers Enrages Mexican Town
description: For years, as thousands of undocumented workers floated openly across the Rio Grande each day from this sprawling border metropolis to jobs in El Paso, Tex., illegal immigration became a symbol of tolerance, even brotherhood, between the two cities.

title: At the Bar; The waters roil in Virginia Beach, home of Pat Robertson's distinctive law school.
description: In the sea to shining sea of largely indistinguishable American law schools, Regent University School of Law, established seven years ago in Virginia Beach, Va., by the televangelist Pat Robertson, stands alone.

title: Timothy Gordon; Actor, 71
description: Timothy Gordon, the founder of the S.R.O. Hotel Touring Players and an actor who took theater to shelters for the homeless in New York City, died on Monday at Concord Hospital in Concord, N.H. He was 71 years old and lived in Pembroke, N.H.

title: Brighton Journal; Left, Right, Left, Right, but Labor's Not in Step
description: Jane, a middle-aged delegate from the Midlands, recalls Labor Party conferences of the mid-1980's with nostalgia. Those were the days. The party had a red flag. The speeches were fire and brimstone. And the enemy was clear: the banks and boardrooms of the Tories and their lackeys in Parliament.

title: Art in Review
description: Ed van der Elsken Howard Greenberg Gallery 120 Wooster Street (near Prince Street) SoHo Through Oct. 16

title: Art in Review
description: Louise Fishman Robert Miller Gallery 41 East 57th Street, Manhattan Through Oct. 16

title: Arrow International (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Included a gain from patent litigation settlement that had the effect of increasing net income by $ 4,382,000, or 20 cents a share, and after a charge of $ 3,380,000 from change in accounting for postretirement benefits other than pensions.

title: State Unveils Its Plan For Yanks in Manhattan
description: New York State unveiled its plan yesterday to keep the Yankees from jumping to New Jersey, proposing a $319 million, 50,000-seat stadium and a $211 million, 7,000-space parking garage that would be built on the Long Island Rail Road storage yards south of the Jacob Javits Convention Center.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: 'Songs of the 40's'

title: Review/Art; A New Painter's Way With Image and Text
description: There are probably too many paintings in Christian Schumann's first solo show at the Postmasters Gallery in SoHo. There is so much going on in any one of them that initially it's hard to look at more than a few square inches at a time. But Mr. Schumann's teeming images, grafted together with singular precision, are one of the brighter spots in the season's first round of exhibitions, and cause for optimism about the state of painting.

title: Turgeon's Still in Doubt For Opener
description: Still suffering from a sore left wrist, Pierre Turgeon continued to skate alone on Long Island Thursday while his Islander teammates continued their exhibition season with a game at San Jose.

title: Don't Get Mad, When You Can Get Smart
description: To the Editor:

title: Echlin Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Fiscal 1993 results included Sprague Devices Inc. and Frictiontech Inc. Fiscal 1992 results have not been restated for these pooling of interests transactions.

title: National Medical Enterprises Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After a gain of $ 60,121,000, or 37 cents a share, reflecting the impact of the adoption of FAS 109. Year-ago results have been restated accordingly.

title: Schnellenberger Renews Declaration of Independence
description: Howard Schnellenberger has never been one to pass up a challenge. He took over the University of Miami's floundering football program in 1979 at a time when the school was considering scrapping football. Five years later he led the Hurricanes to a national championship.

title: Wolves' Rider Faces Driving Charges
description: ISAIAH (J. R.) RIDER, the Minnesota Timberwolves' top draft pick this year, appeared in court in Alameda, Calif., yesterday to face two counts of driving with a suspended license. He was ordered to return to court on Oct. 14 to enter a plea.

title: PRIVATIZING URGED TO IMPROVE ROADS
description: The Federal Government's top highway official proposed today that private businesses operate portions of the 42,500-mile Interstate System, charging tolls and providing money to repair decaying highways and bridges.

title: Reed Wants Schintzius to Remain a Net
description: If Nets General Manager Willis Reed has his way, reserve center Dwayne Schintzius will not be headed to the Milwaukee Bucks in the next two weeks.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Science Times on Tuesday about research showing that protecting the habitat of one group of species may not protect others misstated, in one reference, the size of the tracts studied. They were about 39 square miles, not 6.

title: Wolverine World Wide reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 11
description: b-Net loss, which included losses from discontinued operations of $ 6,285,000 in the quarter and $ 7,884,000 in the 9 months. The 9 months was also after a charge of $ 750,000 from an adjustment in accounting.

title: Executive Leaves Rotando Agency
description: One of the top three executives at Rotando Lerch & Iafeliece in Stamford, Conn., has left the agency, prompting its renaming as Rotando Partners.

title: Magazine Honors Ramirez
description: Although outfielder Manny Ramirez has struggled with major league pitching since joining the Indians last month, he accomplished plenty in the minors this year. Enough, in fact, to be named minor league player of the year yesterday by Baseball America magazine.

title: Insurers Fear They'd Be the Big Losers in a World of Managed Health Care
description: Since the President gave his health care speech last week, employees have lived with fluttery stomachs in the offices of the Bartmon Shapiro insurance agency, a thriving business high above Central Park South whose windows offer panoramic views of the park and the midtown Manhattan skyline. Under President Clinton's health care plan, the profession of health insurance agent could virtually cease to exist.

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows in New York City that are to close soon: Closing This Weekend "BLACK COMEDY/WHITE LIARS," Roundabout Theater, 1530 Broadway, at 45th Street. A revival of Peter Shaffer's 1967 one-act comedies. Through Sunday. Performances: Tonight at 8; tomorrow at 2 and 8 P.M; Sunday at 2 P.M. Tickets: $38 to $42. Information: (212) 869-8400. "IN THE SPIRIT OF FLUXUS," Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street. Approximately 400 objects and documentary material, by some 40 artists, trace the genesis and resilience of this irreverent, anarchic art movement. Through Sunday. Hours: Today through Sunday, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. Admission: $6; $5 for students and the elderly. Information: (212) 570-3676. Closing Next Weekend "HAND-PAINTED POP: AMERICAN ART IN TRANSITION, 1952-66," Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street. Through Oct. 10. Hours: Wednesday, Friday, Saturday and Sunday, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M.; Thursday, 1 to 8 P.M.; closed Mondays and Tuesdays. Admission: $6; $5 for students and the elderly. Information: (212) 570-3676.

title: An Obstinate Short Slips Away Into a Draw
description: The strategy Gary Kasparov used against Nigel Short in Game 11 of their world championship match yesterday in London was to pit an advantage in mobility and space against one of material. But Short defended obstinately and brought the game to a draw by exchanging off everything that might do him harm.

title: Cintas Corp. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: The latest first quarer's share earnings included 2 cents a share charge from tax adjustments.

title:
BASEBALL;
Braves to Giants: The Key's in the Mailbox, Come On In
description: The Atlanta Braves' signature over the past three seasons has been rallying to win in their last at bat. Perhaps their most memorable comeback came last year when Sid Bream slid safely home in the bottom of the ninth inning to win Game 7 of the National League Championship Series.

title: Settlement for $371 Million By Prudential Unit Expected
description: Prudential Securities has agreed to pay about $371 million to settle Federal and state charges of securities law violations stemming from its sales of money-losing limited partnerships during the 1980's, people with knowledge of the talks said yesterday.

title: U.S. WARNS BEIJING AS PROBLEM GROWS
description: In an effort to salvage the deteriorating relationship between the United States and China, Secretary of State Warren Christopher warned the Foreign Minister of China that his country risks losing favorable trade status with the United States if it does not make quick progress on human rights and arms issues, senior Administration officials said today.

title: Harold Zarowitz, 70, An Expert on Diabetes
description: Dr. Harold Zarowitz, a pioneer in the treatment of diabetes in the New York area, died on Tuesday at Beth Israel Hospital in Manhattan. Dr. Zarowitz, a tive and resident of Brooklyn, was 70.

title: Orbit International Corp.  (NMS) reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-After a gain of $ 643,000, or 10 cents a share, from a change in accounting method for design costs by USA Classic Inc. unit, an interest in which was sold in a public offering in November 1992. The period also included a gain of $ 7.5 million, or $ 1.12 a share, from public offering of USA Classic.Orbit International said that the decrease in sales in the latest fiscal year reflected the exclusion of USA Classic from its consolidated financial statements due to the public offering of USA Classic's shares. Orbit said that its current 43 percent noncontrolling interest in USA Classic was accounted for with the equity method.Sales represented net sales.

title: Art in Review
description: Frisell's Improvisations

title: Executive Changes
description: DEAN FOODS CO., Franklin Park, Ill., a dairy and specialty foods processor and distributor, named Thomas L. Rose, president and chief operating officer, succeeding William D. Fischer, who will retire at the end of next month. ENVIRONMENTAL ELEMENTS CORP., Baltimore, an air pollution control systems supplier, named Edward H. Verdery executive vice president and chief operating officer.

title: Dow Drops 11.18 Points to Close at 3,555.12
description: The stock market turned in a mixed session yesterday, after suffering a little when a series of relatively good economic reports caused bonds to slide and bond-market performance affected stocks.

title: A Consumer Picks Canadian Health Care
description: To the Editor:

title: People
description: * Lori Burgess was named to the vacant position of advertising director at Seventeen magazine, New York. She was previously associate publisher at YM magazine, New York.

title: Reviews/ Film; An Idyll Shattered By Rape and Murder
description: "Malice" could turn out to be the new season's pop mystery-suspense melodrama you won't want to miss. The film is deviously entertaining from its start through its finish, when most such movies go as irretrievably to pieces as Margo's face at the end of "Lost Horizon." "Malice" stays the course. If it were a car, it could be called a mean machine. Though light of weight, it hugs the road around every hairpin curve in its cruel and twisty narrative.

title: Florence Small Gaynor, 72, Dies; First Black Female Hospital Chief
description: Florence Small Gaynor, the first black woman to head a major teaching hospital in the United States, died on Sept. 16 at Christiana Medical Center in Newark, Del. She was 72.

title: For a 60's Radical, Temper Justice With Mercy
description: To the Editor:

title: Hillhaven Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After a charge of $ 1,103,000 from a change in accounting for income taxes.

title: Sacha Guitry's Elegant Games of Strategy and Sex
description: The bed is ready, the silk sheets have been turned down; in his dressing gown he sprays his bedroom with perfume -- he even sprays a bowl of flowers. An amorous woman soon arrives, free to meet her lover while her husband is calling on his mistress. But suddenly the husband is on the doorstep, desperate for advice because. . . .

title: Thousand Trails Inc. reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Included a nonrecurring recovery of $ 600,000 from an insurance settlement.c-Net loss, and the company said that excluding nonrecurring charges and adjustments, it would have had a net loss of $ 45,000.Thousand Trails is an 80 percent-owned unit of US Trails Inc.

title: Yanks' Peaks and Valleys of '93
description: lthough it might not seem like a successful season now because the Yankees are still absorbing the sting of being bounced from the pennant race, they actually played stellar baseball in 1993. A team that was not supposed to match the Blue Jays matched them until September and is likely to finish second. That will depend on how the Yankees fare in their final three games, against Detroit starting tonight at the Stadium. Here are some of the reasons why the team soared and then struggled:

title: INSIDE
description: For Sale: U.S. Highways

title: When a Continent Moves, Houses Fall and Many Die
description: The Indian earthquake and its devastation are rooted in the slow collision of the Indian subcontinent with the Asian landmass, which created the Himalaya Mountains and causes residual tensions in the Indian tectonic plate that are periodically released in bursts of violent energy.

title: Empire Blue Cross Shuns Rate Increase
description: Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield, New York State's largest health insurer, said yesterday that because of better-than-expected financial results, it would not impose a previously approved rate increase that was scheduled to go into effect at the beginning of next year.

title: ESPN's Hip Kid Brother
description: ESPN2, the ostensibly hip, irreverent new companion to ESPN, starts tonight at 7:30 with the loosely structured, three-hour SportsNight news, update, interview, humor and commentary show.

title: Kay Nolte Smith, 61; Wrote Mystery Novels
description: Kay Nolte Smith, the author of "The Watcher" and other mystery novels, died on Saturday at Monmouth Medical Center in Long Branch, N.J. She was 61 and lived in Tinton Falls, N.J.

title: It's Official: Becker Out of Davis Cup
description: BORIS BECKER confirmed yesterday that he won't play in Germany's Davis Cup final against Australia in December. "I'll keep my fingers crossed for our team," he said. Becker said last January that he didn't want to play in the event this year, but there had been speculation he might change his mind. (AP)

title: President Moves to Loosen Grip Of White House on Regulations
description: President Clinton today gave Federal agencies greater authority to write regulations on pollution, safety, business practices and the like without White House intervention, saying his order would "eliminate improper influence, secrecy and delay."

title: Edwin Crawford, 68; Ran Counties Group
description: Edwin L. Crawford, executive director of the New York State Association of Counties since 1977, died on Monday at Our Lady of Lourdes Hospital in Binghamton, N.Y. He was 68 and had lived in Binghamton and in Brewster, Mass. The cause of his death was prostate cancer, his family said.

title: In Shift, Massachusetts Governor Backs Gun Law
description: With voters growing increasingly fearful of gunfire on the streets, Gov. William F. Weld of Massachusetts reversed course this week and proposed some of the most stringent gun control laws in the country.

title: Nicaragua Boomlet: Martinez for President
description: A new political party in Nicaragua is waging a petition drive to place the name of Montreal Expos pitcher DENNIS MARTINEZ on the 1996 presidential ballot, and Martinez has hinted that he may be interested.

title: Dan Rather Scolds TV News As Pandering to Get Ratings
description: In an unusual condemnation of television news by one of its stars, Dan Rather, the CBS anchor, told a group of news directors that "we all should be ashamed of what we have and have not done, measured against what we could do."

title: On My Mind; New York to Clinton
description: President Clinton came to New York, carried out his political assignment and departed happy and smiling, leaving lots of the people who happen to live here angrier, surlier, more paranoid, more disgusted with politicians than ever. In this city, that is not easy to do, in just one night's work.

title: QVC Is Seen as Ready To Prove Bid Financing
description: QVC Network Inc., the home shopping service, may present Paramount Communications as early as today with proof of QVC's ability to pay a $9.8 billion bid for Paramount, two executives close to QVC said yesterday.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: FOOTBALL Redmen Edge Marist Anthony Russo, who gained 146 yards in 29 carries, scored on a 1-yard run with 2 minutes 38 minutes left in the game as St. John's overtook Marist, 31-30, last night at Redmen's Stadium in Jamaica, Queens. Sean Sharkey, St. John's quarterback, threw four touchdown passes, three of them to Tom MacPherson. Dan Phalen scored twice for Marist, first on a 27-yard reverse and then on a 10-yard pass from Brian McCourt. The Redmen (3-1) had lost to Marist (2-2) in their previous three meetings. U.C.L.A. Romps: J. J. Stokes, held in check in the previous three games, caught five passes for 164 yards and three touchdowns and U.C.L.A. held Marshall Faulk to just 53 yards in a 52-13 victory over San Diego State last night in San Diego. The Bruins (2-2) improved to 16-0-1 against San Diego State (3-2). Faulk, the two-time national rushing leader and 1992 Heisman runner-up, was held to his second-lowest rushing total in three seasons, excluding two games cut short by injury. (AP) TENNIS Eltingh Upsets Courier Jacco Eltingh of the Netherlands pulled off a major surprise yesterday, upsetting Jim Courier, 6-4, 6-3, in the second round of the Malaysia Salem Open tennis championships in Kuala Lumpur. The 23-year-old Eltingh, unseeded and ranked 75th in the world is known more for his doubles play, but he used an attacking style to eliminate the second-ranked player, a baseliner who has won four Grand Slam tournaments. (AP)

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a New Jersey trial in a 1992 strangling misstated the Italian word for "now," which the defendant reportedly said at the time of the slaying. It is "adesso," not "odessa."

title: USA Classic Inc. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a gain of about $ 1.3 million from a change in accounting method for design costs, in the quarter and year.c-Net incomeRegarding the year-ago quarter's share earnings---On a pro-forma basis, net income reflecting the company's initial public offering completed in November 1992 was 22 cents a share.On a pro-forma basis, net income reflecting the company's initial public offering completed in November 1992 was 57 cents a share for fiscal 1993 and 41 cents a share for fiscal 1992.

title: Expansion of Jury Rolls Needed in New York; Vanishing Stars
description: To the Editor:

title: 5,307 Bid Adieu Triumphantly
description: On April 5, the Mets won the first game of 1993 at Shea Stadium. Last night, the Mets won the final game of 1993 at Shea. If only there were some way to forget the extended bit of unpleasantness in between.

title: Maxwell Laboratories Inc.  (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss, which included restructuring and other pretax charges of $ 8.3 million in the quarter and year.

title: Senate Gives the Supercollider Another Chance at Survival
description: The Senate rejected efforts to cut off money for the Superconducting Supercollider today, giving the Texas-based proton smasher a breath of air, at least temporarily.

title: A Search for Direction at Apple
description: Perhaps the clearest indicator of the change and uncertainty at Apple Computer Inc. lately is the way Bill Fernandez, the software engineer who became the company's first employee in 1976, spends his time these days. He reads the Help Wanted ads in the newspaper.

title: Finalists for Book Awards
description: "The Shipping News," by E. Annie Proulx, and "United States: Essays 1952-1992," by Gore Vidal, are among the 15 books of fiction, nonfiction and poetry chosen as finalists for the 1993 National Book Awards, the award's administrators announced yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: The Advertising column in Business Day on Sept. 17, about a promotional campaign by Barneys New York for its new midtown store, misstated the number of the company's stores in New York City. It is three -- including a small outlet in the World Trade Center -- not two.

title: Weicker Rejects Re-election Bid In Connecticut
description: Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr., the one-time liberal Republican who built a career out of going his own way, announced today that he would not seek re-election to a second term.

title: Restaurants
description: "Have some bread," says Emily Rapp. "It's just out of the oven." You have just settled into one of the cozy seats at Etats-Unis, and in her hand is a bowl containing warm, slightly crusty bread so delicious that your slice vanishes before everyone at the table has been served. Then she hands you a menu.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about women who seek asylum in the United States misstated the year of the military coup against President Jean-Bertrand Aristide of Haiti in some copies. It was in 1991, not 1992.

title: U.N. Force to Rely on Haitians to Keep Order
description: Despite growing violence, the 1,300-member United Nations mission that is being sent to Haiti will rely on the Haitian military and police to maintain order. Those groups have been held largely responsible for the politically motivated killings in the first place.

title: Books of The Times; Los Angeles Middle Agers Fighting the Old Ennui
description: Black Swans By Eve Babitz 211 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $22.

title: Morrison Restaurants (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 4
description: b-Included charge of $ 2,579,000 from change in accounting for postretirement benefits other than pensions and a $ 2,395,000, or 10 cents a share, gain from change in accounting for income taxes.

title: 5 Key Nations Urge Prudence In Setting Peacekeeping Goal
description: The five permanent Security Council members said today that the demands being made on the United Nations exceeded its capabilities and that proposed new peacekeeping operations must be reviewed very carefully.

title: 2 Parties, 1 Goal
description: With each passing year, fewer members of Congress are willing to work with their colleagues in the opposing party. Those who do are met with increasing criticism and suspicion in their own party caucuses. The culmination of this 20-year trend was passage of the budget without a single vote in Congress from the opposition party. Party and partisanship have become more important than policy and partnership.

title: C.I.A. Releases Files on Korea and Cold War
description: A document released by the Central Intelligence Agency today as it began to unseal its archives from the cold war era shows that American intelligence agencies failed to recognize that the Korean War was imminent six days before it began.

title: Guards Force Louvre to Close
description: Angered by plans for a new night shift, guards blocked the entrance to the Louvre today, leaving hundreds of people outside the glass pyramid that leads into the museum.

title: USAir Plans 2,500 Layoffs By Mid-1994
description: The effort by many major airlines to shrink and restructure themselves to a profitable core continued yesterday with USAir's announcement that it would eliminate 2,500 jobs by mid-1994.

title: Clinton Says He's Met Pledge to Cut Staff by 25%
description: President Clinton said today that he had met his campaign pledge to reduce the White House staff by 25 percent, but Republican critics in Congress immediately said he had met his goal by using gimmicks.

title: Giving Addicts Clean Needles Cuts Spread of AIDS, U.S. Study Finds
description: The Federal Government's first comprehensive study of whether giving clean needles to addicts can help prevent the spread of AIDS has concluded that it does and that the Government should finance a significant expansion of such programs.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball National League

title: Suspect Says He Was Unaware of Strangling Plot
description: He marched to the witness stand with the confident stride of a soldier. Then, in calm, self-assured tones, James P. Wanger told a packed courtroom about his religious faith, his plans to enter the Marines and his complete ignorance of a plot to kill his old friend Robert A. Solimine Jr.

title: Review/Film Festival: Short Cuts; Altman's Tumultuous Panorama
description: THE night skies over Los Angeles, which is in a medfly siege of bibical proportions, are filled with helicopters flying in formation as they indiscriminately spray everything below: people, swimming pools, royal palms, trailer parks, stretch limos, possibly also medflies and their larvae. The helicopters menace as they pretend to protect. Their rotors chop the air and puncture the eardrums. With bright red and green wing lights ablink, the machines have the cold precision of android policemen, waggishly festooned.

title: Rogue Cops
description: New Yorkers who live in safe, middle-class neighborhoods often don't understand how law-abiding citizens can fear and hate the police. New Yorkers from violent, drug-infested neighborhoods understand quite well. Renegade cops like Michael Dowd, Bernard Cawley and their fellow criminals in blue have worked mightily at teaching them.

title: Peteski Going South To Bring Title North
description: Is this the year you can swoop down on the Breeders' Cup and strike gold in horse racing?

title: Reviews/ Film; Not-So-Tough Sledding From 4 Unlikely Olympians
description: The usual high-concept film is one that can be described in a sentence or two. But "Cool Runnings" boils down to just three words: Jamaican bobsled team. Since nothing about that phrase says "stroke of genius," there's reason to wonder what kind of film can have been spun out of it. The answer: a cute, buoyant sports fantasy, jolted along by a reggae soundtrack and playfully acted by an appealing cast. This new Disney comedy is slick, funny and warmhearted, very much in the old-fashioned Disney mode.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Twenty-five years ago, JOHN WALL, an assistant United States attorney in Boston, prosecuted Dr. BENJAMIN SPOCK, the Rev. WILLIAM SLOANE COFFIN and three other defendants on charges that they conspired to counsel, aid and abet young men evading the draft during the Vietnam War.

title: Expansion of Jury Rolls Needed in New York
description: To the Editor:

title: California Bonds' High Yield Is 5.3%
description: A $213.2 million bond offering by California State Public Works was initially priced yesterday to yield a maximum 5.30 percent for a bond due in 2009 through underwriters led by Lehman Brothers.

title: Art in Review
description: Maureen Gallace Nicole Klagsbrun Gallery 51 Greene Street (near Broome Street) SoHo Through Oct. 16

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: C. Mackenzie Jr., 83; Led Discovery Museum
description: Cameron Mackenzie Jr., a retired writer and editor who helped to establish what is now the Discovery Museum in Bridgeport, Conn., died on Sunday at the Iowa Methodist Medical Center in Des Moines. A former resident of Westport, he was 83 and lived in Brooklyn.

title: Braves to Giants: The Key's in the Mailbox, Come On In
description: San Francisco Manager Dusty Baker was in a continuous state of applause tonight. First, the Atlanta Braves' score came in, then some Giants runs came in and then the National League West standings came in: A first-place tie.

title: Excerpts From Report on the Waco Raid
description: Following are excerpts from the Treasury Department's report on the raid by agents of the the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms on David Koresh's compound near Waco, Tex. Among the principals cited in the report were Phillip J. Chojnacki, special agent in charge of the bureau's Houston office, and Charles D. Sarabyn, assistant special agent in Houston.

title: McCann-Erickson Shifts Executives
description: McCann-Erickson Worldwide announced a series of executive changes yesterday after hiring James R. Heekin earlier this week for the new position of president of McCann North America in New York.

title: U.S. Seeks Less Risk In Pensions
description: Seeking better protection for the retirement benefits of millions of American workers, the Clinton Administration proposed legislation today to strengthen the Government's system of pension insurance by requiring companies with insufficient funds in their pension plans to make larger insurance contributions.

title: SHARES OF USF&G TUMBLE BY 11.5% IN HEAVY TRADING
description: The shares of the USF&G Corporation dropped 11.5 percent yesterday in heavy trading after a Kidder, Peabody & Company analyst, Steven Gavios, cut his earnings estimate for the insurer because of falling investment income and rising reinsurance costs. Shares of the diversified insurer fell $1.875, to $14.375, on New York Stock Exchange volume of more than 1.9 million shares. Mr. Gavios cut his estimate of 1993 earnings from operations to 50 cents from 65 cents and his 1994 estimate to $1.25 from $1.90. USF&G reported a loss of 24 cents a share last year.

title: Jets Are Content to Leave The Bulldozing to Baxter
description: Boomer Esiason knows that if the Jets are going to beat the defensive-minded Philadelphia Eagles (3-0) on Sunday, they will almost certainly need to pick up short yardage in critical situations.

title: OFFICIALS EXPECT HARD FLU SEASON
description: Warning that a severe flu season is at hand, Federal public health officials said yesterday that they were urging older Americans and others at risk to get flu shots right away.

title: Quake in India Levels Villages and Kills Thousands
description: The most devastating earthquake in India in more than 50 years rocked a remote sugar-cane-growing region of central India early this morning, killing thousands, Indian officials and Government news reports said. Twelve thousand people were feared trapped in the rubble of their homes.

title: Art in Review
description: Hannelore Baron Barbara Mathes Gallery 41 East 57th Street, Manhattan Through Oct. 16

title: Helene Curtis Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After a charge of $ 1,351,000 from an accounting adjustment.Corrected from Tuesday's editions.

title: Roadway Services (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 11
description: b-After a charge of $ 18,131,000 from the adoption of accounting rules regarding recognition of costs of providing health-care benefits to certain retirees under 65 and for deferred income taxes.Roadway Services said that its results for 1993 included the revenue and earnings of Coles Express, purchased by the company in June 1992, and Central Freight Lines of Waco, Texas, since its purchase in early April.

title: Art in Review
description: Judith Joy Ross James Danziger Gallery 130 Prince Street (near Wooster Street) SoHo Through Oct. 23

title: SONAT UNIT RECEIVES INTEREST IN GAS PROPERTIES
description: A unit of Sonat Inc. has paid $133.6 million for the Mobil Corporation's interest in gas producing properties and three pipelines in the Gulf of Mexico. The Sonat Exploration Company has also completed, or agreed to, three other property acquisitions totaling $16.4 million. The acquisitions will increase Sonat Exploration's daily production of natural gas equivalent by about 95 million net cubic feet, or 24 percent, the company said. The Mobil acquisition includes 34 producing wells on 21 lease blocks in the Gulf of Mexico.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Sept. 11 about Richard L. Berman, who died on Sept. 5, misstated when he became president of Moseley Associates, publishing consultants. It was in March 1990, not last March.

title: A User-Friendly Experiment in Justice; Community Court Aims at Saving Time and Money in Dealing With Minor Offenses
description: Justice has never looked so fabulous.

title: Standoff Ends With Arrests And Freedom For Hostages
description: Two robbers, lying in wait outside a tiny bank branch in Park Slope, Brooklyn, accosted three bank workers as they arrived for work yesterday and held them hostage in a nerve-racking standoff with the police that lasted all day, law-enforcement officials said.

title: For a 60's Radical, Temper Justice With Mercy; Our Vietnam Blunder
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: "If anybody looks on this individual as a lame duck on a pond, you better think twice because you're going to find something coming out of Jurassic Park at you." -- LOWELL P. WEICKER JR., announcing he won't seek a second term as Governor of Connecticut. [ A1:1. ]

title: Miller (Herman) Inc. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
V.M.I.'s Unacceptable Remedy
description: For years the Virginia Military Institute claimed the right to offer its uniquely stressful, oppressive martial education program to men only. Then last year the Federal Court of Appeals in Richmond, ruling in a suit by the Justice Department, held that whatever the program's virtues, the state institution must offer them to women as well.

title: Steelers Make Haselrig Ineligible
description: Pittsburgh has placed Pro Bowl guard CARLTON HASELRIG on the National Football League's list of players with non-football injuries. The move means he will be out indefinitely. The team would not comment yesterday.

title: At This Firm the Clients Hire Inside Consultants
description: What's a gaggle of recent business school graduates doing at a corporate-litigation law firm like Bickel & Brewer? Analyzing cases, poring over documents, choreographing evidence for jury presentation -- in short, doing much of the pretrial preparation that lawyers generally hand over to outside consultants.

title: Dinkins on Giuliani: Accentuating the Negative
description: ON THE SCREEN

title: For a 60's Radical, Temper Justice With Mercy; Some Paralegal!
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Currents column in The Home Section yesterday, about three new furniture stores in SoHo, omitted the address of one of them, GVG Editions, and the price of a rug on sale there. GVG is at 97 Wooster Street, near Spring Street, and the rug, shown in the photograph, costs $3,200. The report also misspelled the name of the artist who painted the rug. He is Michael Stromar.

title: Inside Art
description: The Getty and the Graces

title: Art in Review
description: William L. Hawkins Ricco/Maresca Gallery 152 Wooster Street (near Houston Street) SoHo Through Oct. 23

title: Reviews/ Film; In a Scary Future, Babies Who Decline to Be Born
description: Could the world be so terrible that in the near future unborn babies refuse en masse to leave their mothers' wombs? That is the bizarre supposition of Marion Hansel's deadly earnest film, "Between Heaven and Earth," which opens today at the 57th Street Playhouse.

title: From Hearings, Portraits of Disgrace
description: When the Mollen Commission hearings on police corruption are long over, its policy recommendations a matter of record, New York police lore will still be haunted by the young faces of the disgraced officers and the way their numbing, ugly admissions spilled out, one after the next.

title: CML Group reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Included a loss of $ 4,373,000 from discontinued operations, and a gain of $ 8,093,000 from an adjustment in accounting.The 1992 year's share earnings reflected loss from discontinued operations and gain from accounting change--net income from continuing operations was 73 cents a share.All share and per share figures have een adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split that became effective Aug. 16, 1993.

title: Whitman Says Florio Policies Led to Crime
description: Christine Todd Whitman's campaign for governor took on a sharper edge today as she attacked Gov. Jim Florio for failing to stem the tide of violent crime in New Jersey.

title: YELTSIN AND FOES SIGN PACT TO EASE PARLIAMENT SIEGE
description: Representatives of Russia's warring President and Parliament agreed early today to a phased lifting of the armed confrontation at the headquarters of the legislature, the Interfax news agency reported.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; The Partnership for a Drug-Free America accentuates the positive in a new campaign.
description: THE Supreme Court, it is said, follows the election returns. So, too, it seems, does the Partnership for a Drug-Free America.

title: Reviews/ Film; The Opportunist School Of Hotel Management
description: "For Love or Money" begins by having some fun with the notion of Michael J. Fox as Mr. Big, riding around Manhattan in a long white limousine and indulging in a big-ticket shopping spree. This is Mr. Fox as no one particularly wants to see him: cold, aloof and corrupted by power. He is much more at home when he is revealed to be Doug Ireland, the sneaky, quick-witted concierge at a grand New York hotel, working hard to parlay each guest's needs into a golden opportunity of his own.

title: New Jersey Steel Corp. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Report on Initial Raid on Cult Finds Officials Erred and Lied
description: Law-enforcement officials botched virtually every aspect of their plan to capture David Koresh, the leader of the heavily armed cult near Waco, Tex., then misled investigators and Congress about their mistakes, according to the Clinton Administration's first official assessment of the affair.

title: Article 012093 -- No Title
description: The Senate passed a foreign-aid bill tonight that includes $2.5 billion for Russia and other countries of the former Soviet Union. The vote was 87-13. President Clinton signed the bill just hours later.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: WEICKER WON'T SEEK RE-ELECTION

title: For Children
description: Apple Picking Baiting Hollow Orchard Fresh Pond Avenue, off Route 25 Baiting Hollow, L.I. (516) 929-6439 The Milk Pail Orchard Mecox Road, at Horse Mill Lane Water Mill, L.I. (516) 537-2565 Recommended for all ages

title: Article 477093 -- No Title
description: For many New Yorkers, Chinese food has long since lost its exotic appeal. With the proliferation of restaurant delivery and the standardization of menus, people are far more accustomed to dishes like hot-and-sour soup and cold noodles with sesame sauce than they are to "traditional" New York dishes like the egg cream.

title: Heads Lean to Lewis, But Hearts Are Bruno's
description: The bookshop window along St. James Street has a new display this week: dueling copies of Lennox Lewis's and Frank Bruno's autobiographies.

title: Tasting and Toasting Connecticut Wines
description: IN Robert Frost's poem "Mending Wall," we're told that good fences, the historic boundaries of New Englanders' farmland and the expression of their personal reserve, make good neighbors. In Connecticut vineyards, where the autumn foliage will soon go red and gold, the piled-up stones also symbolize the grit and patience that go into making good white wines, the state's strong suit.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: QUANTUM CHEMICAL CORP., New York, said its shareholders had approved a $3.3 billion buyout by Hanson P.L.C.

title: Theory vs. Practice; Clinton's Stated Foreign Policy Turns Into More Modest 'Self-Containment'
description: The contrast between the theory and practice of the Clinton Administration's foreign policy has never been more starkly apparent than in recent days.

title: Cuban Officials Don't Foresee a Thaw With the U.S. Anytime Soon
description: Despite recent agreements with Washington on immigration and narcotics matters, senior Cuban officials say they do not foresee any imminent advance in relations with the United States, which have been marked by open hostility for 34 years.

title: Quick & Reilly Group reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 27
description: The shares outstanding for both 1992 periods were retroactively adjusted to reflect the 5 percent stock dividend declared April 12, 1993.

title: Safety Over Nostalgia: New Bike-Helmet Law
description: THOSE of us who grew up in the 60's remember the dead-girl songs on the radio, the drag races, the close calls, the black-bordered "In Memoriam" pages in the back of our yearbooks, the football hero who never walked again.

title: There's No Letting Up for Devils' Terreri
description: Although he was certain to be the Devils' top goaltender the moment Craig Billington was traded in June, there has been nothing lackadaisical about the way Chris Terreri has approached the job since the first day of training camp.

title: Art in Review
description: Roni Horn Mary Boone Gallery 417 West Broadway (near Spring Street) SoHo Through Oct. 30

title: Martin Marietta to Eliminate 11,000 Jobs
description: The Martin Marietta Corporation, which last year bought the General Electric Company's aerospace electronics division, said yesterday that it would close 12 production sites and eliminate 11,000 jobs nationwide this year to consolidate the two businesses.

title: Micron Technology Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 2
description: b-Included gain of about $ 5.4 million, or 13 cents a diluted share, from licensing of product and process technology, in the quarter and year.The share earnings and shares outstanding are fully diluted.

title:
COMPANY NEWS;
Toxic-Waste Concern Sets Big Cutbacks
description: Chemical Waste Management Inc., which made millions of dollars by cleaning up hazardous waste, is now tidying up its own operations to improve its competitive position.

title: Go Video Inc. reports earnings for Year to July 31
description: b-Net lossCorrected from Tuesday's editions.

title: Sports of The Times; A Baseball Czar Is Pure Mythology
description: IN "Baseball Without Me," an essay that appeared in last Sunday's New York Times, Fay Vincent made a case for the need for a baseball commissioner, a position that has not been filled since he was deposed in a bloodless coup by the owners one year ago.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: Mr. Martin's Play

title: First Cash Inc. (NMS) reports earnings for Year to July 31
Price Co. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
description: b-Included pretax gain of $ 13.3 million from sale of three shopping centers and adjacent Price Clubs and 49.6 percent interest in joint venture that owns five shopping centers to Price REIT. The gain increased earnings by about 14 cents a share. Periods also included gain of $ 6.6 million, or 2 cents a share, on reversal of previously accrued LIFO expense; charge of 2 cents a share for warehouse closings, and charge of 1 cent a share for higher taxes.

title: Ty Cobb Batted Here (and Struck Out)
description: His eyesight has faded a bit over 102 years, and when you ask Chet Hoff a question these days, you have to speak up. But when he answers there is thunder in his voice, and when he grasps your hand after a ceremony in a hospital garden in upper Manhattan, the full, surprising force of his arthritic grip makes it easier to appreciate an unlikely historic fact:

title: BERKSHIRE HATHAWAY SET TO ACQUIRE DEXTER SHOE
description: Berkshire Hathaway Inc. said yesterday that it would acquire the privately held Dexter Shoe Company for stock worth about $420 million. Berkshire Hathaway, a holding company in Omaha run by the investor Warren E. Buffett, will issue 25,221 shares of its common stock to Dexter's owners. The company's stock closed yesterday at $675, up $75, on the New YorK Stock Exchange. "Dexter Shoe Co. is exactly the type of business Berkshire Hathaway admires," Mr. Buffett said. "It has a long, profitable history, enduring franchise and superb management." Dexter shareholders have already approved the merger, which still must be reviewed by the Federal Trade Commission.

title: Sun Television & Appliances Inc. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
COMPANY NEWS: Skirmish of Screen Savers; Toaster-Blasting Penguin And Parody Go to Court
description: Opus the Penguin, of "Outland" and "Bloom County" fame, is in trouble again. This time for shooting at flying toasters.

title: Mademoiselle Names a New Editor in Chief
description: Elizabeth Crow, who resigned last month as president, chief executive and editorial director of Gruner & Jahr USA Publishing, was named editor in chief of Mademoiselle yesterday.

title: U.N. Chief Warning U.S. Against Pullout Of Force in Somalia
description: Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali has warned the United States that a withdrawal of American troops from Somalia would destroy the United Nations peacekeeping operation there.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Rifkin Pleads Not Guilty In Deaths of Two Women
description: Joel Rifkin, the former landscaper from East Meadow, L.I., who told the police he had killed at least 18 women, pleaded not guilty today to killing two women whose bodies were found not far from the criminal courts building here.

title: How Death Penalty Has a Deterrent Effect
description: To the Editor:

title: A New Ferry Out of L.I. May Yet Find A Developer
description: An advisory committee of officials from New York and Connecticut has tentatively backed a developer to operate a high-speed ferry between Shoreham, L.I., and New Haven.

title: Review/Art; Channels to the Sacred, From Africa to the West
description: "Face of the Gods: Art and Altars of Africa and the African Americas," at the Museum for African Art in SoHo, is a show of both great ambition and ambitions fulfilled. Visually and emotionally stirring, it not only documents a wide assortment of crucial connections between African and African-American religious art. It also imaginatively explores the sensitive issue of how non-Western sacred art can be displayed in a secular Western context.

title: Gov. Weicker Exits in Good Form
description: Lowell Weicker is known for his risky positions and unpopular causes. His decision not to stand for re-election as Governor of Connecticut will leave the state poorer -- and politics less lively.

title:
Historic District Renovation;
Conservancy Loan for Harlem Home
description: For the last five years, Frances and Steven Greene, a couple in their 30's living in a rental apartment in Peekskill, N.Y., have been unable to get a loan to rebuild the brownstone they bought on West 121st Street in the Mount Morris Park historic district of Harlem. But in June, they got some help to proceed with a $300,000 renovation of their four-level 19th-century dwelling.

title: Abroad at Home; The Price of Surrender
description: By rejecting terms for the dismemberment of their country, members of the Bosnian Parliament have given the West a last chance to understand the consequences of its policy there: a chance to draw back from folly and danger.

title: Supreme Court Faces a Docket Heavy With Unfinished Rights Cases
description: The Supreme Court's docket for the term that begins on Monday is sparse in numbers but heavy with the unfinished business of past years, particularly in the area of civil rights.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-10 INDIA QUAKE KILLS THOUSANDS The most devastating earthquake in India in over 50 years rocked a remote central region, killing thousands. Twelve thousand people were feared trapped amid rubble. A1 The Indian subcontinent and the Asian landmass collided. A10

title: Art in Review
description: 'De Kooning-Dubuffet: The Late Works' Pace Gallery 32 East 57th Street, Manhattan Through Oct. 16

title: Market Place; Some Baby Bells may be angling for a role in a Paramount deal.
description: WHILE Viacom and QVC Network race to line up money in their battle to buy Paramount Communications, all eyes are now turning toward the Baby Bells as potential partners.

title: Chiefs' Carter Involved in a Shootout
description: Kansas City cornerback DALE CARTER was arrested and released following a shootout outside a nightclub early Thursday, authorities said.

title: Battle for The Post: Worker vs. Worker
description: After not publishing for three days, The New York Post came back to life as the paper's production unions broke ranks with the striking Newspaper Guild and returned to work.

title: Shattered Ties and Broken Hearts: a 'Civil War' at Post
description: Herded behind police barricades, carrying signs in a jumbled picket line, members of the New York Newspaper Guild jeered at their colleagues in the drivers' union just before they entered cargo bays of The New York Post to return to work.

title: Manufacturers Quit a Project For Pay Toilets
description: A plan to put 30 public toilets with advertising kiosks in New York City parks was hobbled yesterday when two leading operators withdrew their names from the search.

title: The Spoken Word
description: MICROBREWERY TALK, Nacho Mama's Burritos, 2867 Broadway at 111th Street. Pete Slosberg, brewer of Pete's Brewing Company, the brewer's of Pete's Wicked Ale, discusses microbrewed beers in the United States, with a tasting of 29 microbrewed beers. Saturday at 10:30 P.M. Free admission, but a charge for the beer. Information: (212) 666-3052. "WRITER'S HARVEST: THE NATIONAL READING," Universalist Church, Central Park West and 76th Street. Russell Baker, Fred Busch, Gloria Naylor and Grace Paley read from their work; first of Share Our Strength's national readings to raise money to fight hunger. Tonight at 8 P.M. Admission: $10. Information about this and the national events: (202) 393-2925. OPERA LECTURE, Kaplan Penthouse, Rose Building, 70 Lincoln Center Plaza, West 65th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Bridget Paolucci discusses Puccini's "Tosca." Sponsored by the Metropolitan Opera Guild. Saturday at 11:45 A.M. Admission: $8. Information: (212) 769-7028. "PLACE AND CYBERSPACE IN THE GLOBAL ECONOMY," New Museum of Contemporary Art, 583 Broadway, at Prince Street, SoHo. Saskia Sassen, co-curator of the "Trade Routes" exhibition, lectures. Tomorrow at 2 P.M. Admission: $3.50; $2.50 for students and the elderly; children under 12 free. Information: (212) 219-1355. "HAPPY HOUR," Biblio's, 317 Church Street, TriBeCa. David Manning and Angela Lukacin read from their work. Tonight, 6 to 8 P.M. Information: (212) 334-6990. READING, the Poetry Project, Second Avenue and 10th Street, East Village. Paul Williams, author of "Rock and Roll: The 100 Best Singles," and Cindy Lee Berryhill read from their work. Tonight at 10:30 P.M. Admission: $6. Information: (212) 674-0910. MOLLY IVINS, 92d Street Y, 1395 Lexington Avenue. The political humorist reads from her new collection, "Nothing but Good Times Ahead." Sunday at 8:15 P.M. $15. Information: (212) 996-1100.

title: Hillenbrand Industries Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
description: b-Included income of $ 1,199,000, or 1 cent a share, and $ 1,778,000, or 2 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, both from results of American Tourister Inc., which Hillenbrand sold to Astrum International Corp. on Aug. 30.c-Included income of $ 455,000, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter and a loss of $ 231,000 for the 9 months, both from results of American Tourister, which Hillenbrand sold to Astrum International, and the 9 months also included a gain of $ 10,747,000, or 15 cents a share, from change in accounting for income taxes.Hillenbrand Industries said that it took a charge of $ 1.4 million in the latest third quarter because of an increase in federal taxes retroactive to Jan. 1.

title: Black Cleric Says Giuliani Is Attracting 'Fascist' Ilk
description: As Mayor David N. Dinkins stood at his side, a prominent black minister charged yesterday that the Mayor has been falsely branded a "murderer" for the death of a rabbinical student in Crown Heights and that these "fascist" elements have gravitated toward his rival, Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: G.M.'s Canada Contract Sends Shares Falling
description: Shares of the General Motors Corporation slid today in heavy trading as investors reacted to news of a tentative labor contract reached Wednesday night by G.M. and the Canadian Automobile Workers.

title: Hillary Clinton Raises Tough Question of Life, Death and Medicine
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton said today that she hoped the nation would engage in a serious discussion about what is appropriate medical care in cases where very expensive treatments do nothing for the patient's quality of life.

title: Seduction and the Impossible Dream
description: The film version of "M. Butterfly" introduces a critically important new element into David Henry Hwang's play: the camera. The artifice that was possible on stage, in Mr. Hwang's daring, multi-faceted meditation on the love affair between a French diplomat and the Chinese transvestite he mistakenly believed was a woman, is simply out of the question on screen.

title: Many Koch Aides Return, as Advisers to Giuliani
description: Four years ago, Rudolph W. Giuliani campaigned for mayor as a political outsider. But this year, in a sign of how differently his candidacy is perceived by the political establishment, he has been receiving quiet help and tutoring from former aides to Mayor Edward I. Koch, who have crossed party lines to share policy prescriptions with the Republican-Liberal.

title: Davstar Industries reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Included $ 563,000 charge to goodwill associated with Gates Plastics unit.Davstar said that the increased net loss was principally attributable to increases of $ 1,725,000 in product design and testing expenses relating to the company's medical products, a reduction in revenues of about $ 720,000 due to reduced orders for non-medical plastic injection-molded products sold by Gates Plastics.

title: Go-Go Gradualism
description: Russia's political turmoil comes down to a dispute over public finance. Neither Boris Yeltsin nor his foes in Parliament have figured out how to finance the conversion of the Communist system to a market economy.

title: Great American Management & Investment Inc. (NSC) reports earnings for Year to July 31
description: b-Included an added reserve of $ 18.1 million related to anticipated litigation and other costs of the company's Madison Management Group Inc. unit, and after a loss of $ 25,764,000 from discontinued operations.c-Net income, which included income from discontinued operations of $ 32,864,000, or $ 2.97 a share.

title: Kosar Said to Sign for $27 Million
description: Cleveland quarterback BERNIE KOSAR, who has been benched part way through his last two outings, has received a $27 million, seven-year vote of confidence from the Browns' owner, ART MODELL, The Akron Beacon Journal reported yesterday.

title: Marriott Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 10
description: b-After a charge of $ 2 million from the cumulative effect of changes in accounting for income taxes and assets previously reported as held for sale.The latest periods' results included charge of 5 cents a share for noncash income tax adjustments.The share earnings and shares outstanding are fully diluted.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * Carlton Communications P.L.C., London, is offering in the United States six million shares of exchangeable capital securities priced at $25 a share to yield 8 percent through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch. The securities, which are exchangeable by the company into cumulative dollar-denominated 9 percent preference chares, are noncallable for five years. The issue is rated A-3 by Moody's and A- by S.& P. * Merrill Lynch & Co., New York, is offering $150 million of 15-year 6 1/4 percent notes due 2008 and priced at 98.937 to yield 6.361 percent through Merrill Lynch. The noncallable notes are rated A-1 by Moody's, AA- by Duff & Phelps, and A+ by S.& P.

title: NESTLE'S PERRIER UNIT PURCHASES DEER PARK WATER
description: Perrier Group of America Inc., the bottled water company that is a subsidiary of Nestle S.A., the giant Swiss food producer, said yesterday that it had bought Deer Park Spring Water Inc. The companies would not comment on the purchase price. Deer Park was owned by the Clorox Company, based in Oakland, Calif. In 1992 Deer Park had sales of $60 million. The Perrier Group of America Inc. is already the leader in the bottled water industry in the United States. Deer Park bottles and delivers spring water in the Eastern United States from its base in the Appalachian Mountains.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL REPORT
description: Pride Bowl

title: Review/Theater; Theirs Is A Marriage Made on Broadway
description: It's not quite a half-century yet, but who's counting? Eli Wallach and Anne Jackson -- stage partners for 48 years, husband and wife for 46 -- have had a full life in the theater. They met while performing in a Tennessee Williams one-act play ("This Property Is Condemned") and more than four decades later are still together on and Off Broadway. After a detour to Hollywood, they always came back to New York, or signed up for a new hitch on the legitimate theater's dwindling road. There's no long-running sitcom in either of their Who's Whos.

title: Acton Corp.
description: Shares of the Acton Corporation surged earlier this week after the insurance company said last Friday that it had agreed to sell its cable television assets. The stock had languished around $5 since the spring, but jumped to $15.875 by Wednesday's close. It settling back yesterday, however, easing 21 percent in value.

title: Box-Office Fraud Inquiry Is Stopped
description: The Manhattan District Attorney's Office announced yesterday that it was dropping its investigation into allegations of fraud at the box office of the Lunt-Fontanne Theater. The investigation was started in March 1992, during the run of "Catskills on Broadway."

title: Hard Lessons on Competitive Bids
description: If the recent scandals in the municipal market force more states and local governments to rely increasingly on competitive bidding in the sales of their tax-exempt bonds, it appears that Merrill Lynch & Company may already have an edge on its Wall Street competitors.

title: Critic's Notebook; A No-Apologies Woman for the 90's: Harlow
description: JEAN HARLOW represented everything that straitlaced 1930's America was supposed to despise. She played platinum-haired prostitutes, gold diggers and other trashy types with no apologies. In "Red-Headed Woman," she strategically places a picture of her rich, married boss under her garter and says, "It'll get me more there than it will hanging on the wall." In "Red Dust," she decides to take a bath in a rain barrel, the better to get Clark Gable's attention. And in "Hold Your Man," she fights a rival for Gable's affections by belting the other woman with a left to the jaw, twice. Yet in her seven-year career, Harlow was wildly popular with both men and women, who found more to envy than to scorn.

title: French Clothier Opening in New York
description: Another combatant has entered the suit war raging in midtown Manhattan.

title: Colin Powell, Who Led U.S. Military Into a New Era, Resigns
description: Gen. Colin L. Powell, who defined the United States' post-cold-war military doctrine, retired today as popular with America's armed forces as with the average American who never served in harm's way.

title: Home Video
description: To promote three recent hits, and to frustrate video pirates, Paramount opens a window -- wide.

title: TV Weekend; Along the Battle Lines Of 'Politically Correct'
description: Herewith a piece of politically neutral advice for documentary makers who want their work taken seriously: Shun re-enactments.

title: For a 60's Radical, Temper Justice With Mercy; Too Much Tolerance
description: To the Editor:

title: Criticism of Raid Heartens Cult Members
description: While the Treasury Department's review was categorical in condemning the mistakes by top officials in charge of the Feb. 28 raid on the Branch Davidian compound, the impact on the coming trial of 11 cult members accused of murdering Federal agents was the subject of sharp dispute today.

title: TV Weekend; A Perpetual Outsider and a New Host
description: Russell Baker makes his entrance as the new host of "Masterpiece Theater" on Sunday evening at 9 with a 90-minute BBC drama called "Selected Exits." The New York Times columnist clearly has no intention of shucking his piquant sense of humor.

title: Hollywood Takes Bidding War in Stride (for Now)
description: Sherry Lansing, chairwoman of the motion picture group of Paramount Pictures, walked past a prominent producer the other morning on the studio lot. The producer stopped and asked Ms. Lansing the question that she has heard repeatedly in recent days.

title: One More Lap for Mario Andretti
description: MARIO ANDRETTI will drive one more Indy-car season for the Newman-Haas Racing team and then retire, he announced yesterday.

title: Don't Rush a Bad Crime Bill
description: There is a dangerous section in the new crime bill being promoted by Senator Joseph Biden and the Clinton Administration. Its title calls it a "reform," but it would lock in court rulings that have watered down the laws under which state court prisoners get their cases reviewed by Federal courts. This section of the bill has to do with the body of law built around the concept of habeas corpus -- literally "you (might) have the body."

title: Demonstrators Seize Project In Brooklyn
description: About 250 Hispanic residents of the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn took over a nearly completed public housing project last night, moving in television sets, blankets and their children because they said they fear that Hasidic Jews in the neighborhood might get special treatment in gaining apartments when the project opens.

title: Well, They All Do Wear Numbers
description: Last year, when former Red Sox Manager JOE MORGAN compared some baseball players unfavorably to race horses in a radio commercial for Suffolk Downs, the Red Sox took offense.

title: The Ad Campaign; Gulotta on the Attack
description: Nassau County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta has begun broadcasting a 30-second commercial and two 15-second commercials on five New York City-based television stations. The spots charge that Mr. Gulotta's Democratic opponent, Benjamin L. Zwirn, Supervisor of North Hempstead, has not kept his promises to cut taxes. The campaign says it is spending $125,000 to run the ads for 10 days, not counting the purchase of time on cable. A typical Long Island viewer is expected to see the commercials three times over the next week. ON THE SCREEN All three commercials begin with a fairy-tale motif, with a rainbow over some hills. Text appears at the bottom, and pages turn on screen as if it were a children's book. Then, the commercial cuts to an unflaterring picture of Mr. Zwirn set against a black background.

title: Where is Gendun Rinchen?
description: In April 1992, my husband, Harrison Ford, and I visited Lhasa, the capital of ancient Tibet. We were doing research there for a film I am writing about the early years of the Dalai Lama, beginning in 1937, when he was recognized as the 14th spiritual and temporal leader of Tibet, and ending in 1949, with the brutal invasion of his country by its neighbor, China. After more than four decades, Tibet is the world's longest-occupied sovereign state, and the largest.

title: G. Brillembourg, 35, Tax Lawyer, Writer And Alpine Climber
description: Gustavo E. Brillembourg, a tax lawyer at the New York firm of Davis Polk & Wardwell, died on Tuesday night after he fell 120 feet from a mountain ledge he was climbing in the Yosemite Valley in California. He was 35 and lived in Manhattan.

title: SUN MICROSYSTEMS FALLS 7.8% OVER SHIPMENT CONCERNS
description: The stock of Sun Microsystems fell 7.8 percent yesterday after an analyst predicted shipments of Sun work stations would fall short of her expectations. Sun's stock declined $1.875, to $22.125, on volume of more than 12.8 million shares, making it the most actively traded issue in the United States. The decline in Sun's stock was set off by Laura Conigliaro, an analyst at Prudential Securities, who cut her earnings forecast for Sun's first quarter and fiscal year. "The evidence we have gathered leads us to conclude that Sun is likely to fall shy of our shipments target for the September quarter," Ms. Conigliaro said. Sun officials refused to comment.

title: On Trying Alternative Medicine for Migraine
description: To the Editor:

title: President of Peru Says He Is Confident of Defeating Guerrilla Group
description: In a display of confidence that his Government is finally winning the long struggle against the Shining Path guerrillas, President Alberto Fujimori of Peru said today that he had rejected a peace offer from the movement's imprisoned leader.

title: Observer; In Russet Mantle Clad
description: Baseball as we have known it ends as the baseball season ends tomorrow, and I'm sorry, Willy, but I can't cry. I was ready to tell baseball "So long, Sweetheart" a year ago.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: New York Philharmonic Avery Fisher Hall

title: Lewis Stumbles Early, but Bruno Crumbles Later
description: He certainly looked like a heavyweight champion, as he stood there in the frosty early-morning air with his long arms thrust high and his Agassi-sized entourage milling around him.

title: Nigeria's New Leader Sounds Like the Old
description: To the Editor:

title: A Keycorp-Society Merger Is Expected to Be Disclosed
description: Two large banking companies, Keycorp, based in Albany, and the Society Corporation, based in Cleveland, are expected to announce on Monday that they will merge, investment bankers said yesterday.

title: Giuliani Says Dinkins Ally Made an Anti-Italian Slur
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani asserted yesterday that a prominent black minister's charge that he is supported by "fascist elements" seemed intended as an anti-Italian slur and may have been part of a coordinated effort by the Dinkins campaign to use supporters to inject race into the campaign.

title: Japanese Starting to Link Pay To Performance, Not Tenure
description: In Japanese festivals, dozens of people together hoist a heavy portable shrine, known as a mikoshi, and chant as they carry it through the streets. Since it is impossible to tell who is actually doing the lifting, it is only natural that some shrine carriers shirk off, shifting more weight onto others.

title: FISCHER & PORTER SHARES UP 71% ON SALE POSSIBILITY
description: Shares of the Fischer & Porter Company surged 71 percent yesterday after the company said it would explore a sale of the company. The maker of measurement and control devices said it had hired CS First Boston Group to advise it on strategic alternatives, including a sale. Fischer & Porter shares jumped $6.125, to $14.75, on the American Stock Exchange.

title: Female Goalie to Get a Tryout
description: ERIN WHITTEN, the second woman to play professional hockey, will get a tryout next week with the Toledo Storm of the East Coast Hockey League.

title: Trombonists in a Variety Show of Traditions
description: The opening concert of Highlights in Jazz, at Pace University in lower Manhattan on Thursday night, was all amiability. The show brought together the trombonists Al Grey, George Masso and Slide Hampton, and in various combinations with their rhythm section, the three produced a concert that never quite took off but didn't wither away either.

title: C. Lamar Elmore, 48, German Wine Expert
description: Dr. C. Lamar Elmore, a former professor of German language and literature, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 48.

title: Blanchard Kicks Away Jets' Doubts
description: The good news about the place-kicking of the Jets this season is that there is no bad news. Cary Blanchard, the second-year pro out of Oklahoma State, is leading the team in scoring for the second straight year, with 23 points. He has been 11 for 11 on extra points and 4 for 5 on field goals. He's doing his job, and that's no big deal for a kicker.

title: Officers Describe Police Watchdog Agency as Ineffectual
description: As hearings into corruption in the New York City Police Department resumed yesterday, two former narcotics officers described the department's internal watchdog agency as disorganized, incompetent and so ineffectual that honest police officers feared reporting their crooked colleagues.

title: Victory Is Sour for Lawyer Fighting Nassau Parking Tickets
description: Ira J. Raab won't have to pay the $15 parking ticket he received last March when he pulled into a crowded lot and parked in a spot reserved for the police, a judge has ruled.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Symphony for United Nations Carnegie Hall

title: Harold C. Hinton, 66, Asian History Expert
description: Harold C. Hinton, an expert on Asian history and a former professor of political science and international affairs at George Washington University, died on Sept. 24 at the Estes Park Medical Center in Estes Park, Colo. He was 66.

title: Asbestos Crisis Is Exposing Broader Neglect in Schools
description: The plumbing is so decrepit in one New York City school that the toilets will not flush and the bathrooms stink. A leaking roof in another sends rainwater seeping through classroom walls. And because the lunchroom is sealed off in a third school, children sit on the ground in the schoolyard to eat cold lunches.

title: Gas Tax Hits, and Drivers Aren't Happy
description: With resignation and skepticism, the public began making its first contributions to reducing the Federal budget deficit today when around the country motorists woke up to President Clinton's new gasoline tax and slightly higher prices at the pump.

title: Yeltsin's No Jefferson. More Like Pinochet.
description: President Boris Yeltsin's move to dissolve the Russian Parliament came as quite a surprise, considering that he narrowly escaped impeachment last March when he tried the same thing. But even more surprising is the insensitivity of so many Western leaders and experts who have rushed to justify his actions.

title: To Russians, Ballet Appeals At Least as Much as Politics
description: The Seventh Moscow International Ballet Competition, which ends Saturday night with a gala concert, has been memorable for filling the red velvet and gilt stalls at the Bolshoi Theater for two weeks straight, despite swarms of grim militiamen blocking off city streets in the battle for Parliament. The competition, dedicated to the choreography of Marius Petipa, may also be remembered as much for the prizes that were not awarded as for those that were.

title: In Her Majesty's Service, but Without Free Soap
description: For the small army of courtiers and chauffeurs, stable hands and servants who attend Britain's royal family, the edict delivered this week by Buckingham Palace's management consultants was blunt and unsparing: Off with their perks!

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Philharmonic Seasons
description: To the Editor:

title: Celtics Add Some Backcourt Depth
description: Trying to rebuild their backcourt after the death of Reggie Lewis, the Boston Celtics have signed former National Basketball Association guards TRAVIS MAYS, RODNEY MONROE and LAMONT STROTHERS. Boston announced the signing of the three yesterday along with that of 7-foot-1-inch MATT WENSTROM, the third-string center on North Carolina's N.C.A.A. championship team last season. (AP)

title: A Pioneer of Mutual Funds Takes a Look at Today
description: Walter L. Morgan, a young Philadelphia accountant, had just founded one of the first American mutual funds when stocks rose to dizzying heights in the summer of 1929. His portfolio was heavily invested in common stocks, including such speculative favorites as Curtis Publishing at about $125 a share and U.S. Steel at more than $250.

title: Indicators Post Broad Gain of 1%
description: In another sign of a possible quickening of the economic recovery, the Government said today that its main forecasting index posted a broad 1 percent advance in August, its biggest rise of the year.

title: Lawyer Pounces on Gaps In Murder Suspect's Story
description: For a second day, James P. Wanger was bombarded today with tough questions about inconsistencies and gaps in his accounts of where he was and what he did on the day Robert A. Solimine Jr. was strangled.

title: Watch for Distributions As Year Winds Down
description: NOVICE mutual fund investors can slide into tax traps, particularly in the fourth quarter. But with a modicum of knowledge about how funds work, they can play the tax laws to their own advantage.

title: Bridge
description: Beginners are advised to avoid trump suits with fewer than eight cards in the combined hands, but the experts are alert for exceptions. The right time to play in a 4-3 fit is not easy to spot. The practice is long associated with Alphonse Moyse Jr. who recommended it on every possible opportunity. Delicate bidding maneuvers are often called for, and were forthcoming on the diagramed deal. It was played in a money team game which used to be, but is no longer, played at the Young Men's Philanthropic League, 4 East 80th Street.

title: Mutual Funds
description: * How funds did in the third quarter * How to cushion against a market decline Today in YOUR MONEY, pages 37-43.

title: In Suburbs, Voters' Minds Wander; Candidates Say New York City Still Gets Residents' Attention
description: When Michael G. Cherkasky and Jeanine Pirro compete for votes on Westchester County's train platforms, they share a challenge peculiar to suburban politicians: trying to seize the attention of many people whose political hearts and minds are in New York City, where they cannot vote.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK CITY TWO APPROACHES TO HOMELESSNESS In the four years since they last campaigned to be mayor, David N. Dinkins and Rudolph W. Giuliani have refined their positions on what should be done for the city's impoverished multitudes and now present voters with distinctly different approaches to homelessness and welfare reform. Page 1.

title: 43 Nations Promise Palestinians $2 Billion in Aid
description: Delegates from 43 nations today promised about $2 billion in aid over the next five years for the West Bank and Gaza Strip, as Saudi Arabia put aside its anger at the Palestinians for supporting Iraq in the Persian Gulf war and pitched in $100 million.

title: City Councilman Accused in Report
description: A veteran New York City Councilman repeatedly violated ethics rules in the City Charter by lobbying city officials in the mid-1980's on behalf of private garbage haulers with whom he had business dealings, a report by the Department of Investigation has concluded.

title: New York Rivals Differ Strikingly On Dealing With City's Poorest
