description: For all the acknowledged importance of Broadway theater, Woody Allen's movies or a blockbuster show at the Museum of Modern Art, a new study by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has found that the arts in New York exert their greatest economic impact through a myriad of far smaller and more obscure enterprises and organizations.

title: Program Announced For '93 Tucker Concert
description: Renee Fleming, Florence Quivar, Ruth Ann Swenson, Richard Leech, Thomas Hampson, Samuel Ramey and James Morris are to sing at this year's Richard Tucker Music Foundation Gala Concert, Dec. 12 at 7 P.M. at Avery Fisher Hall. Daniel Oren is to conduct the orchestra, and Birgit Nilsson, the guest of honor, is to recount memories of the foundation's namesake.

title: Abuse-Prevention Efforts Aid Children
description: THE first national survey to assess the effectiveness of school-based programs to prevent sexual abuse confirms that they help children in real-life encounters with potential child molesters.

title: Einstein Changed World on Office Time
description: To the Editor:

title: Federal Paper Board Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 11
description: b-Included noncash charge of 23 cents a fully diluted common share as a result of the change in the federal statutory tax rate to 35 percent from 34 percent, in both the quarter and 9 months.c-Net incomed-Included a gain of $ 9,000,000, or 22 cents a share, from change in accounting of income taxes.Federal Paper Board said that earnings per common share assuming full dilution excluded the conversion of all common stock equivalents for the third quarter of 1993 and excluded the conversion of the company's $ 2.875 preferred stock for the full year 1993 as the effects are antidilutive.

title: Trade Pact to Give Latin America a Big Boost
description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton Pitch on Health Takes Zigs and Zags
description: President Clinton's appearance at a picturesque park here today was staged with utmost care to take advantage of all of the things the Administration wanted to emphasize this week. Most of the crowd was elderly and they all lived in California, a state that remains crucial to Mr. Clinton's political success. The topic was health care.

title: Executive Changes
description: B. F. GOODRICH CO., Akron, Ohio, named David L. Burner executive vice president. He will continue as president of B. F. Goodrich Aerospace. CAMPBELL SOUP CO., Camden, N.J., said that its chairman, Robert J. Vlasic, would retire next month. David W. Johnson, Campbell's president and chief executive, was named to fill the post. Mr. Vlasic will continue as a member of the board. Also, Bennett Dorrance, a member of Campbell's board, was named to the new position of vice chairman.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Lendl's Falling Fast Todd Martin outlasted three-time champion Ivan Lendl in a marathon three-set battle last night to advance to the second round of the Australian Indoor championships in Sydney. Martin rallied to down the seventh-seeded Lendl, 4-6, 7-6 (10-8), 6-4, in a first-round match that lasted 2 hours 33 minutes. It was the ninth time this year that Lendl had lost his opening match of a tournament. Lendl, who won the Australian Indoor in 1985, 1987 and 1989, made an increasing number of errors as Martin stepped up the pace after breaking in the fifth game of the third set. Lendl was within 2 points of victory in the second set tie breaker. Martin, from Lansing, Mich., clinched the victory with an ace that was hotly disputed by Lendl, who stormed angrily from the court. The defending champion Goran Ivanisevic of Croatia, seeded fourth, scored a 6-4, 6-2 first-round victory over Jason Stoltenberg of Australia. An American qualifier, Jonathan Canter, making a comeback after an 18-month break from tennis, upset Henrik Holm of Sweden, 4-6, 6-3, 6-4. (AP)

title: Bourque Arbitrator Rules for Bruins
description: In what must be considered a major victory for the Boston Bruins, and National Hockey League owners in general, a league arbitrator yesterday awarded veteran Boston defenseman Ray Bourque $2.25 million for the 1993-94 season, $2 million less than he had requested of the team.

title: Weicker's Lieutenant to Run for Governor
description: Lieut. Gov. Eunice S. Groark, who joined Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr.'s fledgling independent third party as his running mate in 1990, announced today that she would run for governor next year.

title: No $33.5 Million Deal for Coleman
description: The attorney for Derrick Coleman said that contract negotiations between Coleman and the Nets broke down yesterday after the star forward rejected the team's latest offer, $33.5 million over five years.

title: Cutbacks Hurt, Ad Age Learns
description: Advertising Age, a trade publication that has been in the forefront of reporting on the advertising recession and its effect on magazines, became a victim of sorts itself this week.

title: The Race Card
description: For 12 years, Democrats often led by Bill Clinton -- rightly condemned the code-word racial politics of the Reagan era. But last week it was President Clinton who used code-word politics to try to help Mayor David N. Dinkins, declaring at a fund-raiser in New York that "too many of us are still too unwilling to vote for people who are different than we are."

title: Review/Television; Two Law Series Return, With Some Revisions
description: Despite obvious drawbacks, a television formula can be a thing of wonder. It depends on the talent and inventiveness of those doing the mixing from week to week. Two rigidly formularized NBC series returning this season are proving to be in remarkably tiptop shape. "Law and Order," Wednesdays at 10, is sharper and more provocative than ever. "L.A. Law," Thursdays at 10, is showing its distinctive spunkiness again after being widely judged dead in the water for the last couple of seasons.

title: Lintas Loses Diet Coke's Account After 11 Years
description: The Coca-Cola Company rocked Madison Avenue yesterday by moving its main Diet Coke account from the advertising agency that helped introduce the brand with great success in 1982.

title: Another Great Year for Paris's Vintage
description: THE 1993 vintage has not generally been much of a success in France. Bad weather has caused problems almost everywhere. Except here. In Paris, every vintage is a success.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Witness Says He Saw Yellow Van Just Before Blast
description: In a surprise eyewitness account, a Secret Service agent testified yesterday at the World Trade Center bombing trial that he spotted a yellow van parked in the trade center garage just before he was knocked unconscious by a violent blast.

title: The Phillies and Braves Have Bullpens of Doubt
description: One is a cartoon character of a player. The other is baseball's latest storybook creation. Their jobs are to close games, and so an examination of Mitch Williams and Greg McMichael is not a bad way to open the debate on the National League Championship Series that begins Wednesday night between the Phillies and the Braves.

title: WHITE HOUSE TRIES TO CALM CONGRESS
description: A wave of hostility toward the military operation in Somalia swept Congress today, forcing the White House to send two Cabinet secretaries to Capitol Hill to try to calm critics and plead for additional time to formulate a new policy.

title: Applied Research Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net incomeApplied Research said that the increase in revenue is due to revenue contributions from its unit, Applied Research of Maryland Inc., and product sales from its software unit, ARSoftware Corp.The company also said that the 1993 net loss was a result of a reduction in operating margins for Applied Research of Maryland caused by overruns, start-up costs incurred by ARSoftware and increased interest costs.

title: Sports of The Times; Gloom On 2 Fronts For Chicago
description: THINGS were merely ominous for this city, what with the White Sox getting hammered in their first post-season game in 10 years. And then came the truly miserable rumor that Michael Jordan just might be retiring.

title: Dynamics Research Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 4
In America; The Echoes of Bushwick
description: Nobody talks much about Bushwick. It's just a tired, old, poverty-racked neighborhood in Brooklyn where adults without jobs move listlessly from one boring day to the next, and the police have to close off streets to slow the high-energy encroachment of youthful drug dealers, and the children, of whom there are many, find it difficult to dream because their days and their nights are so often disturbed by the sound of gunfire.

title: William A. Corley, 76, Bureau Chief for NBC
description: William Angus Corley, former chief of the NBC News bureaus in Chicago, Saigon and Moscow, and an Emmy-winning television producer and writer, died on Sunday at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. He was 76 and lived in Manhattan.

title: A Random Tasting Tour And the Flavor Is Ethnic
description: AS EVERYBODY knows, any fool with money can eat scrumptiously in this city, there being no lack of good or fancy restaurants and no shortage of guidebooks or tasteful touters willing to point them out. But where can you get really good pofpof, moinmoin and iddlies? Where is there palm wine? And where can you taste delicious things you have never tasted or even heard of for the price of a movie or less?

title: SENATORS CRITICIZE BOSNIA AID PLAN
description: Members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee expressed reservations today about the Clinton Administration's plan to dispatch 25,000 American troops to the Balkans.

title: Falcons' Miller to Miss the Season
description: Quarterback CHRIS MILLER of the Atlanta Falcons will miss the rest of season after reconstructive surgery on his left knee Monday night. The team said the operation in Vail, Colo., repaired an injury from the Sept. 27 game against the Pittsburgh Steelers. Miller was hurt after throwing a pass on the run. He wasn't hit by a defender. Dr. RICHARD STEADMAN performed the surgery on the same knee Miller injured midway through the 1992 season. (AP)

title: Claim by Ex-Army Coach Is Turned Down
description: The United States Military Academy has rejected a claim by fired basketball coach TOM MILLER for $318,534 in lost salary and benefits. West Point Athletic Director AL VANDERBUSH turned down the claim in a letter dated Sept. 21. Vanderbush was supported by the university's top brass.

title: CHRONICLE
description: In 1958, Dr. WILLIAM H. PICKERING was instrumental in the launching into orbit of Explorer I, the first American space satellite, 83 days after the former Soviet Union took the world by surprise with Sputnik.

title: New Rules Ease Disclosure of U.S. Data
description: The Clinton Administration said Monday that it had changed the rules for disclosing Government information to reporters, historians and the public by making it easier for the Government to release its records under the Freedom of Information Act.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: MANY foods can be given a compelling new texture by coating them with something crunchy like seasoned bread crumbs, crushed nuts or sesame seeds. I recently bought some Cornish hens and decided to crush some toasted pecans for a coating. Pecans are perfect for this kind of cooking because they are delightfully sweet, and having more moisture than most nuts, they blend well in sauces.

title: Lemaire Is Putting New Life Into Devils
description: Two significant characteristics are the same as last season for the Devils: They have a new coach and they have a gap the size of the Grand Canyon at center. But unlike last season, they are viewing one of those facts as a positive.

title: A. P. Molinaro Jr., 65, Advertising Executive
description: Albert P. Molinaro Jr., an advertising executive who marketed health-care products, died on Monday at Hunterdon Hospital in Flemington, N.J. He was 65.

title: INSIDE
description: Plea Deal in House Bank Case

title: AT LUNCH WITH: Marilyn Tucker Quayle; With the Spotlight Off, Basking in Brighter Times
description: MARILYN TUCKER QUAYLE is free at last. Free from political expectations and expediency, free from images imposed by the national news media, free from the stiletto prickliness that contrasted so sharply with her husband's sunny demeanor.

title: George DeSipio Jr., 37, Living Proof Founder
description: George DeSipio Jr., one of the founders of Living Proof, a traveling exhibition of photographs of men, women and children who are infected with H.I.V. or who have AIDS, died on Saturday at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. He was 37.

title: QUAKER OATS ACQUIRES BAKERY COMPANY
description: The Quaker Oats Company of Chicago, said yesterday that it had bought Petrofsky's Bakery Products of suburban St. Louis for undisclosed terms. Petrofsky's, which is privately held, makes frozen bagels and other frozen breads that are sold mostly to supermarket bakeries. It will become part of Quaker's Food Services unit, which posted sales of $470 million in the 1993 fiscal year.

title: Police Official Will Reopen Graft Cases
description: A top New York City Police Department official said yesterday that he would reopen 40 cases involving allegations of corruption and misconduct against police supervisors and their relatives that were kept in a secret file and withheld from prosecutors.

title: Initiative on Northern Ireland Stirs Optimism
description: A new initiative by two of the most influential Roman Catholic leaders in Northern Ireland has led to a feeling of optimism among many that fresh negotiations could get under way soon to try to resolve the sectarian violence that has killed more than 3,000 people in the last 25 years.

title: Rabin and Arafat Open Talks Today
description: Yitzhak Rabin and Yasir Arafat will meet in Cairo today, the first encounter of substance by an Israeli Prime Minister and the Palestine Liberation Organization chairman.

title: UNREST CONTINUES IN HAITI'S CAPITAL
description: In the latest blow to efforts to make a peaceful transition to democracy, about 30 heavily armed civilians hunting for the Mayor of the capital broke up a political meeting at a hotel today with bursts of automatic weapons fire.

title: A Passage to Playoffs Through N.F.C. East
description: When the Jets get down to the last month of the season, they may look back at last Sunday's 35-30 loss to the Philadelphia Eagles with regret.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 1 about the release of classified American documents on the Korean War misidentified the Director of Central Intelligence at the start of the conflict. He was Adm. Roscoe Henry Hillenkoetter, not Gen. Walter Bedell Smith.

title: Jordan, N.B.A.'s Greatest Star, To Announce Retirement Today
description: Michael Jordan, the Chicago Bulls' superstar who is among the most recognized figures in professional sports, will announce his retirement from basketball today, according to a front-office official of the Bulls.

title: Pizza It Is, and Pizza It Isn't
description: Americans long wedded to pizza have begun to wonder how to distinguish between their favorite pie and the focaccia that now turns up everywhere. Pizza, after all, has been the beloved, second only to hamburger on the nation's menu. Focaccia, the darling of health-minded, status-conscious epicures, is the interloper.

title: QVC Tells Paramount Bid Can Be Financed
description: At 10 o' clock yesterday morning, Herbert A. Allen did something he does not ordinarily do as the head of Allen & Company, an investment bank catering to the entertainment world.

title: ONE-STOP SHOPPING FOR ECOLOGY DATA
description: In a report intended to help the nation safeguard plants and animals, the National Academy of Sciences called on the Government today to establish a central repository of scientific information on the nation's flora and fauna.

title: Review/Film Festival; A Taiwan Artist Tells His Island's Story Obliquely
description: The work of Hou Hsiao-hsien, Taiwan's premier film maker, has been turning up regularly at American festivals since "A Summer at Grandpa's" was shown in the 1986 New Directors/New Films series at the Museum of Modern Art. With his very fine new film, "The Puppetmaster," Mr. Hou has come into full control of his talents. He's an artist who has absorbed all the outside influences he needs and is now speaking with his own voice. It's a clear, assertive voice, though not exactly loud, which wouldn't be in character either for the director or for his subject.

title: Broadway Musicians Approve Tentative Pact
description: The executive board of Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians voted yesterday to approve a tentative agreement in contract talks with Broadway producers. The vote was 6 to 2, setting the stage for a ratification vote today and tomorrow by union members.

title: CLINTON REVIEWS POLICY IN SOMALIA AS UNEASE GROWS
description: President Clinton met with his top advisers tonight to review the American role in the international military operation in Somalia. He sought to balance the need to remain in Somalia to recover American hostages with mounting calls from Congress for a clear withdrawal strategy and the President's own goal of putting Somalia on the road to recovery.

title: Group by Group, Dinkins Seeks to Unite Support
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins went to the Upper West Side one morning last week to mingle with ordinary New Yorkers -- an endeavor that often produces a spontaneity that can be at odds with Mr. Dinkins's own penchant for preparedness. A middle-aged man approached the Mayor, asked him what he was doing next Saturday and then invited him to his son's bar mitzvah.

title: Health Care Units To Merge at WPP
description: Two health care communications units of the WPP Group are merging. The J. Walter Thompson Company's JWT Healthcare unit in New York will become an operating division of the Ferguson Communications Group in Parsippany, N.J.

title: Rabin and Arafat to Discuss Details
description: In yet another sign of how the once unthinkable is fast approaching Middle East routine, Yitzhak Rabin and Yasir Arafat will meet in Cairo on Wednesday, the first official encounter of substance by an Israeli Prime Minister and the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: Joseph Warren Dies; Character Actor, 77
description: Joseph Warren, a character actor who appeared in dozens of plays and films, died on Friday at the Village Nursing Home in Manhattan. He was 77.

title:
Commercial Property;
3 Leases Put Grace Tower At Capacity
description: THE Grace building, the dramatically sloped 50-story skyscraper with a main entrance on 42d Street across from Bryant Park, will soon be fully occupied as a result of three recent leases totaling 151,655 square feet on five floors.

title: Atlanta Journal; Atlanta: The City Without a Slogan
description: The erstwhile "Gate City of the South," "Capital of the New South," "City too Busy to Hate," "Black Mecca" and "World's Next Great City" has a problem.

title: Plasma-Therm Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Safety-Kleen Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 11
description: b-After a gain of $ 300,000, or 1 cent a share, from an adjustment in accounting.Safety-Kleen said that earnings for the year-ago third quarter included a $ 7.6 million after-tax charge for estimated costs incurred in conjunction with certain environmental problems at the company's Puerto Rico operations.The company also said that during the latest quarter, it recorded an additional income-tax expense of $ 2.2 million, ''primarily due to an increase in the statutory income tax rate in the U.S.'' About $ 1.5 million of the additional income-tax expense is a result of revaluing the company's fiscal year-end 1992 deferred-tax balances to reflect the tax rate changes.The balance of the increased income tax expense of $ 200,000 and $ 500,000 is related to the current reporting period, and to the first 24 weeks of 1993, respectively, the company said.

title: Teachers' Pension Fund Asks for Diverse Boards
description: A big teachers' pension fund that is one of the country's largest investors issued new guidelines yesterday for companies in which it invests. The guidelines call for an end to all-white and all-male boards but give companies leeway in deciding how, and how much, to pay executives.

title: Lands' End
description: Shares of Lands' End Inc. eased yesterday after the catalogue retailer of apparel, luggage and other products announced a secondary offering by its chairman and vice chairman. The decline ended a price run-up of almost 50 percent in the third quarter, following strong second-quarter financial results and favorable ratings by analysts.

title: Encyclical on Morality Doesnt Stifle Debate, Church Officials Say
description: Roman Catholic officials at the Vatican and in the United States presented Pope John Paul II's new encyclical, "Veritatis Splendor" ("The Splendor of Truth"), in very conciliatory tones today. They insisted that his statement on fundamental moral theory was intended to encourage reflection and discussion of basic principles of morality, not to cut off debate.

title: U.S. OFFICIALS HAIL YELTSIN FOES' ROUT
description: American officials expressed hope today that the defeat of President Boris N. Yeltsin's opponents in Moscow had swept aside the vestiges of the old Soviet system. But they said they remained unsure that the opening would make way for true democracy.

title:
Campus Journal;
California's Budget Cuts Prolong College Careers
description: When Francisco Pardorla transferred to the California State University campus here as a junior in 1989, he vowed to let his hair grow until he graduated. His hair is now down to his waist.

title: Pizza Chain Account Goes to Thompson
description: Showbiz Pizza Time Inc. in Irving, Tex., said yesterday that it had selected J. Walter Thompson Chicago to handle the account of its Chuck E. Cheese pizza parlor chain, previously at the Keller Crescent Company in Irving. Billings were estimated at $15 million.

title: Review/Fashion; The Look in Milan: Easy
description: As the spring and summer fashion openings continue to unfold here, interest has begun to shift from the nature of the presentations to the clothes themselves. There is a growing realization that the prime business of the showings here is the introduction of clothes that stores can sell and women can wear. The styles that command the most attention are not the ones that rate high in shock appeal but those that make a smooth transition to fresh, new looks. It is, at any rate, the fabrics of fashion that offer the most news. They are mostly thin and fluid, with no hard edges. Many are crushed, crumpled and slashed.

title: Hampton Seems Headed For Unwelcome Rest
description: In a season in which Rodney Hampton was on pace to carry the ball more times than any running back in history, Lewis Tillman, his backup, made an odd request.

title: Hurricanes Are Seeing Red Over That Big Point Spread
description: A six-foot-high sign hangs in the University of Miami football locker room. On it is the number 14. That's the amount of points by which some oddsmakers have favored Florida State University to defeat the Hurricanes on Saturday in Tallahassee.

title: Car Renters Biased Against Young Drivers, Lawmaker Says
description: Most car rental companies still turn away some drivers under 25, despite a state law banning the practice 10 years ago, State Senator Roy M. Goodman charged yesterday. He called for imposition of stiffer fines against the companies and giving young drivers the right to sue.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a man who pleaded guilty to having molested children when he was a Roman Catholic priest in the 1960's misstated the first name of the District Attorney of Bristol County, Mass. He is Paul F. Walsh Jr.

title: In Shift, Bond Dealers Seek To Halt Political Donations
description: In a move that reflects an unexpected change of sentiment in the municipal bond industry, the Public Securities Association called on municipal bond dealers yesterday to stop making political contributions to state and local officials or candidates for government office in hopes of winning underwriting business.

title: Food Notes
description: Health Food Branch

title: Review/Theater: The Fiery Furnace; Sturdy Midwestern Women Making Compromises With Life
description: In "The Fiery Furnace," a new Circle Repertory Company production at the Lucille Lortel Theater, dear Julie Harris is the matriarch presiding over a cozy Wisconsin farmhouse kitchen of the 1950's. Appliances and new miracle products like Reddi Wip are proliferating, promising a new age of homemaking ease. A casserole is in the oven, the cookie jar is full and Ike is in the White House. What possibly could be wrong with the picture?

title: Bellwether Area Cool to Whitman
description: If Middlesex County is any indication, and Middlesex County usually is, Christine Todd Whitman has run smack into a wall of voter skepticism in her bid to defeat Gov. Jim Florio.

title: Fran Carlon, 80, Dies; Radio and TV Actress
description: Fran Carlon, an actress who worked in radio, television, films and theater, died on Monday at her home in Manhattan. She was 80.

title: Maybe Knicks Are After N.F.L. Title
description: The Knicks kicked off a new preseason earlier this week by dedicating a renovated practice gymnasium, in which Pat Riley revealed his rewritten battle cry.

title: New Venture In Securities
description: Hyperion Capital Management is forming a joint venture with the AIG Investment Corporation to manage mortgage-backed securities internationally.

title: Review/Fashion; A Few Artisans Try To Blow the Socks Off
description: The modern woman, as she is cast on Milan's runways, rolls out of bed with greasy hair, pulls on her boyfriend's white cotton briefs, a thinning T-shirt that barely covers the tops of her thighs, black ankle socks and her father's loafers, and goes to face the world.

title: Hearing for Troubled Man to Be Dropped
description: The lawyer for Larry Hogue, the mentally ill, homeless man who for years menaced residents of the Upper West Side, said yesterday that he would withdraw his request for a competency hearing and try to persuade prosecutors to get his client medical treatment instead.

title: Hopeful Start for Profit-Making Schools
description: A year ago, the Harlem Park Community School here seemed to represent the worst of what was wrong in public schools: graffiti covered the halls, crack vials littered the grounds, students did not have enough textbooks and, because the toilets did not work, the children sometimes defecated or urinated in stairwells.

title: Mexican Cellular Deal Seen
description: Hoping to tap into Mexico's cellular telephone market, the Bell Atlantic Corporation is close to a $1 billion deal to buy into Mexico's second-largest cellular telephone company, officials of the Mexican company said today.

title: Yeltsin And the Possessed
description: In the euphoric days of August 1991, when the Communist regime finally collapsed under the weight of its own absurdity, the Parliament of the Soviet Union gathered for what would be its valedictory session.

title: Rice Continues Its Surge On Talk of Japan Purchases
description: Prices for rice futures contracts at the Mid-America Commodity Exchange hit their upward limit today for the third time in a week, driven by excitement over prospects that Japan will import rice from the United States this year for the first time since 1975.

title: Bidding War Shakes Loose Fat Fees for Wall St.
description: Thanks to the battle for control of Paramount Communications Inc., it has been raining hard on Wall Street. And nobody seems to be complaining -- certainly not the rainmakers.

title: Louis Grossman, 76, Judge in Manhattan
description: Louis Grossman, a former Civil Court judge in Manhattan who served for many years as an acting State Supreme Court justice, died on Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 76.

title: Dow Gains 9.50 Points in Anxious Trading
description: Stocks were mixed yesterday in heavy trading, and the Dow Jones industrial average was the only one of the three most widely watched market indicators to close with a gain.

title: Review/Opera; Mozart's Magic Spell, Cast in Bright Colors
description: The Metropolitan Opera's production of "Die Zauberflote" returned to the house on Monday evening, with its brightly colored storybook sets by David Hockney and a cast of singers so fully in tune with the work's style and substance as to make the passions of Mozart's magical world ring consistently true.

title: Father-Son Recital
description: Pavel Berman, the winner of the gold medal at the 1990 International Violin Competition of Indianapolis, is to make his Carnegie Hall debut on Oct. 24 at 3 P.M. in a recital of works by Mozart, Shostakovich, Dvorak and Wieniawski. He is to be accompanied by his father, the pianist Lazar Berman. The joint recital is a benefit for Classical Action: Performing Arts Against AIDS. Tickets are $15 to $40, or half-price for students and the elderly. Information: (212) 315-2145.

title: Safeway Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 11
description: b-Included extraordinary loss of $ 27.8 million from the early retirement of debt, and after a charge of $ 27.1 million from an adjustment in accounting.

title: After a Year of Tumult, Pakistanis Will Vote
description: After a year of tumultuous political maneuvering, power plays and constitutional crisis -- all of which have staggered the country's fragile economy -- Pakistanis will vote on Wednesday in what are likely to be the first free and fair national elections in more than two decades.

title: 'Young Republican' Arrested in Murder Scheme
description: The head of a young Republican club tried to have a political rival killed for spreading the claim that he had molested club members, Federal prosecutors in Manhattan said yesterday.

title: Gerald J. Carroll, 46, Navy Pilot and Author
description: Gerald J. Carroll, a decorated naval pilot who wrote two novels based on his experiences in Vietnam, died on Thursday at his home in Leonardtown, Md. He was 46.

title: Kruk Certainly Willing But Is the Slugger Able?
description: The lineup appeared out of nowhere. It listed Ricky Jordan as the starting first baseman for the Phillies. Manager Jim Fregosi, taken aback by the bogus lineup, said it was wrong. John Kruk was going to be at first base.

title: Trade Pact to Give Latin America a Big Boost; Democracy in Mexico
description: To the Editor:

title: Alta Energy Corp. reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Included noncash charge of $ 2,892,075 for adoption of FAS 109, Accounting for Income Tax.c-Net income and included gain of $ 851,000 or 29 cents a share, from a gas contract settlement.

title: Revolutions Tend To Reap as They Sow
description: To the Editor:

title: By Any Name, Dykstra Is as Tough as Nails
description: Lenny Dykstra still has his tobacco juice and his toys and that arrogant strut. He is still the guy who named his youngest son Cutter, after the bad guy in the Judith Krantz novel "I'll Take Manhattan." He is still the guy whose autobiography, "Nails," would be "four pages long without the expletives," according to a former teammate, Wally Backman.

title: Mexico City Journal; 1968, Soaked in Student Blood, Refuses to Fade
description: Francisco Buendia was not born when angry students shook this city with demonstrations as it prepared to be host to the 1968 Olympic Games. Although he looks something like a throwback in shredded jeans and long hair, he conceded that he was not much of a counterculturalist, either.

title: Stolt Comex Seaway S.A.  (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain of $ 396,000 in the quarter and 9 months.Stolt Comex Seaway said that it has operated as an integrated business since the third quarter of 1992, so there are no directly comparable financial results. The company was formed by Stolt-Nielsen Seaway and Comex Services.

title: Sweetness Rewarded In a Tasting
description: IN a photo finish, an opulent dessert wine was voted No. 1 in this year's New York State wine competition.

title: Eating Well
description: HILLARY RODHAM CLINTON, who is shaping the Administration's health-care reform proposal, believes strongly that nutrition is an important part of health care. For instance, she said yesterday through her spokeswoman that "good nutrition has proven health benefits and is one of the cheapest ways people can be more responsible about their health."

title: Campbell & Wagman Plans to Shut Down
description: Campbell & Wagman Inc., a seven-year-old agency in Los Angeles, said yesterday that it had decided to close after determining that it would not participate in the review of its largest account, First Interstate Bancorp, with billings of $30 million.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CARAUSTAR INDUSTRIES, Austell, Ga., a cardboard tubing maker, will buy Federal Packaging Corp., St. Paris, Ohio, for undisclosed terms. MERRILL CORP., St. Paul, has entered into a letter of intent to acquire May Printing Co. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Study Ties Prostate Deaths to Animal Fat
description: AMERICAN men whose diets are rich in animal fats, and particularly fats from red meat, face nearly an 80 percent greater risk of developing potentially fatal prostate cancer than do men with the lowest intake of such foods, a major new study has found.

title: Advanced Micro's Profit Rises Nearly 25% but Stock Falls
description: Advanced Micro Devices Inc., the leading maker of Intel-compatible microprocessor chips, released third-quarter earnings results today that disappointed Wall Street investors, who drove its stock down $4.75, to $22.

title: Poles a Quick Study With Fast Food
description: Poles love pizza. But Pizza Hut didn't know they loved pizza that much. Or that they would fall for corn on the cob, or burritos, or for that matter, Taco Bells.

title: Turn On the Lights in Central Park and Improve the Security; And in Brooklyn
description: To the Editor:

title: The Deepest Dive Yet For Gulf of Mexico Oil
description: The Shell Oil Company announced yesterday that it would spend $1.2 billion to bring into production a giant oilfield in the Gulf of Mexico, a project intended to push offshore-recovery technology to the deepest levels yet and to create 2,200 jobs, most in Texas and Louisiana, and thousands more among subcontractors in 34 states.

title: Spell It Out to the U.N. on Somalia
description: America's national pride could be injured if the Clinton Administration decides to extricate U.S. troops from the gathering disaster in Somalia. America's national interests could be injured if it does not.

title: Suddenly It's Spring Again: Rangers Lose
description: Booed the last time they left the Madison Square Garden ice last spring, the Rangers returned last night with an abundance of enthusiasm, an excess of adrenaline, and more than a few butterflies.

title: Bally of Switzerland Picks DDB Needham
description: Bally of Switzerland, the maker and retailer of shoes, leather goods and fashion accessories, has selected DDB Needham Worldwide in New York to handle its global account, the agency said. Billings were estimated by Campaign, the British advertising trade publication, at $20 million.

title: Keep It Safe, Game Is Advised
description: Football must be made safer for its players.

title: Yeltsin Uses Decrees to Curb Dissenters
description: With the Parliament building still smoldering and ringed with armor, President Boris N. Yeltsin moved today to concentrate power in his office and to shatter any possible opposition.

title: CHRONICLE
description: WILLIAM M. KUNSTLER'S name tends to conjure up images of a crusader for unpopular causes and controversial defendants. But a star-struck movie fan? He certainly seemed like one the other day when he hung up the phone after talking with LEW AYRES, the film actor.

title: EASTERN COLLEGE REPORT
description: Rutgers

title: Using Steinbeck, Hemingway and Others as Parole Officers
description: When Walter Grajales went to court after he was caught breaking into a car, the judge gave him an unusual choice: he could either go to jail or take a literature class.

title: Ecology & Environment Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Ecology & Environment said that the increase in net income for fiscal year 1993 was due to an increase in pretax margins, compared with the prior year, which was hurt by the expiration of the USEPA Field Investigation Teams contract.

title: Injury Puts Pacers' Miller Out of Action
description: REGGIE MILLER, the Indiana Pacers' leading scorer the past four seasons, severely sprained his left ankle in a pickup game and will be sidelined for at least half the preseason. Miller, the National Basketball Association's leader in consecutive regular-season starts (339), probably will be ready for the Nov. 5 season opener at Atlanta. The 6-foot-7-inch guard injured the ankle Sept. 24 and recovery will take four to six weeks from that date, Pacers trainer DAVID CRAIG said.

title: Critic's Notebook; Upstart and Formal Styles in Montreal
description: Modern dance from Britain, admittedly in a selective overview, has pride of place at this year's International Festival of New Dance in Montreal. But already in the first week of the eight-year-old festival, which is presenting 27 companies from seven countries through Oct. 9, the lively Belgian dance scene has, as in the past, come to the fore here.

title: Clinton to Visit New Jersey
description: President Clinton will visit New Jersey on Friday to trumpet his health-care proposals, a spokeswoman for Gov. Jim Florio said today. The spokeswoman, Audrey Kelly, said the President would make a policy speech during a visit to Robert Wood Johnson University Hospital in New Brunswick and the Governor would appear with him. Though the speech falls in the final weeks of a tough re-election campaign for Mr. Florio, his aides insist that the President's visit is not political. "He will be talking about health care reform the Governor has put forth and how we in New Jersey can assist in developing national health care policy," Ms. Kelly said. "The President probably will also touch again on how crime affects health care costs."

title: PHILIP MORRIS TO BUY STAKE IN LITHUANIAN CANDY COMPANY
description: The Philip Morris Companies said yesterday that its Kraft Jacobs Suchard unit would buy 67 percent of the shares of Kaunas C.F., the leading Lithuanian chocolate maker. Terms were not disclosed. The remaining 33 percent of the company's shares will be held by Kaunas employees. After the acquisition, Kraft Jacobs will invest in modernizing Kaunas's facilities, the company said. Founded in 1888, Kaunas is in central Lithuania. It has 800 employees and had sales of about $10 million in 1992. It is the latest acquisition by Kraft Jacobs in Eastern Europe in recent months, including the confectioner Figaro in Slovakia, the coffee and spice producer Dadak in the Czech Republic, the wafer maker Olza in Poland and the Csemege confectionery plant in Hungary.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: The Real Test: With Parliament Gone, Can Yeltsin Reform the Economy?
description: For 18 months, President Boris N. Yeltsin complained that the Russian Parliament was blocking his Government's efforts to move the Russian economy toward a Western-style free market.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-17 CLINTON MEETS ON SOMALIA President Clinton met with his top advisers to review the entire Somalia operation. He sought to forge a policy that balances the need to remain in Somalia to recover American hostages and the President's own goal of putting Somalia on the road to recovery. A1 CLAN CHIEF BARS PEACE TALKS Gen. Mohammed Farah Aidid, the fugitive clan leader, said he would no longer participate in any peace talks and urged Somalis to defend themselves against United Nations "colonialism. A17

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Turner officials pull back from allowing CNN to run commercials that imitate news interviews.
description: THE Turner Broadcasting System considered, but rejected, plans to run commercials that resemble segments of news interview programs on its CNN and Headline News cable television networks.

title: Nynex Seeks Diversity as Core Business Ebbs
description: The Nynex Corporation's decision to invest $1.2 billion in the entertainment industry is based on a strategy the company began devising in February 1992.

title: Undermanned Islanders Lose in Hextall Debut
description: Opening night in the Saddledome began with fire on ice, as a large "C," representing the logo for the Calgary Flames, was set ablaze in the center face-off circle.

title: Turn On the Lights in Central Park and Improve the Security
description: To the Editor:

title: WORLD MORATORIUM ON NUCLEAR TESTS IS BROKEN BY CHINA
description: Rejecting a plea from President Clinton, China exploded a nuclear weapon at a test site beneath its western desert today, breaking an informal testing moratorium. In response, the Administration ordered preparations for a resumption of American tests.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK CITY MAYORAL RACE IS A TOSSUP

title: Zanart Publishing Inc. (NMS) reports earnings for Year to June 30
Josephine Jablons, 69, A City Opera Trustee
description: Josephine Jablons, a board member of the New York City Opera Company, died yesterday at her home in Manhattan. She was 69 and also had a home in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Somali General Denounces Further Peace Talks
description: After the fiercest battle between United Nations and Somali forces in Mogadishu, Gen. Mohammed Farah Aidid, the fugitive clan leader, said in a radio broadcast Monday night that he would no longer take part in any peace talks and urged Somalis to defend themselves against United Nations "colonialism."

title: National League Championship Matchup
description: ON THE MOUND Can They Get The Final Outs? The rotation gave the revolution the club staged over the second half in the N.L. West its momentum. It's deep and often unmerciful, paid multi-millions to allow as close to nothing as possible. The team's collective e.r.a. of 3.14 wasted the rest of the competition in the N.L. Greg Maddux should win his second straight Cy Young Award, Tom Glavine won 20 games for the third straight season and Steve Avery has the most sinister stuff of all of them. John Smoltz, the man with all the pitches and all too often the habit of wasting a great part of his talent, is a post-season deity in Atlanta. He seems to find his zone when the October moonlight finds him on the mound. Avery split his season record against the Phillies, his e.r.a. a full half a point higher versus Philadelphia than it was for the season. He will also be facing the club's right-handed lineup, certainly its more lethal incarnation. Maddux simply is the best pitcher in baseball at the moment. He walks no one, gives up a hit every five innings or so and always takes his club deep into games. Glavine, who has a mixed post-season resume at best, may enter the scene with the most to personally prove. The bullpen, as almost virtually all in baseball are, is ordinary. Mark Wohlers throws hard, but straight, and so is turning around a lot on the mound. Kent Mercker never seems to throw strikes when he has to. Steve Bedrosian and Jay Howell have been effective surprises. But the Braves have not won the World Series the last two seasons because they never seemed able to get the final out. Greg McMichael, barely invited to spring training, gets the invitation to make history for the Braves as the club's closer. But the right-hander, whose out pitches are not strikes, has been awfully suspect after a summer-long run of fantasy finishes. The Phillies, who have faced McMichael six tmes in 1993, stuck him with an 8.53 e.r.a. At Least They're Healthy Conventional wisdom says the Phillies are at the wrong end of a mismatch in this department. As usual, there's considerable truth to standard thinking. The club's starters, a revelation over the first half, were often wounded and worked over across the team's uneven trek to October's promised land. Tommy Greene has been hurt, and Terry Mulholland was once feared done for the season. All are now available and certainly capable. They may have to be much more. Their track record, though, says the corps, one augmented Danny Jackson's left-handed presence, will give the Phillies innings, keep them close enough for there to be hope that the offensive engine will wear down the opposition. Certainly, turning the games over to the bullpen will be a mortifying option. The contingent of relievers, one the front office sought all season to improve and alter, was ranked 11th in the N.L. They together amassed 24 blown saves. The Phillies, not surprisingly, were a marginal 23-20 in one-run games. Mitch Williams, the theoretical closer, is the perfect top man for a below average bullpen. His final pitching line of the season about captured the perpetually potential downside to his dramatics: 1 IP, 1 hit, 2 runs, 2 walks, 2 wild pitches. Advantage Braves IN THE FIELD Sometimes Vulnerable You don't win three straight division titles without a line of defense, and the fielding fortifications for the Braves got more imposing when McGriff was added. His bat gets people's attention and headlines and it might have got him more than a handful of MVP votes (McGriff's arrival sparked the inflation of everyone's averageinfalted the averages of his cohorts at the chop shop, but his play aty first might get the Braves an extra out or two when it counts most this series. But Atlanta, whose overall fielding efforts ranked third in the N.L., isn't without its departments of defense that trouble Manager Bobby Cox. Terry Pendleton, garnerer of Gold Gloves, has been erratic this season at third. Ron Gant, for all his speed and hustle, still can seem unrefined three years after his conversion to an outfielder. David Justice can launch the odd throw that looks more like one of his home runs. And the defense's vulnerability was on full and painful display over the season's final stretch. Freddy Krueger With a Glove It can be Nightmare on Broad Street when the Phillies slip into their slapstick routine in the field. It can happen anytime with this club, and there won't be a worse time than if the Phillies don't make the routine and remarkable plays in October that win championships. Dave Hollins is the first baseman of the future, only he now plays third base in the present. He doesn't do it soundly. John Kruk, the man who does play first, hasn't of late played it nearly as efficiently and airtightly as he had earlier in the season. The club turned the fewest number of double plays of any club in the N.L. in 1993. It also made 141 errors, their defense finding its rightfully mediocre place in the second tier of the league (9th place.) Pete Incaviglia, the man with the World's Gym upper body and world's worst set of wheels, can be an adventure in left. Lenny Dykstra still runs into walls in cnter, but doesn't pick himself up with the ball in his glove quite as often. Advantage Braves. AT THE PLATE Well-Balanced and Hot "There are good lineups at the plate - Texas, San Francisco, Philadelphia," said Ron Gant, the left-fielder for the Braves. "None are hot like we are hot." The temperature turned out these numbers - Atlanta's 169 homers led the N.L. and Gant, David Justice and Fred McGriff all hit 30 or more homers and drove in 100 or more runs. It's a lineup blessed with fabulous balance - Otis Nixon's basehit bunts and afterburners (his 47 stolen bases were good enough for 3rd in N.L.), Jeff Blauser's hit parade out of the No. 2 hole (182 for a shortstop), Terry Pendleton's decision to go nuts with the bat the last week of the season (the third baseman drove in nine over the final weekend), and Mark Lemke's repeated flair for post-season mass production. The lineup had a perfectly healthy appetitite for the strong-arm offerings of the Phillies, as Justice, Pendleton and McGriff combined to hit .333, with Justice homering three times. Gant, though, could be the wild card. With right-handers Tommy Greene and Curt Schilling coming at the Braves in Game 1 and Game 2, Gant, who hit only .191 against the Phillies, will be under the microscope to see if the breakthrough in the clutch he made throughout the second half of 1993 extends to the second season. They Score in Bunches The club nearly scored 900 runs in 1993, a staggering total that wasn't hurt by the 5.3 runs a game the club scored on average in its 12 games with the Braves. Len Dykstra, who might have been the runaway choice for N.L. MVP in the absence of Barry Bonds, is a machine of offensive menace, on base always and across the plate more than any other player in baseball this season. He's a lifetime .312 hitter against Atlanta. The heart of the order is as patient and muscular as they come - John Kruk (.430 on-base percentage, .316 average), Darren Daulton (105 r.b.i., 117 walks) and Dave Hollins (.330 against left-handers.) And the attack - Philadelphia's club average of .274 trailed only the Giants - has been aided by assorted phenomena - Pete Incaviglia drove in an astonishing 89 runs in only 368 at-bats (the left-fielder hit four homers against Atlanta pitching) and and Kevin Stocker, a minor-league promotion halfway through the season, hit .324 in 70 games. Key questions would involve how fast Daulton's bat still is (the catcher played in 147 games), how a lack of team speed might hurt the club in a short series (the Phillies were next to last in the N.L. in stolen bases), and the ability of players with great numbers but inconclusive track records (Mariano Duncan, Jim Eisenreich) to produce in the passion of post-season. Advantage Phillies. OFF THE BENCH Not Glamorous, But Solid Sid Bream, Rafael Belliard, Bill Pecota. They aren't glamorous names, but they are the estimable backbone of the bench for the Braves. They'll provide professional defense and the occasional quality at bat in a big spot. And the dugout isn't devoid entirely of intriguing mercenaries. Deion Sanders can steal a base and make an impact if asked to start. And Francisco Cabrera, whose 15 minutes of fame might have been among the most intense in baseball history hit .357 with a homer and three r.b.i. against the Phillies this year. Which Ones Are They? It's hard to separate the bench from the regulars. Jim Eisenreich hit .318 as the right-fielder against right-handers and Milt Thompson drove in 44 runs as the left-fielder against right-handers. Pete Incaviglia wreaked havoc against lefties and Wes Chamberlain hit 12 homers and 20 doubles in under 300 at-bats. The bench is deep beyond the platoon, too. Todd Pratt 87 as the backup catcher and pinch-hitter. Rickey Jordan who can homer on half-swings, hit .289. And Kim Batiste can fill the role of home-run threat. Advantage Phillies.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a "Political Memo" article on Sunday, about the political effects of the Mollen Commission's investigation of police corruption, referred incorrectly to the aftermath of televised comments by Eric Adams, head of an organization of black police officers.

title: Chairman Of Hershey Is Retiring
description: Richard A. Zimmerman, chairman and chief executive of the Hershey Foods Corporation, said yesterday that he would retire on Dec. 31. Hershey's president and chief operating officer, Kenneth L. Wolfe, will replace him, the company said.

title: Team Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
LOAN GUARANTEES FOR ISRAEL ARE CUT
description: The Clinton Administration has slashed the loan guarantees that it will give Israel next year because of Israel's continued settlement in the occupied territories and its disputed construction in East Jerusalem, officials here said today.

title: Encyclical on Morality Doesn't Stifle Debate, Church Officials Say
description: Roman Catholic officials at the Vatican and in the United States presented Pope John Paul II's new encyclical, "Veritatis Splendor" ("The Splendor of Truth"), in very conciliatory tones today. They insisted that his statement on fundamental moral theory was intended to encourage reflection and discussion of basic principles of morality, not to cut off debate.

title: Parking Rules
description: Alternate-side parking rules will be suspended in New York City tomorrow and Friday for the Jewish holidays of Shemini Atzereth and Simhath Torah. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: The Loneliness of the One-Mushroom Pasta Sauce
description: SO many kinds of mushrooms are in the markets today, even in ordinary supermarkets, that it is easy to find more than just the standard white variety. Which is great for pasta dishes, since a variety of mushrooms will play off one another and enhance the otherwise subtle taste of a one-mushroom sauce.

title: Lincoln Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a gain of $ 565,533, or 63 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Admiral Kelso Keeps His Command
description: In deciding not to sack Adm. Frank B. Kelso 2d from his post as Chief of Naval Operations, Defense Secretary Les Aspin has made a decision based on politics, not principle. By overruling Navy Secretary John H. Dalton's call to remove Admiral Kelso, Mr. Aspin spared President Clinton further corrosion of his uneasy relationship with military brass.

title: Essex County Gas Co. (NMS) reports earnings for Year to July 31
description: The company noted that in its earnings release the Massachusetts Department of Public Utilities approved a 4.2 percent rate increase, or $ 1,733,000, in the company's annual revenues. The new rates will go into effect on Dec 1. As previously reported, the company had filed for a $ 3 million rate increase last May.

title: Tom Bristol Coughran, Banking Executive, 87
description: Tom Bristol Coughran, a banking executive who was an Assistant Secretary of the Treasury during the Eisenhower Administration, died on Saturday at Alexandria Hospital in Virginia. He was 87 and lived in Falls Church, Va.

title: Buttafuoco Admits to Sex With Amy Fisher
description: Joseph Buttafuoco admitted today what most of America had believed all along: that he had had an affair with Amy Fisher.

title: U.S. Looking Ahead to Swell of Cuban Refugees
description: Acting on reports that the Cuban economy is on the verge of collapse, the Clinton Administration is drafting contingency plans for dealing with a potential wave of Cuban refugees, officials say.

title: In the City of Change, Is 'Las Vegas Landmark' an Oxymoron?
description: OCTOBER is going to be a banner month for demolitions in Las Vegas. On Oct. 27, the Dunes Hotel and its legendary 18-story sign are scheduled to become a neon-lighted memory in the American psyche. The demolition, perhaps the most lavishly choreographed architectural blowup in United States history, is being designed to do for demolition what the Folies-Bergere did for legs.

title: From Russia, a Bid to Increase Arms in Caucasus
description: Western diplomats said today that Russia asked last month for an increase in the number of tanks and heavy weapons Moscow is allowed to station in the Caucasus, where civil wars are raging in three newly independent countries, under a conventional arms reduction treaty signed three years ago.

title: Whitman Plan to Cut Taxes: Experts Taking It Seriously
description: By most accounts, Christine Todd Whitman committed a colossal political blunder when she proposed a $1.2 billion cut in income and business taxes for the financially strapped state of New Jersey. The states' editorial pages have heaped scorn on her plan and, according to polls, 70 percent of the state's citizens -- including a majority of her fellow Republicans -- simply do not believe that she can deliver on her promise to cut taxes.

title: Parking Rules
description: Alternate-side parking rules will be suspended in New York City today and tomorrow for the Jewish holidays of Shemini Atzereth and Simhath Torah. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Physicians Clinical Laboratory Inc. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: All year-ago net income, share earnings and shares outstanding are pro forma because the company was a limited partnership until Aug. 1, 1992.

title: New 'Woman Friendly' Fund Hits Its First Glitch
description: Skeptics are calling it the latest marketing gimmick of a mutual fund industry that is going to ever-greater lengths to wow investors.

title: Giants' Moore Is Back, But His Future Is Murky
description: The nameplate over Eric Moore's locker was blank, but Moore was there, sitting, talking extensively about his four-game suspension from the National Football League for violating its substance-abuse policy. Moore looked relieved to be back with the Giants. How long he'll be back is unclear, but for now he has been given a second chance.

title: Across the Globe, Expressions of Regret and Gratitude
description: From the "Say It Ain't So, Mike," headline in The Chicago Sun-Times to the special news report on Romanian television, Michael Jordan's abrupt retirement sent shock waves around the globe yesterday. And in a world where basketball has become a rare unifying force, the world reacted as one, with surprise, admiration, understanding and dismay.

title: No Headline
description: "I have nothing more to prove in basketball. I have no more challenges that I felt I could get motivated for. It doesn't have anything to do with my father's passing, or media pessure, or anything other than that I had achieved everything in basketball I could. And when that happened, I felt it was time to call it a career." MICHAEL JORDAN. [ B17:2. ]

title: Digital Board Raises Chief's Pay
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation's directors have voted a 20 percent raise for the new chief executive, Robert B. Palmer, while noting that the nation's No. 3 computer maker had come up short of its financial objectives.

title:
THE SOMALIA MISSION;
Somalis May Let Red Cross Visit Pilot Held as Hostage
description: A wounded American helicopter pilot shot down and captured by Somali guerrillas may soon get a visit by the International Red Cross and a care package to offer comfort.

title: 4 TEEN-AGERS HELD IN TOURIST KILLING
description: The authorities have charged four boys -- a 13-year-old, a 14-year-old and two 16-year-olds -- with first-degree murder in the killing of a British tourist last month. They were also charged with first-degree attempted murder and automobile theft.

title: Pop and Jazz in Review
description: Dimi Mint Abba Symphony Space Dimi Mint Abba's songs are invocations, battle cries, dances and laments. On Sunday night, performing as part of the World Music Institute's Musical World of Islam series, the Mauritanian singer's voice was by turns righteous and melancholy, flamboyant and delicate, forceful yet attentive to the finest details of pitch and inflection.

title: Review/Television; The Effect of Images on Governmental Policy
description: So now we must add to the nightmarish images of our century the corpse of an American soldier being dragged through dusty streets by an exulting band. The picture would be painful under any circumstances, but there is a twist of the knife: the young man was in Somalia as part of an effort to feed people.

title: COMPANY NEWS: The New Technologies; Americans See Future and Say, 'So What?'
description: The companies seeking fortunes in whiz-bang high-tech goodies we are constantly told are just over the horizon have their work cut out for them, according to a public opinion poll commissioned by the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers.

title: Real Estate Investment Trust of Calif.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a $ 146,000 gain on the sale of real estate in the quarter and 9 months.c-Included a $ 2,105,000 gain on the sale of real estate.

title: Review/Dance; Translating Lofty Goals Into Steps
description: Coyote Dancers, a new group directed by Maher Benham, gave a polished performance on Sunday afternoon at the Marymount Manhattan Theater. Two guest artists, Maxine Sherman and Steve Rooks, both former members of the Martha Graham Dance Company, enhanced the occasion. Yet the matinee was disconcerting because Ms. Benham's choreography seldom matched the loftiness of her stated intentions.

title: A Victim's Mantle for Mr. Giuliani
description: The sudden ferocity of the New York City mayoral campaign arises, at least in part, from this fact: To the surprise of people on both sides, the re-election campaign of Mayor David Dinkins is not dead yet. It will be very hard for the Mayor to hold the narrow lead over his Republican challenger, Rudolph Giuliani, that he has in some polls. But the tightness of the contest has produced some transparently ugly politics.

title: Virginia Bracker, 86, Foreign Correspondent
description: Virginia Lee Bracker, a retired reporter and foreign correspondent for The New York Times, died on Tuesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 86.

title: AT HOME WITH: Niki de Saint Phalle; An Artist, Her Monsters, Her Two Worlds
description: LUNCH is about to be served at the country home of Niki de Saint Phalle, and there is a worm on her chair. "Yeuuch," the French-American artist says, recoiling in horror. "Do you think you could remove that?"

title: For St. Petersburg, It's All Just Politics
description: The city known in Soviet times as "the Cradle of the Revolution" sat this one out, and there was none of the massed public support for President Boris N. Yeltsin that did much to discourage the coup leaders of August 1991.

title: On Both Sides: Disarray and Indecision
description: In the night before the final and fateful assault on the Parliament center, both the White House and the Kremlin, the headquarters of competing claims to Russia's power a scant three miles apart, seemed caught in illusion and indecision.

title: Yeltsin Cancels Guards at Lenin's Tomb
description: At 4 P.M., the usual clutch of onlookers gathered for one of Moscow's most venerable rituals, the changing of the guard at Lenin's Mausoleum on Red Square.

title: YELTSIN, IN SPEECH, APPEALS FOR CALM AFTER 'NIGHTMARE'
description: In his first address to the nation since army tanks crushed an uprising against him, President Boris N. Yeltsin called on Russians today to put the "nightmare of these black days" behind them, and affirmed that elections to a new Parliament will be held Dec. 12.

title: Argentbank reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest quarter included a $ 235,000 securities gain relating to the call of a $ 5 million security.

title: Jordan About to Become Last Year's Role Model
description: Many young basketball players yesterday mourned Michael Jordan's retirement. It was too soon, some said. They didn't understand.

title: A Legacy as Jordan Departs: Stars Are Corporate Heroes
description: Magic Johnson once told of how he tried, early in his career, to persuade the sneaker company he had a contract with to market a basketball shoe in his very famous name. He said he was told by a company official, with all due respect, that "no basketball player could ever sell a shoe."

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Charles Keating's Lasting Taint
description: Overdrafts at the House bank unseated more than a few incumbents last year. Charles Keating is having a similar effect in the Senate, albeit on a smaller scale.

title: Health Care Spending Is Found to Vary Greatly State by State
description: The Federal Government issued new data today showing huge variations in health care spending from state to state. The figures suggest that the Government would have difficulty setting local budgets for health spending, as President Clinton has proposed.

title: Settlement In Lawsuit Against De Kooning
description: A lawsuit that raised questions about the authenticity of a group of sculptures attributed to Willem de Kooning was settled yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan when representatives of the Abstract Expressionist artist and of his late wife's estate agreed to a financial settlement with Philip Pavia, a Long Island sculptor who filed the suit three years ago.

title: At Visa, New Quest for U.S. Growth
description: When Carl F. Pascarella abruptly replaced H. Robert Heller as president of Visa U.S.A. in late August, he became the third person to hold that job in less than four years.

title: Nothing Left to Prove
description: His retirement was shocking. His career was spectacular. And his legacy is secure.

title: Books of The Times; The Trillings: Two Portraits in One
description: The Beginning of the Journey The Marriage of Diana and Lionel Trilling By Diana Trilling Illustrated. 442 pages. Harcourt Brace

title: Two Candidates Present Two New Yorks
description: In the New York City of Rudolph W. Giuliani's television ads, people live in fear. They worry about drug dealers, high taxes and bad schools. They are scrappy and strident, and their voice has a timbre that is straight out of Brooklyn.

title: Keenan Is on the Defensive
description: Mike Keenan came to the Rangers' practice facility at Rye Playland in Rye, N.Y., yesterday morning convinced that a few of his original starting six defensemen would be on the bench tonight when New York is host to the Tampa Bay Lightning at Madison Square Garden and a few of his rookies would get a chance to play.

title: Insurer to Pay for Investigation of Its Sales Tactics
description: The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company yesterday agreed to pay for an independent investigation of charges that its insurance agents engaged in unethical practices in selling tens of thousands of whole life policies around the United States.

title: Redskins' Quarterback? It's a Multiple-Choice Test
description: When the Redskins play the Giants Sunday in Washington, their starting quarterback will probably be Mark Rypien. Or maybe Rich Gannon. Or possibly Cary Conklin.

title: Two Killed in Crash Of Aircraft on L.I.
description: A part-time flight instructor and his student were killed today when a twin-engine aircraft the student was piloting crashed and burned in a wooded area near the East Hampton town airport.

title: CCA Industries Inc.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Now, the Little Prince Can Come to Supper
description: "THE LITTLE PRINCE" has endured for 50 years. No one knows if the plates, cup and porringer inspired by the beloved book will last that long, but they are sunny to look at and are sweet without being cloying.

title: Reform Welfare? What For?
description: The Clinton Administration's agenda is so filled with issues that it would probably welcome a chance to put one or two of them aside. So here is an issue that could easily be taken off the top of the list: welfare reform.

title: Schintzius and Coleman Are Focal Points of Nets
description: On the eve of the opening of training camp, the New Jersey Nets matched the Milwaukee offer sheet for 7-foot-2-inch reserve center Dwayne Schintzius, and kept the lines of communication open on the contract extension for Derrick Coleman, their 6-10 starting power forward.

title: Wyandanch Seeks U.S. Help in Fighting Crime
description: Desperate for help in waging a war they fear they are losing, civic leaders turned today to a top Federal law-enforcement official for aid in ridding this community of drug dealers and prostitutes.

title: Review/Fashion; Mere Meets More in Milan
description: For a time yesterday, as the number of spring and summer showings passed the midpoint, it looked as if fashion had reached the end of the road.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: GUILTY VERDICT IN RITUAL SLAYING After seven hours of deliberations, a jury found James P. Wanger guilty of murder and 10 other charges against him in the bizarre ritual slaying of a teen-age friend. A1. KELLY REVERSES ON POLICE MONITORING New York City's highest police official reversed his opposition to the creation of an independent monitor to review the Police Department's anti-corruption programs as long as he retained the power to investigate and punish wrongdoers. A1.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: THE 4-year-old white girl studied the photographs the researcher had given her. Each picture showed pairs of children -- one black and one white -- in ambiguous, nonthreatening situations, like two children in a playground. The researcher asked the girl questions about what she saw, such as: "Which child is the bad child?" or "Which child will win the game of checkers?"

title: SPRINT VENTURE TO OFFER COMPUTER TELEPHONE SERVICE
description: The Sprint Corporation, the nation's third-largest long-distance carrier, will team up with Minnesota Supercomputer Center Inc. to market high-performance computer services over its long-distance fiber optic network. As envisioned, an oil exploration company, for example, could transmit billions of bits of seismic data to a supercomputer, which could then compile it into vivid images of underground geological formations. Using a technology called Asynchronous Transfer Mode, Sprint will be able to transmit the equivalent of four full-length books a second. Minnesota Supercomputer, an 11-year-old company with $25 million in sales, operates five supercomputers.

title: Alpha Microsystems (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 29
description: b-Included a tax benefit of $ 28,000 in the quarter and 6 months.c-Net loss and included restructuring charge of $ 2.7 million associated with the closure of the company's Italian and French operations in the quarter and 6 months.Alpha Microsystems said the improvement in earnings for the current quarter reflected reductions in operating expense levels, the absence of a restructuring charge, the continued performance of service operations and contributions from its vertical niche software initiatives.

title: Library at Time Cut by a Third
description: Time Inc. informed its library staff yesterday that 43 jobs, about one-third of the library workers, would be eliminated in six months. The move was described as part of a transition to greater reliance on electronic research.

title: American Exchange Shifts Its Account
description: The American Stock Exchange in New York said yesterday that it had selected McCann-Erickson New York to handle its account, previously at DeVito/Verdi in New York for three years. Billings were estimated at $3 million.

title: Review/Film; Sound (and Reality) Check For an Underground Band
description: Even by the forgiving standards that rock critics tend to apply to dedicated underground bands with little commercial potential, the music of Half Japanese, a group from Uniontown, Md., is difficult to admire. Formed in 1975 by the brothers Jad and David Fair, the band has always prided itself on not being able to play its instruments. And Jad Fair, its indomitably cheery lead singer and chief songwriter, has a voice that comes about as close as rock singing can to sounding like chalk on a blackboard.

title: Pasqua: From First To Last
description: All Dan Pasqua wanted to do was fit in. That is all any reserve who is thrust into the spotlight really wants to do. Maybe Pasqua thought about smacking a few hits, but he primarily wanted to make the plays at first base and remain anonymous afield as a defensive replacement for Frank Thomas, the ailing White Sox slugger.

title: INSIDE
description: Penned by a Serial Bomber

title: Safety Concerns Limit the Ability Of Reporters to Work in Somalia
description: Delays and confusion over information on the major battle between United Nations forces and Somali militiamen over the weekend has underscored the difficulties for journalists operating in Mogadishu.

title: And Now, Whoppers vs. Waffles
description: On the eve of their first face-to-face debate, Gov. Jim Florio and his Republican challenger, Christine Todd Whitman, spent today prepping while their surrogates participated in a food fight of sorts.

title: Pop and Jazz in Review
description: Pinetop Perkins Village Vanguard 178 Seventh Avenue South (at 11th Street) Greenwich Village Through tonight

title: Another Vote
description: While the Mayoral race captures the attention of most of New York City, another campaign is taking place this week. For the first time in the history of their migration to the continental United States, mainland residents of Puerto Rican ancestry will have a chance to voice their preference on the island's future -- whether it should remain a commonwealth, form an independent nation or become the 51st state.

title: WHERE TO FIND IT
description: NO one really knows who gets credit for devising the hooked rug. Some view the rugs, made from fabric strips pulled through a woven base with a wood-handled crochet hook, as true, born-in-America folk art. Others, notably W. W. Kent in his 1930 book "The Hooked Rug," trace the craft's origins to the sixth-century Copts or Bronze Age Vikings.

title: Bond Firms Halt Funding
description: The nation's two largest underwriters of municipal bonds have agreed to temporarily stop making political contributions to state and city officials.

title: New Jersey Teen-Ager Convicted of Ritual Slaying
description: After seven hours of deliberations, a jury today found James P. Wanger guilty of murder and 10 other charges against him in the bizarre ritual slaying of a teen-age friend.

title: RABIN AND ARAFAT HOLD FIRST TALKS
description: Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin of Israel and Yasir Arafat, the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, met here today to coordinate the transition to Palestinian self-rule in the Gaza Strip and in Jericho, on the Israeli-occupied West Bank. After the meeting, they said talks on administrative details would begin Oct. 13 in Cairo and in Taba, an Egyptian resort.

description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $ 86,000 in the quarter and $ 120,000 in the year, and the year also included a gain of $ 6,000 from adoption of new accounting method for income taxes.The company is listed on the Boston Stock Exchange.

description: Imposing a negotiated sentence that he said was not adequate to the crime, a state judge sentenced Katherine Ann Power today to 8 to 12 years in a Massachusetts prison for her role in a 1970 bank robbery that resulted in the murder of a Boston police officer.

title: Market Place; A new company's process excites investors in waste disposal.
description: INNOVATIVE technology combined with a careful reading of rules governing the handling and disposal of hazardous waste may turn into a winning combination for a start-up company named Molten Metal Technology Inc. of Waltham, Mass. Early buyers of its stock have done pretty well, even though the company is not expected to earn any money for at least another calendar year.

description: Ellington's New York Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue at 103d Street; (212) 534-1672.

title: An Elusive Clan Father Is Peacekeepers' Nemesis
description: In the Somali language, the surname of Gen. Mohammed Farah Aidid, the powerful clan leader waging the vicious guerrilla war in the streets of Mogadishu, carries this meaning: "He who will not be insulted."

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Sept. 29 about William Ballard, an architect who guided New York City planning from 1963 to 1966 and who died on Sept. 27, referred incorrectly to his second wife. She is Martha Moore Ballard, the former Martha Moore Muzzey, and she survives him. The couple were divorced in 1945.

description: Companies

title: Lemaire-Type Defense Gives Devils a Victory
description: On the day in June he was hired as the coach of the Devils, Jacques Lemaire made it clear that defense would be his top priority. In their opening game of the season tonight, the Devils made it clear their coach knew what he was talking about.

title: Review/Music; 4 Siblings Committed Both to Play And Teach

What sets these four siblings apart is an exceptional commitment to musical education. They are quartet in residence in the small town of Jesup, Iowa, where they have aroused enthusiasm for chamber music among young listeners.

title: The Islanders' New Line Looks Good Amid Defeat
