description: For Raymond W. Smith, the 55-year-old chairman of the Bell Atlantic Corporation, this week has been not only the culmination of his drive to reinvent Bell Atlantic, but one worthy of the most audacious of riverboat gamblers.

title: Synovus Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary charge of $ 2,912,000 from the early extinguishment of debt in the quarter and 9 months.

title: Cypress Semiconductor reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
Digital Sound Corp.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Boston Acoustics reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 25

Books of The Times;
The Road to Saigon and On: A Reporter's Story
description: Muddy Boots and Red Socks A Reporter's Life By Malcolm W. Browne Illustrated. 366 pages. Times Books/ Random House. $23.

title: Is Women's Health Harmed By Medical Specialization?
description: Medical care for most men is one-stop shopping: a trip to a general doctor for a physical examination that includes full preventive care. But that approach works poorly for a woman, new studies have shown, with tests like Pap smears often overlooked, particularly if the doctor is a man.

title: WD-40 Co. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: On April 8, the company reached an out-of-court settlement with two former commissioned sales corporations who brought an action against the company on April 30, 1992. The suit was settled for a total sum of $ 2.5 million and is included in the 1993 results. This settlement does not constitute an admission of liability by WD-40 for any of the claims asserted in the action, it said.

title: Rembert Is Waived After Being Charged
description: The Cincinnati Bengals waived wide receiver REGGIE REMBERT yesterday after he was arrested and charged with driving under the influence.

title: From Top to Bottom, Oilers Are Club Chaos
description: The Houston Oilers returned to the scene of the crime Monday night at Rich Stadium and repeated a much worse offense. Ridiculed and embarrassed in a playoff loss to Buffalo last season in which their lead was the biggest ever squandered in a National Football League game, the Oilers made it much simpler this time.

title: Ball State Loses Coach and Player
description: Ball State Coach DICK HUNSAKER resigned, and his star forward, STEVE PAYNE, was declared ineligible yesterday after the school said it had discovered National Collegiate Athletic Association rules violations.

title: Anne Thompson MacDonald, 96, Founder of Recording for the Blind
description: Anne Thompson MacDonald, the founder of Recording for the Blind, a nonprofit organization that has put more than 80,000 books on tapes for blind and learning-disabled students since 1948, died on Saturday at a nursing home in Huntington, L.I. She was 96 and had lived in Manhattan.

title: Sports of The Times; Stew's Home Wherever He Pitches
description: DAVE STEWART has an explanation why he has never lost a league championship game. He says he is a hard worker because his parents were hard workers.

title: German Tells Why He Stabbed Seles
description: GUNTER PARCHE, an unemployed lathe operator, testified yesterday at his trial in Hamburg, Germany, that the losses of STEFFI GRAF left him so devastated him that he sometimes lost the will to live.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Chrysler and Subaru Shift Accounts to New Agencies
description: Chrysler and Subaru said yesterday that they would change advertising agencies in a surprising one-two punch that underlined the tumultuous nature of the American car market.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Penguins in Miami? The Florida Panthers' debut at Miami Arena included everything except an upset. Martin Straka and Joe Mullen scored to help the Pittsburgh Penguins beat expansion Florida, 2-1, last night. Before a sellout crowd of 14,372, the Panthers' Scott Mellanby scored the final goal of the game at 11 minutes 32 seconds of the third period. Straka, who came into the game tied for the National Hockey League lead with five goals, scored on a rebound to break a scoreless tie at 17:40 of the second period. Mullen scored a short-handed, unassisted goal at 3:51 of the third period. (AP) Flyers 5, Sabres 3: Eric Lindros's goal with 5:17 remaining in the third period broke a 3-3 tie and lifted host Philadelphia to the victory over Buffalo, which had led by 3-1. Philadelphia Coach Terry Simpson united last season's line of Eric Lindros, Mark Recchi and Brent Fedyk late in the second period. The threesome responded with three of the team's four third-period goals. (AP)

title: Culbro Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
description: b-Included a charge of $ 9,177,000 from the cumulative effect of adoption of SFAS No. 106, ''Accounting for Postretirement Benefits Other Than Pensions,'' effective at the beginning of the current fiscal year.c-Net income

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the listing of equity offerings in Business Day on Monday, under the headline "Equity Issues This Week," misstated the underwriter for a stock offering by Danka Business Systems P.L.C. The underwriter is Robert W. Baird & Company, not Prudential Securities.

title: Lapse in Sounding Alarm Is Linked to Derailment
description: A towboat pilot was lost in a predawn fog without a compass or nautical charts when his vessel rammed a railroad bridge, but he could have still averted the worst wreck in Amtrak's history if he had promptly notified the authorities, Coast Guard and Amtrak officials told Congress today.

title: Cherokee reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
description: b-Net loss and after a payment of $ 264,000 for preferred dividends.

title: White Rose Crafts reports earnings for Year to July 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Food Notes
description: A Store Gets a Make-Over

title: Oakhurst Capital reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
description: b-Included a loss of $ 16,000 from discontinued operations in the quarter and 6 months.c-Net income

title: Redskins Sign Willis to Shore Up Line
description: Down to only three healthy players on the defensive line, the Washington Redskins signed 11-year veteran defensive end KEITH WILLIS yesterday.

title: A Decade Later, It's Torvill and Dean Again
description: It is early yet, but the 1990's have not been kind to comebacks. Bjorn Borg hauled his wood racquet out of the closet and got whacked. Mark Spitz hauled out his skimpy bathers and got lapped. Magic Johnson gathered up his courage and caught flak.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: International Paper Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a charge of $ 28 million to reflect the increase in the federal income tax rate. The adjustment consists of a one-time noncash charge of $ 25 million to revalue deferred tax balances and a $ 3 million charge to reflect the higher tax accrual for the first 9 months of the year.c-Included extraordinary charges on the early extinguishment of debt of $ 2,000,000 in the quarter and $ 6,000,000 in the 9 months. The 9 months also was after a charge of $ 50,000,000 from an accounting adjustment.

title: Sihanouk Calls His Cancer Unthreatening
description: King Norodom Sihanouk of Cambodia said today that a tumor removed near his prostate gland in China last week was cancerous but that the cancer had not spread and was not life-threatening.

title: Republic Bancorp Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a gain of $ 950,000, or 7 cents a share, from an accounting adjustment.Year-ago per share earnings follow preferred dividend payments.Per share earnings reflected a previously reported 10 percent stock dividend to issued Oct. 29.

title: A Surge in Advocacy Within Parent Groups; P.T.A.'s Shift From Bastions of the Status Quo to Challengers of Authority
description: Until recently the parents at Public School 154 in Flushing, Queens, played little role in school life, split as they were into immigrant groups from 20 countries and harried by the demands of their jobs.

title: Review/Film Festival; A Walter Mitty Dreams of Fame on Football Field
description: Some people dream of being rock stars, others Nobel Prize-winning authors. The dream of Daniel E. (Rudy) Ruettiger (Sean Astin), the central character of David Anspaugh's film "Rudy," is only a little more down-to-earth, given the odds against him. Physically small and a mediocre student, he lives to play football for Notre Dame.

title: Asian Republic Still Caught in Web of Communism
description: When the Soviet Union was disintegrating, one of the first statues of Lenin to be pulled down in Central Asia was in this sleepy capital. It was replaced by a statue of Abul Qasim Firdawsi, a 10th-century poet.

title: New Jersey Reservoir at Drought Level
description: Northern New Jersey's biggest reservoir, the Wanaque, has been drawn down to its lowest level since the drought of the mid-1960's, and the agency that operates it wants the state to order a stop to heavy demands on it.

title: Theater in Review
description: Some People Performance Space 122 150 First Avenue (at Ninth Street) East Village Written and performed by Danny Hoch; lighting design, David Castaneda; technical director, Sarah Sidman. Presented by Performance Space 122.

title: So Far, the Phillies Defy Both Logic and the Braves
description: It's a good thing the Atlanta Braves and the Philadelphia Phillies got a breather from their National League Championship Series yesterday. They needed it, if only to try to figure out the total upheaval of the norm that has occurred through the first five zany games of the series.

title: FOURTH FINANCIAL ACQUIRING GREAT SOUTHERN BANCORP
description: The Fourth Financial Corporation will acquire the Great Southern Bancorp for about $84.1 million in stock under a definitive merger agreement reached yesterday. Fourth Financial said in July that it would buy Great Southern, a savings and loan based in Springfield, Mo.

title: AT LUNCH WITH: Joyce Randolph and Audrey Meadows; Trixie and Alice, on Their Own
description: SOMETIMES an actress becomes so identified with one role in her career that the character clings to her as stubbornly as puppy hair to a navy blazer, impossible to brush off.

title: Giuliani Accuses Dinkins Of Being a Weak Leader
description: Rudolph W. Giulinai made a blistering advertising attack on Mayor David N. Dinkins yesterday, criticizing his record and accusing him of weak leadership that has caused the city to lose 350,000 jobs, allowed government scandals and public disorder to flourish and encouraged racial divisiveness.

title: Shelby Williams Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
'Art' Is No Luxury
description: New York City is a difficult place to find an apartment, a cheap hotel room, a seat on the subway or, all too often, a moment's peace. But finding a theater, a museum, an art gallery, a dance group or a concert is a cinch. The city is up to its ears in the arts.

title: Garden Q. & A.
description: Autumn Splendor

title: Car Towing Conducted As Security Is Intensified
description: The towing operation that led to the death of a housing police officer last week in Washington Heights continued yesterday, as officers patrolled rooftops and a police helicopter hovered to provide increased security.

title: Park Communications Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Somali Toll in Clash Was 300, U.S. Says
description: About 300 Somalis are believed to have been killed in the street fighting in Mogadishu on Oct. 3, and hundreds of those treated in hospitals were women and children, military and relief officials say.

title: Brokerage Firm To New York Shop
description: A small New York agency has been awarded a major account by a discount brokerage firm based in Toronto.

title: California Water Service Co.  (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Metal Wizards: The Magic in a Repair
description: So many repairs, so little time.

title: 4 North Americans Win Nobel Prizes for Science
description: For their landmark contributions to the science of genetics, an American and a Canadian yesterday shared the 1993 Nobel Prize in Chemistry. Also yesterday, two Americans shared the Nobel physics prize for their investigation of gigantic gravitational forces exerted by ultradense stars.

title: A MERGER OF GIANTS: The Top Executives; A Corporate Man and a Cable King
description: They come from opposite directions. John C. Malone -- called the King of Cable by his allies, a ruthless monopolist by his foes -- built the nation's largest cable television empire from scratch with daring and debt. Raymond W. Smith plodded along the traditional corporate route to the helm of an even larger company, whose main business was and still is providing 18 million dull dial tones for local telephone customers.

title: Greenspan and Panel Clash Over Fed's Status
description: The Federal Reserve came under fierce attack at a Congressional hearing today, as House members called it undemocratic, unaccountable and an exclusive club made up mostly of white males.

title: 2-Inch Crack Cited in Plane That Lost an Engine
description: Federal safety officials said today that an engine fell off a Boeing 747 cargo jet over Anchorage in March because of unusually strong turbulence and an undetected two-inch crack in the pylon connecting the engine to the wing.

title: Ballard Medical Prod reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago results are restated to reflect a 4-for-3 stock split, effective Feb. 26.

title: Despite Scandal, Politicians Still Want Wall St. Money
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York is already feeling the pinch of the move on Wall Street to stop political contributions aimed at winning bond-selling business. Invitations to be on the committee for his Victory 1994 dinner on Dec. 1 were being opened on Wall Street just as 11 major firms last week announced a moratorium on contributions.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Two Supreme Court justices, SANDRA DAY O'CONNOR and RUTH BADER GINSBURG, attended a reception at the Court on Tuesday evening and came away with something new to wear: T-shirts that read "The Supremes" on the front and either "I'm Sandra, Not Ruth" or "I'm Ruth, Not Sandra" on the back.

title: Israel Glasser, Dean And Professor, 73, At 2-Year Colleges
description: Dr. Israel Glasser, an educator and administrator in the municipal college system for 45 years, most recently at Kingsborough Community College in Brooklyn, died on Monday at his Brooklyn home. He was 73.

title: Retirement Care Associates Inc. reports earnings for Year to June 30
Hynes Urges Reno To Bring Charges On Crown Heights
description: The Brooklyn District Attorney has argued to the United States Attorney General, Janet Reno, that she has ample authority to prosecute a black teen-ager for civil rights violations in the slaying of a Hasidic Jew during the 1991 Crown Heights racial violence.

title: Teen-Age Pregnancy Deserves Moral Censure
description: To the Editor:

title: Patents Don't Grant Exclusive Right to Market
description: To the Editor:

title: 32,000 New Yorkers Vote on Puerto Rico
description: Nearly 32,000 New Yorkers of Puerto Rican background turned out last week for a symbolic vote on whether Puerto Rico should remain a commonwealth of the United States or seek statehood or independence, it was announced yesterday.

title: Structural Dynamics Research Corp. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest periods' share earnings included gain of 1 cent a share on restoration of research and experimentation tax credit.

title: Campaign Trail; Rangel to Ask Farrakhan for a Delay
description: Representative Charles B. Rangel said yesterday that he would ask the Rev. Louis Farrakhan, the Nation of Islam leader, to postpone a politically awkward rally planned for Yankee Stadium three days before the New York City mayoral election.

title: The Wonderful, Horrible Life of Leni Riefenstahl; Riefenstahl, in a Long Close-Up
description: Ray Muller's "Wonderful, Horrible Life of Leni Riefenstahl" is a big, long (over three hours), sometimes clunky but consistently fascinating documentary portrait of the woman most easily identified as Hitler's favorite film maker, with good reason. Ms. Riefenstahl's two outstanding films, "Triumph of the Will" (1935) and "Olympia" (1938), for all of their esthetic glories, served the propaganda machine of National Socialism in ways that probably neither Hitler nor Ms. Riefenstahl could have foreseen.

title: Hubbell Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a charge of $ 16,506,000 from a change in accounting principles.

title: Don't Blame TV for Getting Us Into Somalia; U.S. Support Is Vital
description: To the Editor:

title: Birminghman Steel Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Latest share earnings included a gain of 2 cents a share from the adoption of FASB 109.Year-ago share earnings are restated to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid Dec. 16, 1992.

title: Texas Instruments
description: The stock of Texas Instruments Inc. has dropped precipitously since Sept. 27, when it closed at $80.75, reflecting analysts' views that semiconductor growth may be slowing. Although Texas Instruments has not yet reported third-quarter earnings, profits of some of its competitors have been lower than expected. Yesterday, its shares fell more than 6 percent.

title: Cunningham Among Bessie Winners
description: Merce Cunningham, Beverly Blossom and the Five Lesbian Brothers were among the 26 winners of Bessies, more formally known as New York Dance and Performance Awards, which were awarded on Monday night in a private ceremony at the Dance Theater Workshop. The awards, given to dancers, musicians, scenic and lighting designers, a photographer and a dance producer, are named after the dance educator Bessie Schonberg.

title: Scouting Report From Ryan: Brister Little Threat to Giants
description: Buddy Ryan may be having his own problems in Houston, where the Oilers (1-4) are about to be run out of town. He may be on the verge of losing his job as defensive coordinator. But he still found time to talk about the Eagles, Giants, and the National Football Conference East, a division his defense dominated for so many years when he was the Philadelphia head coach.

title: Transactions
description: Basketball National Basketball Association

title: Coke Gives More To Creative Artists
description: The Coca-Cola Company has awarded the Creative Artists Agency another assignment for its flagship Coca-Cola Classic brand, this one involving advertising for the 1994 World Cup.

title: Early Signs of a Russian Winter
description: This is the fifth season of the National Hockey League's peace dividend, the emigration of players from the former Soviet Union, a stream that began with the end of the Cold War. Finally, New York fans are getting a look at the potential of Moscow by the Hudson.

title: No Headline
description: "This is not a conventional merger in any sense. It's all about coming together to build the next generation of technology and services." -- JAMES MOORE, a consultant, on the merger of Bell Atlantic and Tele-Communications Inc. [ D10:4. ]

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: A Merger of Giants

title: Anti-abortion campaign raises questions of proper role of TV.
description: AN expensive anti-abortion campaign, which has sparked debate over advertisements advocating points of view on controversial issues, has begun running on New York area television stations.

title: Essay; Waco, Reno, Iraqgate
description: If you were the Attorney General and had something terribly embarrassing to hide, to whom would you turn to oh-so-gently investigate your conduct?

title: Looking for Playmates, U.S. Finds Mexico
description: With a place in the World Cup already secured five years ago when the United States was named the host of next summer's extravaganza, the American team has been trying to prepare for the sport's pre-eminent event by playing competitive exhibition games in place of the tension-filled qualifying matches.

title: A MERGER OF GIANTS: The Vision; A Phone-Cable Vehicle for the Data Superhighway
description: The Bell Atlantic Corporation and Tele-Communications Inc. announced the biggest media merger in history yesterday, a deal offering perhaps the clearest evidence yet that American industry is serious about building the vaunted "information superhighway" of the future.

title: INSIDE
description: 4 Share Nobel Prizes In Physics and Chemistry

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Sept. 13, about a visit to the Young Israel synagogue of Kew Gardens Hills, Queens, by the Israeli Ambassador to the United States, after the Israeli-Palestinian peace agreement, misstated the affiliation of the protester being restrained, and characterized the behavior of the congregation incorrectly. In a letter dated Sept. 13, the congregation's rabbi pointed out that the protester was a member of a militant Jewish group, Kahane Chai, and that no member of the congregation took part in the disruption. This correction was delayed by an editing oversight.

title: U.S. MOVE ANGERS DIPLOMATS IN HAITI
description: One day after the abrupt withdrawal of a ship carrying 218 American and Canadian soldiers, some Western diplomats here expressed outrage that the United States had seemingly capitulated in the face of opposition by the Haitian military to a international settlement of this country's crisis.

title: Right Move; Wrong Stock
description: Investors rushed to buy shares of TCI yesterday after Tele-Communications Inc. and Bell Atlantic said they would merge. But there was one problem: they bought the wrong stock.

title: Review/Film Festival; Chillingly Clear Recall Of the Unspeakable
description: Although "Birthplace," Pavel Lozinski's documentary about an American Jew's return to his native village in Poland, unfolds in a quiet, unremarkable manner, this film is shocking simply on the basis of what is being said. Henry Greenberg has gone back to inquire about the fates of his father and brother, and a surprising number of elderly villagers remember exactly what happened to them.

title: CHRONICLE
description: JOSEPH BAUM has long been a prominent figure on the New York restaurant scene: he is the creator of establishments, past and present, like Windows on the World, Aurora, La Fonda del Sol, the Four Seasons and the restored Rainbow Room at Rockefeller Center. But there are those who remember him in a different kind of kitchen, the one on the U.S.S. Lindsey, a minelayer that was blown apart in a kamikaze attack southwest of Okinawa on April 12, 1945. Mr. Baum, then 22, was the supply officer on the vessel.

title: Pop and Jazz in Review
description: Huggy Bear and the Frumpies ABC No Rio 156 Rivington Street Lower East Side

title: Israelis and the P.L.O. Meet: Peace Is in the Details; Talks in Cairo
description: Foreign Minister Shimon Peres and Mahmoud Abbas, of the P.L.O., met here today to carry out the transfer of authority.

title: Remains of Vehicle Shown To Jury in Explosion Case
description: The skeletal remains of a motor vehicle were hauled before the jury in the World Trade Center bombing trial yesterday as the prosecution presented its first evidence to tie the four defendants to a van the Government claims carried the bomb into an underground garage last February.

title: Reviews/Dance; A Questioning of Sexual Identity
description: The dancing is fast, furious and fabulous, the choreographer himself has an eye-riveting presence, the music ranges from Stravinsky and Ravel to Yoko Ono and Elvis Presley. Like everything else onstage, the occasional decor, including Cindy Sherman's slides of mummies and eyeballs, is never dull.

title: For New Jersey Dog, 1,000 Days on Death Row; Is Taro Vicious? Who Cares? By Now, Most of the State's Judicial System
description: The numbers just keep growing bigger in the saga of a death-row dog that has spent more than 1,000 days at the Bergen County Jail, running up at least $100,000 in legal costs and upkeep charges.

title: SLOVENIA REPORTS A WEAPONS CACHE
description: Slovenian authorities have seized a large cache of infantry weapons that they said were destined for the Muslim-led armed forces of Bosnia and Herzegovina, in violation of an international arms embargo.

title: Columbia Poised for Start of Longest Shuttle Flight
description: The space shuttle Columbia was poised today to begin the longest flight of the shuttle program, a two-week mission dedicated to medical experiments involving seven astronauts and 48 rats.

title: Reviews/Dance; Different Mood for 'Rite'
description: Martha Graham's version of Stravinsky's "Rite of Spring," which was a savage tiger of a dance at its premiere in 1984, is looking a bit like a sassy kitten in its current production by the Martha Graham Dance Company. Although some of the work's ferocity has diminished, this "Rite" still permits dancers to offer distinctive interpretations of its leading roles, the Chosen One and the Shaman, as Christine Dakin and Peter London demonstrated on Tuesday night at City Center.

title: Christine O'Reilly, 25, Tennis-Playing Triplet
description: Christine O'Reilly, one of the tennis-playing triplets from Ridgewood, N.J., died on Sunday at the University of California hospital at Irvine. She never regained consciousness after suffering a severe head injury in an automobile accident in Irvine early Saturday morning. She was 25.

title: People
description: * Ron Louie was named creative director at the Evans Group, Seattle, succeeding Mike Mogelgaard, who was promoted to executive creative director for the agency's eight offices. Mr. Louie was previously a senior vice president and creative director at DDB Needham New York.

title: Sports of The Times; Roping Maddux's Calf
description: WHEN Darren Daulton slashed a two-run double down the right-field foul line for the Phillies in the third inning, the Veterans Stadium voices roared, "Whoop, there it is" -- the latest streetcorner slogan. When Dave Hollins crashed a two-run homer in the fifth, they roared, "Whoop, there it is." And when Mickey Morandini hooked a two-run triple into the right-field corner in the sixth, they roared, "Whoop, there it is."

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the sentencing of two Detroit police officers convicted of beating a motorist to death referred incorrectly to the Rodney G. King case. Mr. King was injured in a beating by police officers in Los Angeles; he was not beaten to death.

title: AT HOME WITH: Reno; When a Good Enemy Is Hard to Find
description: RENO doesn't blush, but her blaring voice drops to a conspiratorial whisper as she comes out of the musical closet and admits that her taste is strictly white bread.

title: Jets Win Argument, But Still Lose Game
description: The loss wasn't reversed, but the Jets gained a measure of satisfaction yesterday when the National Football League admitted there were errors by the clock operator and an official on the field at the end of Sunday's game against the Raiders in Los Angeles.

title: Nichols Research Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Don't Blame TV for Getting Us Into Somalia
description: To the Editor:

title: National Book Awards Remove a Finalist
description: Judges for the 1993 National Book Awards have removed Juliet Wittman from the list of finalists for the nonfiction award because the author informed them that she was a British citizen and therefore ineligible for the award. The judges have named a new finalist, Peter Svenson, the author of "Battlefield: Farming a Civil War Battleground" (Faber & Faber).

title: In Heart of Gun Country, Utah Is Changing Its Mind
description: Like starting to drive or date, owning a gun has long been a rite of passage for teen-agers in Utah, a state where many schools once closed during deer hunting season to accommodate the sport.

title: Greene Gives Braves His New Look
description: Tommy Greene, who was nervous and terrible and not around for long in Game 2 of the National League Championship Series, outdid Greg Maddux tonight to give his belligerent brethren with the bats all the room and comfort they required to take apart the Braves in Game 6 and earn a trip to the World Series.

title: Stocks End Day Higher; Dow Up 10.06
description: Cable and entertainment issues led the stock market higher yesterday in reaction to the proposed acquisition of Tele-Communications Inc. by Bell Atlantic, which would be the nation's largest corporate merger ever.

title: PIONEER'S STOCK RISES AFTER NEWS OF INDEX LISTING
description: Shares of Pioneer Hi-Bred International Inc. jumped 12 percent yesterday after it was announced that the company would be included in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. The stock closed up $4, at $37.25, in Nasdaq trading, after jumping as high as $38.75, a new 52-week high. Analysts attributed the stock's move to the S.& P. index listing and to lower crop estimates released by the United States Department of Agriculture. "Everything looks bullish for acreage, and especially seed corn next year," said Bonnie Wittenburg, an analyst at Dain Bosworth.

title: Clayton Homes Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a gain of $ 3,000,000, or 7 cents a share, from adoption of FAS 109.

title: A MERGER OF GIANTS: The 'Other' Deal; An Uncertain Impact on QVC's Plans
description: In the unpredictable drama over the looming takeover of Paramount Communications Inc., the plan by the Bell Atlantic Corporation to acquire Tele-Communications Inc. has abruptly altered the scenario and startled some of the leading players.

title: Mellon Bank Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included restructuring charges of $ 175 million.c-Included $ 18 million restructuring charge in the quarter and 9 months.The latest periods' results included those of the Boston Co., acquired on May 21, 1993.

title: Gannett Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
description: b-After a net charge of $ 146,000,000 from the cumulative effect of accounting changes, which included a credit of $ 34 million for income taxes and a charge of $ 180 million for retiree health and life insurance benefits.Year-ago net income and share earnings are restated for accounting changes.

title: Death Toll About 300 in Oct. 3 U.S.-Somali Battle
description: About 300 Somalis are believed to have been killed during the street fighting in Mogadishu on Oct. 3, and hundreds of women and children were among the 700 treated in hospitals after the battle, military and relief officials say.

title: FIRST CHICAGO CORP. (N)
description: The First Chicago Corporation, parent company of the First National Bank of Chicago, said yesterday that gains on investments in other companies and growth in its credit card business produced a record profit of $284 million in the quarter ended Sept. 30.

title: Panel Sends Cuomo a List of 7 For a Seat on State's Top Court
description: A state commission today sent Gov. Mario M. Cuomo a list of seven nominees to fill a vacancy about to occur on the state's highest court, including three women.

title: Dexter Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a charge of $ 9,875,000 from an accounting adjustment.

title: Artisoft (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
LOCKHEED UNIT GETS $1.5 BILLION CONTRACT FROM NASA
description: The Lockheed Corporation said yesterday that one of its units had been awarded a $1.5 billion contract over 10 years by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration to provide engineering and technical services at the Johnson Space Center in Houston. The contract, with the Lockheed Engineering and Sciences Company, is for an initial five-year period with one-year and five-year renewal options. Lockheed said that McDonnell Douglas Aerospace, a unit of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, would be the largest of several subcontractors.

title: Newhouse Link To Valuevision
description: Valuevision International Inc. said today that it had signed a binding letter of intent to affiliate with the Newhouse Broadcasting Corporation for six years.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: THE end of the day at a preschool or child-care center is often filled with tension, tantrums and tears. It is a difficult transition for both children and parents, as they try to adjust to one another's pace and expectations.

title: Sizing Up the Emerging Colossus
description: As Bell Atlantic and Tele-Communications Inc. officially announced their intent to merge, a significance well beyond the billions of dollars involved began to unfold.

title: MEDCO TO ACQUIRE REMAINDER OF MEDICAL MARKETING
description: Shares of Medical Marketing Group Inc. plunged 20.7 percent after the company said its largest shareholder, Medco Containment Services Inc., would buy the remainder of Medical Marketing at a 26 percent discount. Medco, itself part of a proposed $6 billion merger with Merck & Company, will pay $25 a share for 5.75 million Medical Marketing shares, or about 45.8 percent of the shares outstanding.

title: Microchip Technology Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding reflected 2-for-1 stock split effective Sept. 14, 1993.

title: Rio Hotel & Casino (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a charge of $ 254,000 related to early retirement of unamortized bank-loan costs in the quarter and 9 months. The 9 months was also after a charge of $ 777,000 from an adjustment in accounting.c-Included an extraordinary gain of $ 793,000, or 5 cents a share, on reduction of income taxes from carryforward of prior year's losses.

title: New Ranchers Tend New Stock: Elk
description: On Jack Bridgewater's sprawling ranch by the snow-capped Big Belt Mountains, aspen meadows echo this time of year with a sound and sight uncommon to livestock operations: the eerie moans of rutting elk.

title: Hal Riney Executive Returns to Burnett
description: Tony Houghton, who left the Leo Burnett Company 10 months ago to become president at Hal Riney & Partners in San Francisco, unexpectedly said yesterday that he would rejoin Burnett in Chicago, effective Nov. 8. Replacing him at Riney, as managing director, will be David Verklin, one of the industry's best-known agency media executives.

title: Willamette Industries (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a charge of 13 cents a share related to the increased federal income tax rate retroactive to Jan. 1. The overall amount of the charge was not disclosed.c-Included a charge of 11 cents a share related to the increased federal income tax rate. The overall amount was not disclosed. The period also included a gain of $ 26,364,000, or 48 cents a share, related to an accounting change.

title: Conners to Return to Yanks
description: The looting of the Yankee coaching staff is expected to begin today or tomorrow when the club announces that Billy Conners, the Chicago Cubs' pitching coach who held the same job with the Yankees, has been hired to replace Tony Cloninger, who was the pitching coach last season.

title: Corrections
description: The periodic table within a diagram in Science Times on Tuesday about heavy elements misidentified Element 81. It is thallium. The table also omitted a theoretical element, No. 115; it should have appeared in sequence after 114.

title: Braves' Baffling Role: A Team Without Title
description: It is a club, with its pitching and defense and bold acquisitions, of perfect theoretical architecture. It had produced the game's best record, and it had developed a kind of corporate cool, its players practiced in miracles and spectacularly deep in talent.

title: Tarnished Brass
description: It isn't hard to imagine the confusion of citizens who watched the Mollen Commission's hearings on the New York City Police Department. Is the corruption widespread and systemic or episodic and isolated? Ax grinders speak menacingly of a force in disarray; apologists trot out the "one rotten apple in any barrel" theory. Where to go for the truth?

title: SARA LEE TO ACQUIRE VIKING COFFEE OF FINLAND
description: The Sara Lee Corporation agreed yesterday to buy Viking Coffee, a Finnish coffee roasting company, for an undisclosed price. Sara Lee, based in Chicago, also agreed to buy two of Viking's units, Rich Coffee Oy in Finland and Luxus Kaffee A.B. in Sweden. The acquisition is expected to be completed by the end of the year. Sara Lee is already one of the largest coffee roasters in Europe.

title: Review/Fashion; Good Humor Plays Peekaboo
description: Over the years, after an Yves Saint Laurent fashion show, word would go out and soon women of the world would be appearing in pants suits or looking like Russian peasants. This time, his message is more diffuse. "Be happy," the designer said after his show on Wednesday. "Be happy with your clothes."

title: Untangling a Complex Deal
description: John C. Malone, never known for easy-to-understand deals, has started his most complex yet: selling his company, Tele-Communications Inc., to Bell Atlantic Corporation for $3.9 billion. Analysts are having trouble figuring it out. Big investors are unclear on details. Even the principals are having trouble keeping it all straight.

title: Japan Is Urged to Insure Foreigners' Trade Share
description: As a keystone of its new approach to trade with Japan, the United States will demand that foreign companies gain the same share of the market for various goods and services in Japan as in other industrial nations, an American trade official said today.

title: Don't Blame TV for Getting Us Into Somalia; Charity Begins at Home
description: To the Editor:

title: Investigators Question Commerce Secretary
description: Investigators met on Monday with Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown to ask him questions about allegations by a Vietnamese businessman who said Mr. Brown had been offered $700,000 to work toward removing the nation's trade embargo with Vietnam.

title: Fields Set for 6 Races At Belmont's Jamboree
description: More than 50 of the best race horses from England, Ireland, France, Canada and the United States were entered yesterday in this Saturday's great Belmont Park jamboree, six stakes races worth $2.4 million in prize money plus star billing for the Breeders' Cup three weeks later.

title: A Lifetime of Folk Art, Going . . . Going . . .
description: BURTON AND HELAINE FENDELMAN are about to do a startling thing. That's on top of the startling things they've been doing for the last 28 years.

title: Lukens Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 25
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 2,177,000, or 15 cents a share, and $ 3,690,000, or 24 cents a share, in the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and the 9 months also included a net charge of $ 65,901,000, which included charge of $ 67,222,000 for SFAS 106, and gain of $ 1,321,000 for SFAS 109.c-Net incomed-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 2,664,000, or 19 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 7,305,000, or 55 cents a share, in the 9 months.Discontinued operations reflected the company's industrial operations, which were restated as discontinued in the second quarter.

title: A MERGER OF GIANTS: The Policy Issues; A Marriage of Media
description: Can the merger of two huge companies -- each with monopolistic powers -- possibly usher in more competition?

title: Turkish Leader to Press U.S. on Iraq Embargo
description: Turkey's Prime Minister, Tansu Ciller, left here tonight for Washington, where she is expected to ask President Clinton a question that has come to preoccupy many political and economic leaders here and elsewhere: how long can the Western embargo of Iraq continue without visible political result?

title: Assist From Brown
description: JIM BROWN was on hand yesterday at Mother A.M.E. Zion Church in Harlem, beaming like a proud father at the sight of the 67 newest graduates of his Amer-I-Can Program.

title: A MERGER OF GIANTS: The Cost of Advice; At $35 Million, the Bankers And Lawyers Seem Cheap
description: At $33 billion, give or take a billion or two, the Bell Atlantic Corporation's purchase of Tele-Communications Inc. stacks up as the biggest takeover in corporate history, rivaled only by the $30.6 billion that Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company shelled out for RJR Nabisco four years ago.

title: Review/Music; Serkin's Particular 'Goldberg' Variations
description: "Long have I been away from you" are the playful words to an 18th-century popular tune Bach quotes near the end of the "Goldberg" Variations. It is as if the tune's unsung lyrics were referring to the theme itself, about to return after a long sojourn through canons, gigues, fugues, arias and dances: 30 of the most exquisite variations written for the keyboard. The explanation for the absence of the theme is in the words to another melody Bach quotes in the final variation: "Cabbage and turnips have put me to flight."

title: Smith (A.O.) Corp. (A) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a one-time charge of $ 1.2 million due to the increased federal tax rate in the quarter anmd 9 months.c-Net loss, which included a gain of $ 1.6 million, or 9 cents a share, from tax credits realizable under FAS 109 resulting from reclassification of agricultural businesses, and after a charge of $ 46,122,000 from an adjustment in accounting.

title: Bridge
description: Enthusiastic analysts often consider this post-mortem question: Could it have been made double-dummy? The reader can explore this question on the diagramed deal, given a contract of six hearts and the lead of the spade jack.

title: Mosinee Paper Corp. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included additional provision for income taxes of $ 950,000 resulting from an increase in the corporate tax rate that became law during the quarter. The 9 months also included pretax gain of $ 5,529,000 received in settlement of court ruling against the James River Corp. for patent infringement upon certain washroom towel cabinet roll transfer mechanisms, which increased net income by 41 cents a share.c-Net loss, and the 9 months was after an charge of $ 8,537,000 from the adoption of FASB 106.

title: World Acceptance (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Progress on the Waterfront
description: New York City's Planning Department gave itself an intimidating assignment when it developed a zoning plan for the waterfront. With few exceptions, the city's 578 miles of shoreline have either been neglected to the point of deterioration or overdeveloped in ways that wall off the waterfront. The trick was to improve the shoreline and the public's access to it without discouraging sensible development.

title: Showing Off Big Plans for Recycled Paper
description: PEOPLE who live in glass houses should throw no stones, according to an oft-repeated saying. But what about those in paper ones?

title: Economic Scene; The health care plan could worsen injury-claim abuses.
description: BILL CLINTON'S health care plan makes a cautious stab at curbing malpractice suits, reducing the incentives to go to court and forcing those injured to try mediation first. So there is at least a hope that the total cost of the accident liability system, which runs $130 billion a year in insurance premiums, will fall. Right?

title: Ginsburg at Fore in Court's Give-and-Take
description: The Supreme Court wrestled with two of the term's most important discrimination cases today, and for many minutes during the two intense hours of argument it was Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg's courtroom.

title: Rivers Gets Ready For Rigors Of Season
description: According to Pat Riley, Doc Rivers was in the best shape of any Knick reporting to training camp. Impressive, considering Rivers turned 32 years old today.

title: TSI Corp. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
description: b-Included nonrecurring expenses of $ 5,007,000 in the quarter and $ 6,327,000 in the year, from disposal of operations. The year also included a restructuring expense of $ 15,647,000.c-Included nonrecurring expenses of $ 45,000 in the quarter and $ 779,000 in the year, related to acquistion costs, and the year also included nonrecurring expense of $ 672,000 from research and development repurchase option.

title: Critic's Notebook; This Jewish Mom Dominates TV, Too
description: Of the relatively few stereotypes that have slipped past political-correctness watchdogs in recent years, none has more stamina than the exaggerated Jewish mother, a stock character once again very much in vogue in prime-time entertainment. The British music hall once had its bandylegged, boozy Irish Paddy. Today's television seems curiously partial to neurotically overprotective, brash and often garish mothers of the unmistakably Jewish persuasion.

title: Linoleum Turns Into Vegetables
description: WHEN the kitchen floor in Kevin Gavin's Manhattan apartment needed a little sprucing up, he decided against replacing the linoleum. He remembered the trompe l'oeil throw rug he had seen in a friend's kitchen and asked its designer, Laura Brandt, to paint his entire floor.

title: Dolphins Sign Hodson
description: The Miami Dolphins signed the former New England Patriot TOMMY HODSON as a backup quarterback yesterday and placed DAN MARINO on injured reserve, making him ineligible for the rest of the season.

title: Sonoco Products (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 3
description: b-After an accounting charge of $ 37,892,000 from the adoption of FAS 106 and FAS 109.The adoption of FAS 106 also resulted in an incremental retiree benefit expense of about $ 3 million, which was charged evenly over all four quarters of 1992.Per-share figures have been adjusted to reflect the 2-for-1 stock split announced in April.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-15 U.N. REIMPOSES HAITIAN EMBARGO The U.N. reimposed an oil and arms embargo on Haiti, accusing military authorities there of violating the agreement to return Haiti's exiled President to power. A1 COMMITMENT TO HAITI'S FUTURE A day after an American troop ship was forced to retreat from landing in Haiti, the White House and President Aristide sought to show their commitment to democracy. A8

title: ROMANIA GRANTED FULL TRADE STATUS
description: The House of Representatives has given its seal of approval to Romania by voting to restore normal trade relations.

title: Public & Private; Stinky Cheese Race
description: To: Mr. Dinkins and Mr. Giuliani From: A Mom Re: Bad Behavior

title: Raiders Deal Patterson
description: The Raiders' special-teams captain, ELVIS PATTERSON, has been traded to the Dallas Cowboys for a draft choice, the Raider coach, ART SHELL, said yesterday.

title: Billing Review at McDonnell
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said today that it would review its accounting practices after a Congressional investigation into overcharges on Government contracts.

title: But the Blue Jays Have Some Storybook Characters, Too
description: Now that the Toronto Blue Jays have proved they can repeat as American League pennant winners despite a wholesale change in their appearance, they go to the World Series to see if they can repeat there, too, with their adaptable dozen.

title: Market Place; A New Age's Suppliers Sell Well
description: Some of the biggest winners from the Bell Atlantic Corporation's proposed acquisition of Tele-Communications Inc. could be the stockholders of companies that make construction and maintenance equipment for the data superhighway. Such stocks, which have been hot lately, jumped yesterday on news of the biggest communications merger in history.

title: Products Meant to Be Kind
description: THE best products are those that can be used by the most people, from an active teen-ager to a person with limited hand dexterity. That's what James J. Pirkl, professor emeritus of industrial design at Syracuse University, says he believes. Mr. Pirkl and other judges selected four trans-generational designs from a field of 200 in a competition sponsored by the Arthritis Foundation and financed by the McNeil Consumer Products Company, which makes Tylenol.

title: Pioneer-Standard Electronics Inc. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Combined sales of Pioneer-Standard Electronics and its 50 percent owned affiliate, Pioneer/Technologies Group Inc. for the latest periods were $ 267.9 million for the quarter and $ 497.8 million for the 6 months, compared with $ 171.2 million and $ 340.4 million for year-ago periods, respectively.Prior year earnings per share have been restated to reflect a 3-for-2 share split effective March 15, 1993.

title: Universal Health Realty Income Trust reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a gain of $ 371,000 from the disposal of assets.c-Net lossd-Included a $ 6 million charge as a provision for investment losses in the quarter and 9 months.

title: Corrections
description: A headline on Monday about the wedding of Kathryn Emily Beebe misstated the name of the bridegroom. He is James William Reilly. The report also misspelled the last name of the bride's mother. She is Robin Van Doren.

title: Calendar: Harvest Fair and Antiques
description: Garden Festivals and More New York Botanical Garden, 200th Street and Southern Boulevard, the Bronx; (718) 817-8700.

title: Reviews/Dance; A Dutch Tribute to Ives's Life And Music
description: Beppie Blankert, a Dutch choreographer, is obviously smitten by the music of Charles Ives, the experimental American composer who lived from 1874 to 1954. On Thursday night at St. Mark's Church, she sent him a beautiful theatrical love letter.

title: James A. Buchanan, A Rotarian Official And Benefactor, 74
description: James A. Buchanan 4th, a major benefactor of Rotary International, died on Sunday at the Baptist Medical Center in Jacksonville, Fla. He was 74 and lived on a farm in Dickerson, Md.

title: Total Petroleum (North America) Ltd. (A) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a charge of $ 2.7 million from an increase in the U.S. corporate income tax rate in the quarter and 9 months.c-Net loss

title: Fernandez May Be The Mets' 104th Loss
description: The difference in dollars is enormous. The disagreement in principle is deep. The conclusion is all but inescapable: Sid Fernandez will not pitch for the Mets in 1994.

title: Richard A. Wolters Dog Training Expert, 73
description: Richard A. Wolters, an expert on training hunting dogs, died on Saturday after he landed an ultralight aircraft that he had been piloting near his farm in Hanover, Va. He was 73.

title: After The Roast, Fire And Smoke
description: ON computer networks, across telephone lines, in newspapers, under dryers at hair salons and on radio and television talk shows, "Whoopi and Ted" have been the talk of the nation for almost a week.

title: Israelis and the P.L.O. Meet: Peace Is in the Details
description: The agreement between Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization officially went into effect today, and with it the two sides began crucial negotiations on transferring authority in the occupied territories from Israel to Palestinians.

title: Victims of Truck Hijacking Dial a Rescue
description: Handcuffed and locked in the back of a hijacked delivery truck yesterday, en route to who knows where, two delivery men did what any sensible kidnapping victims would do: They called 911 on a cellular phone.

title: Fund Group Agrees to Pay Restitution
description: The First Investors Corporation, a mutual fund company known for high-pressure sales tactics, yesterday settled litigation stemming from its aggressive sales of two junk bond funds in the 1980's. It agreed to pay an additional $7.5 million into restitution funds for customers, bringing the total amount it will pay to $33.4 million.

title: AVONDALE STOCK HITS 52-WEEK HIGH AFTER NAVY ORDER
description: The stock of Avondale Industries hit a 52-week high yesterday after the company said it had received a $257.5 million order from the United States Navy for a dock landing ship. Shares of Avondale closed at $7.125, up 50 cents, in Nasdaq trading after touching a new high of $7.75. Avondale said it would build the ship, used in amphibious landings, by March 1998. Last month, the Navy also ordered one sealift ship with an option to buy five more in a contract worth as much as $1.3 billion for Avondale. The day after that order, shares of Avondale surged 58 percent.

title: Mozart Makes the Brain Hum, a Study Finds
description: Can it be that the music of Mozart is not only exalting but can also improve intelligence?

title: Inspectors Are Accused Of Extortion
description: The commanding officer of the unit that enforces sanitation laws in midtown and lower Manhattan and 10 current and former inspectors were accused yesterday of extorting between $5,000 and $10,000 a year each from shopkeepers, restaurant owners and street food vendors.

title: 'Jack's Lad's' Leave Irish In a Precarious Position
description: Jack Charlton, the coach of the Republic of Ireland's national soccer team, is probably the best-loved Englishman ever to work in this robustly un-English country. In seven years, what the headlines call "Jack's Magic" has turned "Jack's Lads" into a major soccer power. But the lads, all of whom play for British club teams, didn't have it today, and 33,000 of the fans in "Jack's Army," trudged home in despair after Spain thrashed Ireland, 3-1.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: AMERIHOST PROPERTIES INC., Des Plaines, Ill., said it would build, own and operate a 59-room Holiday Inn Express hotel in Tuscola, Ill. ASSET INVESTORS CORP., Denver, said it had completed the spinoff of a 70 percent stake in its newly formed Commercial Assets Inc. unit.

title: Bowe's Extra Weight Doesn't Worry Him
description: Riddick Bowe ballooned to more than 270 pounds as late as last month, but the heavyweight champion has recently been punishing sparring partners, breaking one's nose, knocking out another's teeth and sending a third packing.

title: Penn Proposes Elimination of 3 Departments
description: Citing the kinds of tight finances that are squeezing campuses nationwide, the University of Pennsylvania has moved to eliminate three departments -- religious studies, civilization and regional science -- and absorb their faculty in other departments.

title: Books of The Times; Deceptions of Sex and Politics in 1930's Europe
description: While England Sleeps By David Leavitt 304 pages. Viking. $22.

title: Unitrin Inc. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After accounting charges of $ 21.2 million in the quarter and $ 21.9 million in the 9 months from the company's 27.9 percent share of Litton Industries, which took a charge of about $ 117 million for adopting SFAS 106.c-After an accounting charge of $ 39.9 million for Unitrin adopting SFAS 106.

title: Hans W. Heinsheimer Dies at 93; Top Publisher of Classical Music
description: Hans W. Heinsheimer, one of the most influential classical-music publishers of the 20th century, died on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 93.

title: Irish President Backs New Call for Peace in Ulster
description: President Mary Robinson indicated today that she approved of the new initiative toward a settlement of the strife in Northern Ireland.

title: Valmont Industries (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 25
description: b-Included a loss of $ 333,000 on disposal of discontinued operations in the quarter, and the 9 months included a gain of $ 4,637,000, or 39 cents a share, which included a gain of $ 3,950,000 on disposal of discontinued operations. The 9 months was also after a charge of $ 4,910,000 from the cumulative effect of accounting change.c-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 925,000, or 8 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 2,309,000, or 20 cents a share, in the 9 months.

title: At the Wire, U.A.W. Balks On Ford Pact
description: Two hours before they were to formally sign a three-year contract negotiated last month with the Ford Motor Company, top officials of the United Automobile Workers union notified Ford that they were unhappy with the company's view of one provision and would not sign.

title: Maybelline Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a pretax charge of $ 5.7 million.c-Net loss, which included nonrecurring pretax charges of $ 17.7 million and a $ 12.3 million extraordinary loss due to the prepayment of certain debt.

title: Bloody Prints in Oslo
description: It could be a coincidence that a Norwegian publisher and friend of Salman Rushdie was shot from behind three times outside his home near Oslo, and that the tires of his car were also slashed by a would-be robber. But the attempted murder of the publisher, William Nygaard, has the same marks of a contract hit as did the fatal stabbing in 1991 of Mr. Rushdie's Japanese translator and the knife attack on the Italian translator of his novel "The Satanic Verses."

title: Woolworth To Shutter 970 Stores
description: The Woolworth Corporation said yesterday that it planned to eliminate 13,000 jobs and close 970 stores, including half of its remaining five-and-dime variety stores, in what would be the largest, most costly reorganization in the retailer's 114-year-history.

title: First Interstate Ascends As a Banking Phoenix
description: In the summer of 1990, Edward M. Carson, the newly appointed chairman of the First Interstate Bancorporation, promised angry shareholders that he would cut the bank's bad loans to 1 percent of assets by the end of 1993, from a level of 5 percent.

title: Poles Designed to Make Walking More Vigorous
description: CROSS-COUNTRY skiers know that poles give power and balance to their stride. Now, there are poles for walkers, an idea based on the concept that two sticks are better than one.

title: Ryan's Family Steak House Inc. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
description: b-After a gain of $ 1 million, or 2 cents a share, for change in accounting for income taxes.

title: Giants' Thornton Has Mild Stroke
description: Giants defensive lineman George Thornton apparently suffered a minor stroke early this morning as a result of severe hypertension, or extremely high blood pressure, according to the team physician, Russell Warren. Thornton is in stable condition at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center and the prognosis for him returning to football this season is good, team officials say.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Religion Notes column on Sept. 25, about a Yom Kippur charity appeal, misstated the amount of a grant given to the Jewish community of Sarajevo by Mazon, a Jewish group working to relieve hunger. It was $50,000, not $500,000.

title: Accounts
description: * Boots Co., London, to BMP DDB Needham, London, to handle the media planning and buying on its estimated $68 million British account, previously handled by various local agencies. * Black & Decker Corp., Towson, Md., to Eisner & Associates, Baltimore, to handle its professional power tools division, previously at Leo Burnett U.S.A., Chicago. Billings were estimated at $7 million.

title: 3D JUROR AT ISSUE IN BEATING TRIAL
description: Legal combat over the composition of the jury continued today in the trial of two black men accused of beating a white truck driver during last year's riot, with a defense lawyer asking for the removal of a third juror during deliberations.

title: Felix Grant Is Dead; Host of Jazz Show In Capital Was 74
description: Felix Grant, a jazz disk jockey in Washington for more than 40 years, died on Thursday at his home in Washington. He was 74.

title: Chancellor Restores 10 Principals Removed by Predecessor in Bronx
description: In an attempt to make peace with a rebellious, corruption-plagued Bronx school district, Schools Chancellor Ramon C. Cortines yesterday reinstated 10 school administrators who had been removed from office in May by his predecessor, Joseph A. Fernandez.

title: Gymnastics Site Flip-Flopped
description: The gymnastics competition of the 1996 Olympic Games will probably be moved to an arena with 13,000 fewer seats to accommodate television, Atlanta Olympic officials said today.

title: ACL Communications Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss related to early retirement of debt of $ 7,490,000 and a gain from cumulative effect of change in method of accounting for income taxes of $ 13,500,000, or 38 cents a share.c-Included an extraordinary tax credit of $ 1,692,000, or 5 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 4,740,000, or 23 cents a share, in the 9 months.Results for the latest quarter included the July acquisition of Call Home America, which added about 50,000 customers and an estimated $ 20 million of annualized revenue, according to the company.

title: Events: Open Houses And Walking Tours
description: Seven Beauties United Cerebral Palsy of New York City; (212) 683-6700, ext. 217.

title: Orange Juice Prices Tumble After Florida Crop Forecast
description: Orange juice prices plunged 10 percent yesterday, the largest single drop in three years, after the Agriculture Department's 1993-94 Florida crop report projected larger-than-expected supplies.

title: Clinton Resists Earlier Somalia Pullout
description: President Clinton and Senate leaders struggled today to beat back a proposal that would require United States troops to pull out of Somalia earlier than the timetable the President has set.

title: Glatfelter (P.H.) Co. (A) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included $ 3,472,000 charge resulting from increase in federal income tax rate.c-After a net charge of $ 4,193,000 from accounting changes which included: gain of $ 10,624,000 for income tax accounting; charge of $ 12,850,000 for SFAS 105; and charge of $ 1,967,000 for change in postemployment benefit accounting.d-Included restructuring charges totaling $ 16,363,000, and gains of $ 1,492,000 on disposal of Ecusta division's airplane and $ 1,642,000 from revised estimates on accounting adjustment. The period also included a $ 3,472,000 charge in latest third quarter from increase in federal income tax rate.

title: Henry H. Perlman, 97, Expert in Dermatology
description: Dr. Henry H. Perlman, a pioneer in pediatric dermatology, died on Sunday at Thomas Jefferson University Hospital in Philadelphia. He was 97 and lived in Philadelphia, where he practiced medicine for more than 70 years.

title: Profits at Weyerhaeuser Plummet 38% in Quarter
description: The Weyerhaeuser Company today reported a 38 percent decline in third-quarter earnings on a 5 percent decline in revenues, indicating that the market for paper and pulp products remained depressed.

title: Molex Inc. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a charge of $ 3,605,000 from an change in accounting for postretirement benefits other than pensions.Share earnings were restated to reflect 25 percent stock dividend declared November 1992.

title: Milk Paint Can Help Windsor Chairs
description: The Windsor chair, which originated in England early in the 18th century, was inspired by a cottage-type chair first made in a woodland area near a town of the same name. It soon found its way to America, where chair makers produced their own variations.

title: Executive Changes
description: AMERICAN EXPRESS TRAVEL RELATED SERVICES INC., New York, appointed John Yates senior vice president of vendor management services.

title: Health Reform Must Include Abortion; Catholics in Exile
description: To the Editor:

title: Lehman Bros. to Move 900 Back-Office Jobs to Jersey City
description: After months of speculation, Lehman Brothers Inc. has decided to move more than 900 back-office employees to Jersey City, to the same 42-floor tower to which Merrill Lynch moved 2,500 back-office jobs a year ago.

title: Dr. Lorie Tarshis, 82, Professor of Economics
description: Dr. Lorie Tarshis, an economist who served as a department head at Stanford University and division chairman at the University of Toronto, died on Oct. 4 in a Toronto nursing home. He was 82.

title: Lufkin Industries Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 563,000, or 8 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 671,000, or 10 cents a share, in the 9 months.c-Net lossIncome from discontinued operations reflected contribution from discontinued trailer operation, the assets of which Lufkin continues to operate while it seeks a buyer.

title: Precision Castparts Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
description: b-Included a tax benefit of $ 2.4 million, or 18 cents a share, due to an agreement with the Internal Revenue Service for research and development tax credits, and after a charge of $ 2.9 million from an adjustment in accounting.

title: Televised Debate
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins will debate George J. Marlin, the Conservative Party candidate for Mayor, at St. Francis College in Brooklyn tonight. The debate begins at 7:30 P.M. and will be televised live on New York 1. It will also televise a debate at 9 P.M. between three candidates for comptroller: Alan G. Hevesi, the Democratic candidate, Howard Lim, the Conservative candidate, and Barbara Bollaert, the Right-to-Life candidate.

title: Woody Allen Asks Connecticut to Discipline Prosecutor
description: Woody Allen asked yesterday for disciplinary action against a Connecticut prosecutor who had said there was "probable cause" to believe that Mr. Allen molested his 7-year-old daughter, but then did not file charges.

title: Tellabs Inc. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
description: b-After a gain of $ 1.5 million, or 10 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

title: GFC Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a charge of $ 4,857,000 for deferred taxes in both the quarter and 9 months, and the 9 months also included income from discontinued operations of $ 4,208,000, or 21 cents a share.c-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 3,311,000, or 16 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 8,100,000, or 40 cents a share, in the 9 months.

title: Agassi Out Until '94
description: ANDRE AGASSI has pulled out of next month's Paris Open because of a wrist injury and won't play for the rest of the season, organizers of the tournament said yesterday in Paris.

title: Clinton and Aristide Move To Affirm Policy on Haiti
description: A day after an American troopship was forced to retreat in the face of a small mob on a Port-au-Prince dock, the Clinton Administration and the exiled Haitian President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide, sought to demonstrate the United States commitment to the return of democratic rule in the Caribbean country.

title: Clinton Offers Job Training For Trade Pact Casualties
description: The Clinton Administration proposed a $100 million program today to help retrain Americans who lose their jobs because of the North American Free Trade Agreement. But critics of the pact were unimpressed by the proposal.

title: Earnings Nearly Tripled In Third Quarter at CBS
description: The confluence of improved sales and several one-time factors provided record third-quarter earnings for CBS Inc., the company announced yesterday. Net income for the period that ended on Sept. 30 rose to $118.3 million, nearly tripling that earned during the 1992 period.

title: Rabin Says Sales to China Didn't Break U.S. Law
description: Israel's Prime Minister, Yitzak Rabin, acknowledged on a state visit today that his country had sold arms to Beijing, but he disputed a United States intelligence estimate of the size of the sales and insisted that they do not violate any restrictions on transferring American weapons technology.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Maple Leafs Move to 4-0 Mark Rob Pearson and Wendel Clark each scored twice as the undefeated Maple Leafs crushed the winless Washington Capitals last night in Toronto. Peter Zezel, Dave Andreychuk and Nikolai Borschevsky scored Toronto's other goals. Toronto (4-0) is off to its best start since 1944-45, when that season's lineup started 6-0 and went on to win the Stanley Cup. Ted Kennedy was a member of that team and was on hand for a pre-game ceremony during which banners were raised bearing the jersey numbers of Kennedy and Syl Apps. Keith Jones scored for the Capitals, who at 0-5 are off to their worst start in 10 years. (AP) Whalers 4, Canadiens 3: Geoff Sanderson had his second straight two-goal game and Pat Verbeek and Robert Kron also scored as the Whalers rallied for three goals in the third period and edged the Montreal Canadiens in Hartford. Sanderson, who has five goals in four games, snapped a 2-2 tie with a short-handed goal at 6 minutes 50 seconds of the third period. Just 2:30 earlier, Verbeek had drawn Hartford even with a quick wrister from the low slot. Kron capped the third-period uprising with his first of the season at 8:21, a tap-in from the right post off a feed from Randy Cunneyworth. Rookie Chris Pronger had two assists for Hartford. (AP)

title: Oilers Bench Moon, Will Go With Carlson
description: The Houston Oilers, who have lost four of their first five games, switched quarterbacks yesterday, with CODY CARLSON getting the starting job over the Pro Bowler WARREN MOON.

title: U.N. Says Bosnia Factions Block Winter Supplies
description: As Bosnia heads into the second winter of its civil war with more than half of its population dependent on food relief supplies, United Nations officials have accused the warring factions of deliberately frustrating efforts to help the most vulnerable groups survive the winter.

title: A MERGER OF GIANTS: The Companies;
description: Offering a majestic vision of how communications would transform the American home, chief executives of Bell Atlantic and Tele-Communications Inc. disclosed details of their $33 billion merger yesterday.

title: Opening New Freeway, Los Angeles Ends Era
description: More than half a century after Los Angeles ushered in the modern automobile era of urban commuting with the first California freeway, officials on Thursday will open what is almost certainly the area's last freeway.

title: Reviews/Dance; Song in Easy Concert With Choreography
description: Concert Royal, a musical group directed by James Richman, and the New York Baroque Dance Company, directed by Catherine Turocy, have often collaborated to revive Baroque spectacles. They did so again on Saturday night at Gould Hall in "An Evening of Opera-Ballet," a charming tribute to a French Baroque theatrical form that blended singing with dancing.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK CITY GRUMBLES IN A QUIET NEIGHBORHOOD As residents of the quiet, shaded Soundview section of the Bronx prepare to vote for mayor, they grumble that the out-of-the way feeling that attracted them to the neighborhood in the first place may be its curse as New York City officials show little interest in their concerns, which range from uneven sidewalks and overgrown trees to the incursion of drugs and crime. A1. SCHOOL OFFICIALS REINSTATED In an effort to make peace with a troubled Bronx school district, Schools Chancellor Ramon C. Cortines reinstated 10 school administrators whom the previous chancellor removed from office in May amid charges that their hiring had been tainted by bribery and political dealing. A1.

title: CHRONICLE
description: It's Mama Marla and Baby Tiffany: MARLA MAPLES gave birth to a 7 1/2-pound girl yesterday at St. Mary's Hospital in Palm Beach, Fla. And DONALD TRUMP, the child's father, couldn't wait to talk about it.

title: Homes in Queens Hit in Series of Robberies
description: An armed gang of robbers has been at work in affluent neighborhoods in eastern Queens for about a month, often breaking into homes during the early hours of the morning, a police official said yesterday. So far, no one has been injured.

title: Furniture That Gleams With Simplicity
description: THE designer Chris Lehrecke was nurtured on Modernism, quite literally: his mother breast-fed him while sitting in a 1948 rocking chair by the designers Charles and Ray Eames. His father, a German-born architect, installed the family in an avant-garde glass house in Tappan, New York, which initially depressed the youngster. "I wanted to live in a development like everyone else," he said.

title: Whitman Goes on Attack, Accusing Florio on Funds
description: After a bruising week on defense, Christine Todd Whitman's gubernatorial campaign went on the attack today, charging Gov. Jim Florio with violating state election laws by spending money designated for the general election before the primary was held in June.

title: Southwestern Public Service Co.  reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: Per-share net income in both periods reflected payment of preferred dividends.

title: Office Depot Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 25
description: Figures have been reststaed to reflect a 3-for-2 common stock split in June 1993.

title: Scientologists Granted Tax Exemption by the U.S.
description: The Government said today that it had agreed to grant a tax exemption to the Church of Scientology and more than 150 of its related corporations, ending one of the longest-running tax disputes in American history.

title: Phillies' Wild Things Are in the World Series
description: Five years after hitting such a nadir that not even the hungriest of free agents wanted to put on the uniform, one year after finishing a humbling last in the National League East, 25 Phillies finally got to say last night that all things considered, they'd rather be in Philadelphia.

title: Wolohan Lumber (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a gain of $ 516,000, or 7 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

title: Exabyte Corp.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
description: b-Net lossc-Included a one-time charge of $ 13,469,000 related to the acquisition of R-Byte Inc. for both the quarter and 9 months.

title:
SOCCER;
Sun Is Setting on England in 1994 World Cup
description: England's soccer team was defeated tonight by the Netherlands, 2-0, almost certainly ending its World Cup hopes, and 5,000 English visitors slumped in their corner among the 43,000 serenading Dutch fans in Feyenoord Stadium.

title: Tiny Gardens Lush With Memories
description: THROUGH her miniature gardens, Dieta von Matthiessen keeps her childhood memories alive: the faraway lands of bedtime stories, the family vacation to the Yucatan and the exploration of brooks, woods and a forbidden swamp at a 250-acre farm in Brewster, N.Y., that she and her two siblings called home.

title: Delays in Grand Central Fire Laid to Crippling of 3 Systems
description: The Metro-North Commuter Railroad was crippled Tuesday night and early yesterday morning because a fire in a shed at Grand Central Terminal knocked out or heavily damaged three systems that are supposed to back up each other: radio, telephone and signal-control equipment.

title: Western Digital Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 25
description: b-Net income

title: Richter Gets Benched; Rangers Get the Point
description: Mike Richter was flat on his back, the puck behind him in the net, and Mike Keenan was pacing behind the bench. Everybody knew this would happen sometime. Keenan has only so much patience with his goaltenders. Last night, he ran out.

title: Matrix Service Co. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
Seagate Technology Inc.  (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
Coltec Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 3
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $ 378,000 and $ 1,017,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, both from debt refinancing and early extinguishment of debt.c-Net loss, which was after an extraordinary charge of $ 105,347,000 incurred in connection with the April 1992 recapitalization and included premiums, expenses and write-offs of deferred financing costs from early extinguishment of debt.Latest 9 months' results included restructuring charge of $ 25.2 million, or $ 15.3 million after taxes, to cover consolidation costs and rearrangement of certain manufacturing facilities and related reductions in work force.The company said for the 9 months ended Sept. 30, 1992, it would have reported pro forma earnings, before extraordinary items, of $ 58.2 million, or 84 cents a share. Pro forma gives effect to the April 1992 recapitalization as if it had occurred Jan. 1, 1992.

title: Protest at Nunn Speech
description: A speech by Senator Sam Nunn at the 92d Street Y.M.C.A. was interrupted several times last night by gay-rights advocates protesting his opposition to gays in the military. Senator Nunn, Democrat of Georgia, the chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, addressed about 200 people, speaking on Somalia and other issues. Five minutes into his speech, a group called the Lesbian Offenders started singing the Pledge of Allegiance and then yelled obscenities. Security officers ejected them. Moments later several men stood up, screaming, "You're taking away our civil rights." They, too, were ejected. After three more interruptions, Senator Nunn finished his talk.

title: U.S. Is Reported to Be Seeking An Informal Truce With Somali
description: The White House's special representative in Somalia said today that the United States was seeking an informal truce in its undeclared war with Gen. Mohammed Farah Aidid that would make it possible to begin withdrawing American troops by early next year.

title: Jones Back in New York
description: KIM JONES, a two-time runner-up, will be running in the New York City Marathon once again. The 35-year-old Jones, who turned in the fastest time by an American woman in the race's history (2 hours 27 minutes 54 seconds) in placing second to INGRID KRISTIANSEN in 1989, will do well to do better than second this time. Among her opponents on Nov. 14 will be WANDA PANFIL, the woman who beat her to the line in her second second-place finish, in 1990.

title: Health Reform Must Include Abortion
description: To the Editor:

title: Delchamps Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
description: b-Included a gain of $ 900,000, or 13 cents a share, from adoption of SFAS No. 109.

title: Christian Science Church Settles Claim to Bequest
description: The Christian Science church, which recently lost several hundred million dollars trying to expand its communications empire, has agreed to share a conditional bequest of $100 million with two rivals for the money.

title: Yeltsin, in Tokyo Limelight, Avoids Islands Dispute
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin ended a long-postponed trip to Japan today basking in his treatment by the Japanese as a democratic leader in full control of Russia, but neatly sidestepping any promises to return disputed territory to Japan.

title: College Basketball Tickets on Sale
description: Individual seats for college basketball at Madison Square Garden will go on sale tomorrow for a 31-game schedule that includes five St. John's regular-season Big East games, the preseason National Invitation Tournament and the E.C.A.C. Holiday Festival.

title: Review/Music; Extremism in the Defense of Rock, From Iggy Pop
