title: Topics of The Times; Get a Life, Coach
description: If we hadn't already suspected there was something seriously wrong with football, Bob Young would have convinced us. The Houston Oilers' offensive-line coach needs to make an appointment with his nearest attitude-adjustment clinic. When one of his offensive linemen, David Williams, missed a game because he wanted to be with his wife when his son was born, Mr. Young compared it to avoiding a combat mission in World War II.

title: Review/Theater; The Seminal American Musical Is Rebuilt From the Ground Up
description: Without "Show Boat," there would have been no "Porgy and Bess," no "Oklahoma!," no "West Side Story." Jerome Kern and Oscar Hammerstein's 1927 Broadway musical was the first to tell an adult story adapted from a sprawling novel (by Edna Ferber), the first to traffic in serious themes (miscegenation, marital collapse), the first to aspire to the epic size of classic 19th-century American literature. With its cracker-barrel humor, metaphorical use of the Mississippi River and poignant attempts to bridge the vast American racial divide, "Show Boat" is the Broadway musical's answer to "The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn." Or would be if Twain had had Florenz Ziegfeld's taste for soaring melodies and lavish spectacle.

description: Mylan Laboratories Inc., a generic drug powerhouse with a current market value of almost $2.4 billion, said yesterday that it had received takeover inquiries. "Some major drug companies have approached us," Patricia Sunseri, a Mylan spokeswoman, said. "Any talks we're having are confidential." Mylan, based in Pittsburgh, is the nation's largest independent generic drug company. Mylan's stock closed yesterday at $29.50 a share, down 87.5 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.

description: In a welcome reversal, the White House has announced that future appearances by President Clinton at major political fund-raising dinners will be open to the press -- the same sound policy followed by Presidents Reagan and Bush.

title: Citicorp's Earnings Tripled in Third Quarter
description: Citicorp, the nation's largest banking company, said yesterday that third-quarter net income had more than tripled, to $528 million, helped by reduced credit costs in both commercial and consumer lending and by strong trading revenues.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Friday about Andrew S. Zysman, a doctor in San Francisco who campaigned for accelerated AIDS research, described the use of the antiviral drug acyclovir incompletely. It is prescribed to treat herpes, both in patients with HIV infections and in others.

title: Review/Fashion; A Mostly Minimal Look in London
description: While watching the parade of blank minimalist dresses in London, it's difficult not to fantasize that from behind the catwalk, a spiky-haired punk might emerge and paint graffiti across the wall of white slips.

title: Review/Film; East German Agitprop
description: "Strictly Propaganda" offers a virtual-reality-style voyage into a brave new world, a place where housewives tirelessly salvage bricks from bombed-out rubble and children sing sweetly about wanting to join the army some day. If the effect of such scenes is disorienting, it ought to be, since this documentary consists entirely of excerpts from East German newsreels and educational material. Promoting everything from sex education for teen-agers to steamer cruises on the Volga, each of these snippets has its own blunt agenda. "Show us where children are not so well off," a teacher asks a student, spinning a globe. "Yes! Where capitalism dominates! A good answer."

title: Bridge
description: If your partner opens the bidding and the opponents reach a game, it is reasonable to assume that you can afford to double holding five trumps headed by the ace and a side king. West made this assumption on the diagramed deal and was disappointed by the result.

title: Where to Find It

Good glass is as clear as, well, crystal, but repairing it can be a messy business requiring grinding wheels, pumice and other dust-inducing materials.

title: Economic Scene; A giant in the profession gives a lift to economic history.
description: CRACK just about any college history text, and you'll find it is full of economics: hardly anyone these days would write about, say, the decline of Spain in the 17th century without paying obeisance to economic causes.

title: Reviving the Roar of an Antic Era
description: The frenzy and the innovation of the Roaring Twenties -- and the Marx Brothers -- were explored this weekend at the annual Classics in Context Festival at the Actors Theater of Louisville. During three days of plays, films, lectures and colloquies, more than 100 theater professionals and academics sampled and analyzed the performing arts of the period, a decade bookended by two cataclysmic events: World War I and the Great Depression. One panelist compared American theater in the 20's to the stock market, "a joy ride" destined to crash.

title: Cleaning Soiled Furniture
description: "PATINA," a word bandied about by furniture buffs, describes the surface quality of old furniture. Originally it referred to the green rust that forms on copper, but it was later adapted to depict the coppery look that old dense and dark mahogany takes on. Nowadays, it suggests the matchless texture of a slightly softened luster gradually acquired through years of polishing.

After all, the 31-year-old Italian only recently arrived in town, has made only one full-length film (in Italian) and isn't even confident that the movie critics or the public will enjoy it.

Since 1967, thousands of Palestinians have been chased and jailed in a deadly game of "capture the flag" in which youngsters challenge Israeli rule by hoisting the outlawed P.L.O. banner.

title: A Clean-Air Minuet

The car company is rolling the dice in the courts and lobbying in legislatures for weaker rules, as state officials consider running to the Clinton Administration to lay down the law to enforce the strictest standard available.

title: Public & Private; Williams 1, Oilers 0
description: Last month the television program "Day One" ran a profile of Jimmy Johnson, the coach of the Dallas Cowboys. Jimmy put life and work in perspective for those of us watching at home; he admitted that when he was offered the job with the Cowboys, his commitment to the team was so total that he ditched his wife of 26 years. "Put your wife on waivers?" asked the interviewer, Forrest Sawyer, and Jimmy did not demur.

title: New Proposal From Cuomo For Yankees

The company, with 150 million shares outstanding, said it would repurchase shares from time to time over three years. CPC shares have risen about 17 percent in the last few months as the company has reported strong earnings and become a subject of takeover speculation. The company makes Hellmann's mayonnaise and Skippy peanut butter, among other brands. CPC shares fell 50 cents, to $46.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: How to Save Yankee Stadium
description: "I f you build it, they will come," promised the ghostly voice in the movie "Field of Dreams." But if the ballpark in the Iowa cornfields had been built by the people who gave us the new Comiskey Park in Chicago or Camden Yards in Baltimore, the slogan would have been rephrased: ". . . and build it with public money." Big league owners know that by threatening to move, they can extort any concessions they want from their cities. Unless their antitrust protection is revoked, Yankee Stadium is doomed -- maybe not this decade but somewhere down the line.

title: Lois Kibbee Is Dead; Actress of Television And Stage Was 71

She was 71 and lived in Manhattan.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. The Great One and the Young One Gretzky versus Gretzky was no match. The Kings versus the Lightning was. Wayne Gretzky scored one goal and assisted on two others last night to lead Los Angeles to a 4-3 victory over the Tampa Bay Lightning and his younger brother Brent in St. Petersburg, Fla. It was the first meeting in a pro game between the nine-time National Hockey League most valuable player and the younger Gretzky, a rookie playing in only his second N.H.L. game. Brent Gretzky, 21, attempted only one shot and barely missed scoring when the puck hit the left post of an unprotected net. (AP) TENNIS Becker Is Eliminated by Delaitre in France Second-seeded Boris Becker of Germany was eliminated from the Lyons (France) Open in the first round yesterday. Olivier Delaitre of France beat Becker, 7-6 (9-7), 6-7 (4-7), 6-4. (AP)

description: The Omnicom Group said yesterday that it had bought a stake in Aegis, the London holding company that owns Carat Espace, one of Europe's largest media buying services.

title: At Flashpoint of Rioting, Now Banality Is Jarring
description: Nothing very remarkable happened today at the infamous corner of Florence and Normandie Avenues in South-Central Los Angeles. The regulars came to get their chili dogs at Art's Famous Chili Dogs ("Since 1933"), neighborhood women got their hair done at Goldie's Beauty Salon, and all day long photographers and reporters came.

title: Knicks Romp for 3d in a Row
description: The Knicks (3-0) rolled to their third preseason victory last night, defeating the San Antonio Spurs, 95-75, at Madison Square Garden. Several Knicks turned in strong efforts, including Hubert Davis (18 points) Patrick Ewing (17 points), Charles Smith (17 points) and Greg Anthony (10 points, 6 assists). David Robinson (18 points, 10 rebounds) and Dennis Rodman (14 rebounds) led San Antonio (1-2).

title: Liquori, Former No. 1 Miler, Has 'Mild Form' of Leukemia
description: When Marty Liquori noticed a lump on his groin after a tennis match near his home in Gainesville, Fla., a couple of years ago, he couldn't have been less concerned.

description: Uglynest Caterpillar

description: b-Included a charge of $ 125 million for restructuring accrual and securities gains of $ 127 million in the quarter and 9 months.Per share earnings are fully diluted.

title: American Air's Parent Shows Upturn in Profits
description: Investors, whose hopes for a strong rebound in the airline industry have risen and been dashed at various times in recent months, saw a third-quarter earnings report from the AMR Corporation that suggested simply that a modest recovery was under way.

title: CyCare Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
American Brands reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a charge of $ 201,000,000 from cumulative effect of adopting, effective Jan. 1, FAS 106 and FAS 112.

title: Theodore Robertson, Pathologist, 75, Dies
description: Dr. Theodore Robertson, a pathologist and medical educator at Cornell Medical College for more than 30 years, died on Monday at a nursing home in Stamford, Conn. He was 75 and lived in Locust Valley, L.I., for most of his life.

title: Clinton Altering Nation's Tactics In Drug Battle
description: The Clinton Administration issued a national drug strategy today that echoed the President's campaign promises to increase drug rehabilitation but provided no details about how the plan would be paid for or carried out.

title: Settlements Are Expected In Prudential's Fraud Cases
description: Prudential Securities Inc., which grew in the 1980's from a third-tier firm into one of the largest and best capitalized brokerage firms in the country, is expected to settle Federal and state charges as soon as today that it violated a raft of securities laws in that decade, people involved in the case said yesterday.

title: Progressive Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share figures have been adjusted for a December 1992 3-for-1 stock split.b-Included gains of $ 42.2 million, or 37 cents a diluted share, from sales of securities, in the quarter and 9 months.c-Includes a gain of $ 1.4 million, or 1 cent a diluted share, mostly from sales of equity securities, and a net gain of $ 1.8 million, or 2 cents a diluted share, from California Proposition 103 settlement, which was less than Progressive's reserves for it, in the quarter and 9 months. The 9 months also included a gain of $ 14.2 million from the cumulative effect of accounting change.

title: Transactions
description: Football National Football League

title: Lemieux Sets Return to Penguins' Lineup
description: MARIO LEMIEUX, progressing on schedule from his second off-season back operation in four years, plans to return to the Pittsburgh Penguins' lineup next Thursday against Quebec.

title: Destec Energy Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a gain of $ 11,305,000, or 18 cents a share, from cumulative effect of change in accounting for income taxes.

title: Term Limits Limit Voters' Rights
description: Cities and towns all over America have adopted term limits for their elected officials. In the past few years, 15 states have also put limits on the number of years their senators and representatives may serve in Washington. The idea has an irresistibly popular ring to it: Force the rascals out! But it is profoundly wrong.

title: U.S. TO OFFER PLAN ON A ROLE IN NATO FOR EX-SOVIET BLOC
description: The United States has decided to support an expansion of NATO that could eventually include Russia, the countries of Eastern Europe and other former members of the Warsaw Pact, a senior aide to Secretary of State Warren Christopher said today.

title: White House Issues An Order to Bolster Recycling of Paper
description: After months of wrangling between environmental groups and the paper industry, the Clinton Administration yesterday issued an executive order requiring Federal agencies and the military to buy paper made from at least 20 percent recycled fiber by the end of next year and 30 percent by the end of 1998.

title: Term-Limit Backers to Begin Ad Campaign
description: The day after New York State's Court of Appeals approved a referendum on limiting elected municipal officeholders to two terms, supporters of the measure said they would be able to mount a well-financed campaign that would include television and radio advertising. Opponents conceded they would be heavily outgunned.

title: INSIDE
description: Teheran and Baghdad Talk

title: Assembly Vote Reaffirms Colonial-Era Land Deals
description: The General Assembly, bowing to pressure from people whose homes and businesses have been the targets of Indian tribal land claims, voted today to reaffirm the legality of land transfers by Indians to early colonists.

title: Crompton & Knowles Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 25
description: b-After a charge of $ 5,800,000 from adoption of FASB 106 and FASB 109.Latest share earnings for the 9 months included a charge of about 1 cent a share for increased federal income taxes retroactive to January 1993.

title: Menstruation Doesn't Promote Infection
description: To the Editor:

title: Germantown Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a gain of $ 1.5 million from the sale of securities and a gain of $ 639,000 from the sale of a group of consumer loans in the quarter and 9 months. The 9 months also included a charge of $ 2,419,000 from the adoption of FASB 106.

title: G. E. Wiedenmayer, Company Chairman And Ex-Banker, 85
description: Gustave E. Wiedenmayer, who spent 44 years with Midlantic Banks Inc. and helped build it into New Jersey's biggest bank holding company, died on Sunday at his home in Dorset, Vt. He was 85 and also had a home in Boca Raton, Fla.

title: BANKAMERICA CORP. (N)
description: The BankAmerica Corporation, the nation's second-largest banking company after Citicorp, said yesterday that third-quarter earnings fell slightly from the preceding quarter and were only about 3 percent higher than a year earlier.

title: Subdued Start for Tokyo Car Show
description: The gargantuan Tokyo Motor Show began today with the theme of "ecolution," a Japanese-coined combination of ecology and evolution that is meant to refer to cars that do not harm the environment.

title: Leetch Is the Latest Ranger to Feel the Wrath of Keenan
description: No one expected that Brian Leetch would be a problem. He was supposed to be a savior, a player whose absence last season because of injuries could explain much of the Rangers' dreadful downfall.

title: U.S. TELLS HAITIANS OF EMBARGO TERMS
description: Sharply raising the stakes for the Haitian military, United States diplomats announced a stringent series of conditions today that they said must be met before international sanctions placed on Haiti this week can be lifted.

title: Irving M. Ariel; Surgeon, 82
description: Dr. Irving M. Ariel, a surgeon, medical educator and specialist in radiation therapy for cancer, died on Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 82.

title: Review/Music; Mourning and Mending: Reflections on War
description: Benjamin Britten's "War Requiem" is one of 20th-century music's rare public works. In the vastness of its scale, in the breadth of its humanitarian aims and in the simplicity of its language, this is music intended to move large numbers of listeners at first hearing and at no sacrifice of original intentions to mass appeal.

title: Wallace Lozier, 87, Physicist Who Won An Academy Award
description: Dr. W. Wallace Lozier, a physicist who helped the Union Carbide Corporation win an Oscar in the 1950's with his work on lighting techniques, died on Oct. 9 at a nursing home in Bay Village, Ohio. He was 87 and, until last year, lived in Rocky River, Ohio.

title: Cray Computer (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Wall Unit? Big TV? No, 'an Experience'
description: The wrap-around blue leather sectional sofa shook as a jet thundered, in Dolby Surround sound, toward a group of furniture retailers at the International Home Furnishings Market. The buyers gathered in the Ladd Furniture showroom were checking out the company's introductions in the hot-and-getting-hotter category of home theater.

title: Hershey Foods reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 3

title: Reno Chastises TV Networks On Violence in Programming
description: Attorney General Janet Reno told the television industry today that unless it moved immediately to stem the tide of shootings, stabbings and other mayhem beamed daily into the nation's homes, the White House and Congress would seek laws to do it for them.

title: On the Rebound, Spurs Take Gamble on Rodman
description: Dennis Rodman will say to your face what many people say behind his back.

title: Pop and Jazz in Review
description: Steve Vai The Academy

title: Once Again, Burger King Shops for an Agency
description: Burger King, which changes advertising agencies practically at the flip of a Whopper, is doing so again.

title: Greg Manning Auctions Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company attributed the higher earnings in the fourth quarter of fiscal 1992 to the World Columbian Stamp Expo in May 1992, in which the company generated 64 percent of its full-year net income.The company said its latest fourth quarter included additional expenses from its initial public offering in May.

title: A Wary Reply to South Africa's Call
description: Sprung from its economic shackles after more than a decade of sanctions, South Africa is seeking foreign investment to help cushion its transition to a multiracial democracy. But many American companies are so leery of the country's volatile politics that they are staying away and, it now appears, will not play a major role in shaping the start of this new era.

title: TV Venture For Digital
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation has teamed with two partners to develop a system to allow home television sets to get access to movies, home shopping services and interactive games.

title: Taxpayers, Not Prisoners, Are Being Punished
description: To the Editor:

title: Report Finds Shelter System Worsening
description: New York City's shelters for the homeless deteriorated in 1993 to their worst condition since 1986, a study to be released today has found.

title: The Turning of the Leaves Puts Senses at Their Mercy
description: I JUST wanted an excuse to drive up to Ithaca, N.Y., because a friend had told me it was my kind of place: intellectuals and cows all mixed up together. So I decided to go take a look at the fall colors and talk to a few tree lovers at Cornell University about why the leaves change from green to gold to red. But the conversation kept drifting away from chlorophyll and anthocyanins into memory.

title: Parker Hannifin Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Parker Hannifin said that this year's first quarter net was reduced by $ 1.6 million representing the effect of recently enacted tax law changes in Germany and the U.S. The company also said net for the quarter was hurt by restructuring costs of 2 cents a share, primarily for its European industrial business.

title:
CURRENTS;
Exploring Jefferson's Real Passion
description: THOMAS JEFFERSON'S role as a statesman continues to generate a stream of books and magazine articles. But his rule-breaking architecture still surprises much of the public. An exhibition originating in New York, "Thomas Jefferson and the Design of Monticello," redresses the situation by emphasizing Jefferson's design experiments in his home in Charlottesville, Va.

title: Johnson & Johnson reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 3
description: b-After a charge of $ 595,000,000 from an adoption of accounting changes for postretirement benefits, postemployment benefits and income taxes Year-ago results are restated to include an incremental after tax charge of $ 11 million from the adoption of accounting changes for postretirement benefits, postemployment benefits and income taxes.c-Restated to include incremental $ 35 million after tax charge from the above accounting changes.

description: Year-ago 12 months included a charge of $ 9.5 million from a court-ordered remand of a rate order.

title: A Big Gain In Earnings At Compaq
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation, continuing to profit while much of the personal computer industry is struggling, said today that third-quarter earnings more than doubled and that sales reached record levels for the fifth straight quarter.

title: Business Group Assails Scope and Cost of Clinton Health Plan
description: A leading business group that the White House had hoped to recruit as a major backer of its health care plan criticized many elements of the proposal today, saying it was far too ambitious and costly.

title: Economist Takes Reins at University of Chicago
description: Hugo F. Sonnenschein, an economist and former provost of Princeton University who almost flunked out of college as an 18-year-old undergraduate, was inaugurated today as the 11th president of the University of Chicago.

title: Losses Force Lloyd's Into New Funding
description: Battered by nearly $9 billion in losses over the last three years and with more to come, the Lloyd's of London insurance market today adopted the most radical change since its founding three centuries ago -- an effort to attract new financing and renewed confidence.

title: You Call This Jam? Traffic Was Frozen in Place.; Nighttime Accidents in Greenwich, Conn., Turn Into Rush-Hour Gridlock on I-95
description: Shari Cardozo offered to help the paramedics, but they said things were under control. She fiddled with the radio. She snacked on junk food she found in the car. She turned the engine on to keep warm. She turned it off to save gasoline. She kicked off her shoes and napped for a while. Finally, nine hours later, she drove off, having spent the night stuck in a 30-mile-long traffic jam on Interstate 95 caused by two chain-reaction tractor-trailer pileups in Greenwich, Conn.

description: b-Included a pretax loss of $ 6,665,000 on the sale of assets.

description: The Philadelphia Eagles agreed to terms today on a one-year contract with 37-year-old wide receiver JAMES LOFTON, the National Football League's career leader in receiving yards. Terms of the deal weren't given.

CURRENTS;

description: WHAT are architects dreaming up for the millennium? A house that looks forward but also looks back. The split, effective Jan. 1, places Philips's account, estimated at $20 million to $30 million, in review.

title: Yanks' Abbott Honored for Achievements
description: Making it to the majors with a hand deformed from birth was an impressive enough achievement, but it was the no-hitter he pitched for the Yankees against Cleveland on Sept. 4 that clinched JIM ABBOTT's selection to receive the Freedom Forum's Free Spirit Award at a dinner at the New York Public Library last night.

title: DIGITAL EQUIPMENT CORP. (N)

description: Mary E. Clark, a lawyer who successfully campaigned for a change in Florida law so that people with major illnesses would not lose a large part of their medical insurance coverage, died here on Saturday. She was 37.

title: Gaston, Fregosi Ask: Who'll Stop the Rain? Not Their Pitchers

description: Mom drinks, Dad is a lying adulterer, Junior has AIDS and Sis -- well, she's truly a mess, a pill-popping semi-amnesiac. So, really, what else is new?

description: Peter G. Nash, a former general counsel for the National Labor Relations Board and top lawyer for the Department of Labor, died on Tuesday at his home in Gaithersburg, Md. He was 56.

description: Shares of Information America Inc. rebounded yesterday. The Atlanta-based company gathers information from government agencies and other sources and sells it through computer data bases that can be accessed by telephone. Its stock had slumped this week after it broke off talks to buy three information services from Paramount Communications.

title: Schilling Tunes Out On Jays Videos
description: Curt Schilling studied videotape after videotape of Toronto's hitters before starting Game 2 of the World Series. Schilling was trying to find some weaknesses in the powerful lineup and he thought his research was successful. Schilling went to the mound with a batch of information and promptly allowed six earned runs in six and a third innings in an 8-5 loss. So much for the videotapes.

These actions reduced earnings by 4 cents a share.c-Reflected after-tax gain of $ 22 million, or 10 cents a share, on the sale of the distribution rights of the cigarette papers and related products. The cumulative effect of the adoption of both accounting changes reduced earnings by 9 cents a share. It also reflected the effect of increased corporate tax structure.

title: FREEPORT-MCMORAN RESOURCE UNITS FALL 14 PERCENT
description: Freeport-McMoran Resource Partners L.P.'s units were down more than 14 percent yesterday amid concerns about whether the partnership might delay the payment of cash distributions to its unit holders. The oil, gas and mining partnership, based in New Orleans, said on Tuesday that it would not borrow money to finance payment of the distribution, the equivalent of a common-stock dividend. The partnership's units fell $3, to $17.75, on the New York Stock Exchange. Freeport-McMoran Resource, a unit of Freeport-McMoran Inc., said its public unit holders would be entitled to receive 60 cents a unit each quarter through the end of 1996.

title: Dole Concedes to Clinton in Fight Over Right to Send Troops to Haiti
description: Senator Bob Dole, the Republican leader, backed off today from a proposal to restrict President Clinton's military options in Haiti and agreed to downgrade it to a nonbinding "sense of the Senate" resolution.

title: Playing on Uncertainties About the Health Plan
description: SPONSOR: The Coalition for Health Insurance Choices, financed by the Health Insurance Association fo America. ON THE SCREEN: A couple, Harry and Louise, is sitting over breakfast. He is reading a newspaper, she a published version of the President's health care plan. The camera angle changes, and we see the health care plan from above as Louise underlines a passage with a yellow marking pen. At the end of the ad, an 800 number appears along with a tag identifying the sponsors. THE SCRIPT: Harry: "I'm glad the President's doing something about health care reform."....Louise: "He's right. We need it."... Harry: "Some of these details--"... Louise: "Like a national limit on health care?"... Harry: "Really." ...Louise: "The government caps how much the country can spend on all health care and says, 'That's it!"'...Harry: "So what if our health plan runs out of money?"...Louise: "There's got to be a better way." ACCURACY: The implication of the ad is that under the President's plan, only a certain amount of money can be spent on health care, and after that, patients will be out of luck. The President has proposed a complicated set of regulations to limit the rate in increase in health care spending to the inflation rate. Among other things, these regulations would limit the amount that health insurance premiums could rise each year. Many health care providers are concerned that the limits would adversely affect the quality of care and that some health care plans might actually run out of money. The President's proposal also calls for each state to set up contingency funds to bail out insolvent plans. SCORECARD: The ad purports to reflect the concerns of average citizens, and it effectively appeals to a generalized sense that the Clinton Administration's plan doesn't quite add up. But the ad has an melodramatic, overacted quality that may make viewers suspicious. And once they learn the ad is sponsored by the insurance industry, these suspicions are only likely to increase. ELIZABETH KOLBERT

title: Review/Television; A 'Cheers' Spinoff, Set in Seattle
description: One guy is a bit of a slob, happy to plop into his vibrating Barcalounger with a can of beer; the other is a finicky esthete, partial to fine wines and Eames chairs. Think Oscar and Felix in "The Odd Couple." The older one is working-class gruff; the younger upwardly-mobile sarcastic. Think Archie and Meathead in "All in the Family." "Frasier," Thursdays at 9:30 on NBC, is not the season's most original concept, but it's one of the few new series likely to survive. And deservedly, not just because it follows "Seinfeld."

title: STORAGE TECHNOLOGY COMPLETES AMPERIF MERGER
description: The Storage Technology Corporation said yesterday that it had completed its acquisition of the Amperif Corporation, a closely held developer of disk storage subsystems for Unisys computers. Amperif stockholders approved the merger involving the exchange of 1.9 million shares and warrants of Storagetek common stock for all the outstanding shares of Amperif. At Storagetek's stock price of $25.25 yesterday, the transaction is valued at about $48 million, nearly half what it was when the acquisition was announced on May 20. Since then, losses and uncertainties surrounding Storagetek's Iceberg mainframe storage product have shaved almost 56 percent off the value of the company's shares.

It might be, major league baseball officials and owners believe, if the players received money for the rest of the games. As long as the players play for nothing past Game 4, officials and owners have no fear about the legitimacy of any World Series games.

New Architectural Center Tucked Within a Museum

Now, Pittsburgh also has the Heinz Architectural Center, opening Nov. 7 within the Carnegie Art Museum. The three-story study and exhibition center, designed by Cicognani Kalla Architects, a New York City firm, should increase public appreciation of architecture.

Bernard Thevenet said it would favor climbers and Miguel Indurain said it would be different. All of them, winners of the Tour de France, agreed that the 81st edition of the bicycle race would be difficult.

title: Senate Opens Debate on Measure To Increase Grazing Fees in West
description: The Senate began debate today on compromise legislation that would raise grazing fees on Federal land in the West, but some senators from the region who oppose the plan said they would filibuster the measure.

title: Irene Sharaff Memorial
description: A memorial tribute to Irene Sharaff, the costume designer, is to be held on Monday at 5 P.M. at the John Houseman Theater, 450 West 42d Street, Clinton. Ms. Sharaff died in August at the age of 83. The speakers are to include Leo Lerman, the writer and editor; Gray Foy, the artist, and the theatrical designers Donald Brooks, William Ivey Long and Barbara Matera. Film clips illustrating Ms. Sharaff's work for "The King and I" and "An American in Paris" are to be shown. The tribute is open to the public.

title: BANKERS TRUST NEW YORK CORP. (N)
description: The Bankers Trust New York Corporation earned a record $310 million profit in the third quarter as all of its leading lines of business grew and provided more earnings than they did a year earlier.

title: Review/Dance; Bill Jones Troupe, in an Elegy for Departed Friends
description: The Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company is one of this country's most provocative and interesting modern dance troupes, even when operating at something less than full capability as it did on Wednesday night at the Joyce Theater (175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street, Chelsea). The new dance on this second program of a two-week season was relatively minor. But the performing was as impressive as ever. And Mr. Jones and dancers still provide one of the few occasions when today's modern dance addresses social issues of the time theatrically, and does so with a cathartic passion.

title:
City Incentives;
Tenements Are Rebuilt As Rentals

description: Two Brooklyn teen-agers have been arrested in a series of robberies of homes in affluent neighorhoods in eastern Queens, and the police said yesterday that the arrests had ended the crimes. A third suspect remained at large.

title: Rebound Hopes Rise on German Rate Cuts
description: Catching financial markets off guard, Germany's central bank lowered its two most important interest rates today by half a percentage point, awakening hopes that Western Europe's troubled economies will begin to bounce back in the months ahead.

title: Ukraine to Keep Chernobyl in Operation
description: The Ukrainian Parliament voted today to continue nuclear energy production at the Chernobyl power plant, reversing its decision of two years ago to shut the power station down by the end of 1993 because of safety concerns.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary last Friday about the actress Ruth Gilbert misstated the place of her death. She had been a patient at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan, but she died at a hospice at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * Cyprus Minerals Co., Englewood, Colo., priced $250 million of 6 5/8 percent notes due in 2005 at 99.392 to yield 6.70 percent through Kidder, Peabody & Co. The nonredeemable notes are rated Baa-2 by Moody's Investors Service and BBB by Standard & Poor's Corp. and are priced to yield about 140 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, more than a 10-year Treasury security. * New York State Energy Research and Development Authority priced $147 million of tax-exempt facilities-refunding-revenue bonds on behalf of Consolidated Edison Co. of New York through Goldman, Sachs & Co. The bulk of the financing consists of a bond due in 2020 priced to yield about 5.276 percent. The rest is a bond due in 2022 that is priced to yield 5.375 percent. The offering is rated Aa-2 by Moody's and AA- by S.& P.

title: U.S. Freezes Assets of 41 Haitians
description: The Clinton Administration stepped up its campaign against Haiti's military leadership today by giving American banks a list of Haitian military and police leaders whose bank accounts, real estate and other assets are to be frozen.

title: KOHLBERG, KRAVIS PLANS TO OFFER STOCK IN DURACELL
description: A Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company partnership plans to sell 5.8 million shares of stock in one of its prospering investments, Duracell International Inc. The stock sale will cut the partnership's stake in Duracell to 47.8 percent from 52.72 percent. But it will also enable the partnership, KKR Associates, to reap profits for institutional backers at a time when other Kohlberg, Kravis investments, like RJR Nabisco Holdings, are struggling. Shares of Duracell, a Bethel, Conn., manufacturer of alkaline batteries, fell $1.375 yesterday, to $34.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: If You Have a Good Game, They Will Watch, and Stay
description: If World Series viewers must stay up past midnight, they apparently prefer a competitive game to keep their eyelids from drooping.

title: Prosecutor Appointed In Balkan War Trials
description: The Security Council today unanimously appointed Venezuela's Attorney General, Ramon Escovar-Salom, as the prosecutor charged with bringing war criminals in the Balkans to justice before the special war crimes tribunal it has already created.

title: MOBIL CORP. (N)
description: The Mobil Corporation said yesterday that its 40 percent rise in third-quarter operating profit was the result of higher international oil production, strong margins in refinery operations, and increased sales of its petroleum products.

title: James Leo Herlihy, 66, Novelist Who Wrote 'Midnight Cowboy'

description: Dr. Lawrence Randolph Hafstad, a physicist who played an important role in the development of nuclear power plants, died on Oct. 12 at his home in Oldwick, N.J. He was 89. He had lived in Washington most of his life.

description: In foreign policy as in domestic policy, Senator Bob Dole of Kansas can play good cop / bad cop with President Clinton.

A number of these executives said they were puzzled by Ms. Reno's warning, which came in the aftermath of several tragedies apparently linked to a movie and a television program.

title: A New Party in Western Canada Growing on Protest and Populism
description: Prairie populism, fed by economic disgruntlement, disenchantment with mainline politicians and hostility to power in Ottawa, is energizing a new political party that promises to give the Canadian West a greater say in the way the country is governed.

The terms were not disclosed. The brands, which include Tahiti, Pouss' Mousse and Soft Wash, are market leaders in Europe and the South Pacific and have sales of $75 million. Colgate's personal care business, which includes Palmolive and Irish Spring soaps, generates more than $1.6 billion in annual sales.

Just such a drama unfolds in a small, stunning show of the artist's paintings on paper at C&M Arts, a gallery that occupies the generous foyer and dining room of the Upper East Side town house belonging to Robert Mnuchin, an art collector turned art dealer.

title: Colgate-Palmolive reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a charge of $ 358,200,000 from an accounting adjustment.

title: The Brothers Gretzky
description: BRENT GRETZKY couldn't look his brother in the eyes. "I was too nervous," the Tampa Bay rookie said Wednesday night, describing the first face-off of his pro career against his older brother and nine-time National Hockey League most valuable player, WAYNE.

title: It May Be Nafta or Japan, A Clinton Aide Argues
description: Picking up a theme pursued by the Clinton Administration this week, Roger C. Altman, the Deputy Secretary of the Treasury, warned yesterday that if Congress rejected the North American Free Trade Agreement, a backlash in Mexico might lead the Government there to sign a trade deal with Japan.

title: Not Your Usual Sorts of Antiques
description: The largest assortment of Americana ever shown at the Fall Antiques Show will be on view through Sunday at the Hudson River pier at 52d Street in Manhattan.

title: Adventures in Daveland (and Not Just at Night)
description: SOMETIMES television viewers begin to think of the characters they watch as real people. Psychologists have a term for this. The viewer, they say, has entered into a "parasocial relationship" with the figures on the small screen.

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows in New York City that are to close soon: Closing This Weekend "HOLLY NEAR: FIRE IN THE RAIN," Union Square Theater, 100 East 17th Street. An autobiographical play with music by Holly Near, starring Ms. Near and co-written and produced by Timothy Near. Through Sunday. Performances: today at 8 P.M.; tomorrow at 7 and 10 P.M.; Sunday at 3 and 7 P.M. Tickets: $30. Information; (212) 307-4100. "OEDIPUS THE KING," Pearl, 125 West 22d Street, Chelsea. Sophocles' drama, directed by Ted Davis. Through tomorrow. Performances: tonight at 8; tomorrow at 5 and 9 P.M. Tickets: $16 to $20. Information: (212) 645-7708. PHOTOS BY RODDY MCDOWALL, Nikon House, 620 Fifth Avenue, at Rockefeller Center. Celebrity photographs by the actor. Through tomorrow. Hours: Today and tomorrow, 9:30 A.M. to 5:30 P.M. Free. Information: (212) 586-3907. ALFRED STIEGLITZ, Pace/MacGill, 32 East 57th Street, Manhattan. Vintage photographs from the collection of Georgia O'Keeffe. Through tomorrow. Hours: Today, 9:30 A.M. to 5:30 P.M.; tomorrow, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. Free. Information: (212) 759-7999. "FOOD FOR THOUGHT," St. Marks Church, Second Avenue at 10th Street, East Village. A Dancspace Project presentation. Through Sunday. Performances: tonight through Sunday at 8:30 P.M. Tickets: $10, or $5 with two cans of food. Information: (212) 674-8194. ROBERT DOISNEAU, Witkin Gallery, 415 West Broadway, at Prince Street, SoHo. Photographs. Closes tomorrow. Hours: today and tomorrow, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. Free. Information: (212) 925-5510. Closing Next Weekend "NEW YORK SCHOOL," Long Fine Art Gallery, 24 West 57th Street, Manhattan. Drawings and paintings by Motherwell, Francis, Pollock and Frankenthaler. Through Oct. 30. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M.; closed Sundays and Mondays. Free. Information: (212) 397-2001.

title: End the Grim Harvest
description: The United Nations General Assembly turned its attention this week to the legacy of death from 100 million land mines sown across the globe. Calling for a report by next year on improving international mine-clearing efforts, for the first time the Assembly formally recognized the need to assist the estimated 62 countries afflicted by this scourge.

title: Schlumberger Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a charge of $ 248 million from a change in accounting for postretirement benefits other than pensions.

title: Blast Prosecutors Making Case, Shard by Shard
description: A piece of a brake drum, some shreds of burned tire, a hinge with flecks of yellow paint, the twisted wreckage of a wheel, pieces of manifold and an alternator -- these were among the items displayed to the jury yesterday as prosecutors, testing the patience of the judge and risking losing the attention of the jury, continued, slowly and methodically, to build their case against the four men accused of blowing up the World Trade Center last Feb. 26.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL REPORT
description: Princeton

title: Chancellor Tries to Resolve Parent Protest
description: Schools Chancellor Ramon C. Cortines sought without success again yesterday to mediate between parents occupying a Brooklyn elementary school and their local community school board, which wants the parents and students to leave.

title: Russia Halts Nuclear Waste Dumping in Sea
description: Bowing to protests from Japan, the United States, and other countries, Russia said today that it had suspended plans to dump low-level nuclear waste into the Sea of Japan this weekend.

title: QVC NETWORK TRIES TO WIN PARAMOUNT WITH A HOSTILE BID
description: The fight for Paramount Communications became hostile yesterday, as QVC Network Inc. decided to bypass the Paramount board and take its offer directly to the shareholders.

title: Plan Opens More Data To Public
description: In the clearest indication yet of the Clinton Administration's willingness to offer broader public access to Government information, the National Science Foundation is financing a project that will make corporate filings to the Securities and Exchange Commission available free via a computer network.

title: In Hungry Belgrade, a Yen for Peace
description: In the central square here, Vida Milivojevic took out a knife. Brandishing it in her right hand as she stood over a 70-pound side of pork propped on a bench, she began hacking the meat into pieces small enough to fit into her bag.

title: Jays' Hopes Are Trapped By Chance
description: Trailing by 2-0 in the eighth inning tonight, the Blue Jays finally had a rally going against Phillies right-hander Curt Schilling. With none out, Willie Canate, pinch-running for Pat Borders after the catcher had singled, hurried to third on Rob Butler's pinch-hit single.

title: 54 Years of Talent
description: The next American teen-aged tennis phenomenon, 13-year-old VENUS WILLIAMS, will team up with the evergreen phenom, 41-year-old JIMMY CONNORS, tomorrow night in Baltimore for the First National Bank Tennis Festival. The event is sponsored by the tennis player PAM SHRIVER to assist children's charities in her hometown.

title: Canadian Takeover Bid
description: Desjardins Group, Quebec's largest financial institution, detailed a takeover bid this week for the Laurentian Group Corporation valued at $11.57 Canadian a share, or a total of $625 million Canadian, about $475 million United States.

title: Gillette Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a charge of $ 138,600,000 from an accounting adjustment.

title: Kuriles Were Ceded To Soviets by Treaty
description: To the Editor:

title: PRUDENTIAL AGREES TO PAY INVESTORS FOR FRAUD LOSSES
description: Prudential Securities Inc. agreed today to repay hundreds of thousands of customers for huge losses they suffered because of widespread fraud at the firm for more than a decade.

title: CONGRESSMEN KILL THE SUPERCOLLIDER
description: A Congressional panel officially killed the $11 billion Superconducting Supercollider today, but not before a final bitter wrangle between the members of the House and Senate conference committee over how lavish to make the burial.

title: Review/Film; Microcosms: 2 Jewish Retreats
description: "The Shvitz," Jonathan Berman's rambling documentary history of New York steam baths, is only 50 minutes long. But so much of the film is devoted to showing pot-bellied, hairy-chested men over 50 waddle around in towels and drip sweat that watching it is not unlike sitting in a steam room too long. You are likely to leave the film feeling wrung out rather than energized.

title: Bye-Bye, Rabbit Balls: The Dead-Ball Era Is Back
description: For the better part of four games in the World Series, the stage belonged to the big boys. The record 65 runs scored by the Toronto Blue Jays and Philadelphia Phillies indicated as much.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-10 EUROPE BACKS U.S. NATO PLAN Reaffirming NATO's view, European defense chiefs embraced Washington's plans to offer former Soviet republics and East European nations closer ties with NATO but not early membership. A1 The Czech President criticized associate membership in NATO. A8

title: Can't We Afford a Little Music in Our Lives?; New York Leads
description: To the Editor:

title: Help Addicts? Sure. We Promise. Really!
description: Four years ago, during the last campaign for mayor, David Dinkins flatly committed himself to the principle of drug treatment on demand. "There's an awful lot we need to do to cure the problem of drugs," the candidate said at a televised debate on Aug. 1, 1989. "First of all, we need treatment on demand." He repeated that pledge numerous times during the campaign.

title: Bishops and Health Care
description: To the Editor:

title: GERRITY OIL PUTS ITSELF UP FOR SALE AND SHARES RISE
description: Shares of the Gerrity Oil and Gas Corporation rose nearly 7 percent after the company announced late on Wednesday that it was up for sale. The shares rose $1 yesterday, to $17.75, on the New York Stock Exchange. Analysts said recent lawsuits against senior management and questions about its environmental record and field operations might have motivated the sale. Gerrity Oil, based in Denver, said it had received a number of inquiries from potential acquirers.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Jimmy Scott Returns

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; For Lintas, the cruelest month: Diet Coke is lost, now an upstart swipes the IBM PC account.
description: IN a second big dose of bad news this month, Lintas Worldwide was dropped by I.B.M.'s personal computer division just 16 days the agency lost the Diet Coke account.

title: Review/Film; Fencing as Metaphor for Honor and the Lack Thereof
description: "By the Sword" is a half-baked little movie about modern fencing as a sport and a way of life. F. Murray Abraham and Eric Roberts star in the film, which was directed by Jeremy Kagan and written by John McDonald and James Donadio. It opens today at the Loews 34th Street Showplace.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: FIAT S.p.A., Turin, Italy, will merge the construction and public works activities of its Cogefar-Impresit subsidiary with those of two privately owned construction companies, Lodigiani and Girola. NORTHWEST AIRLINES INC., St. Paul, and KLM Royal Dutch Airlines will merge their Dutch cargo operations, combining the marketing, sales and handling services under KLM Cargo.

title: Genuine Parts reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a charge of $ 3,052,000 for the new tax rate, and a charge of $ 950,000 to reflect the impact of the rate increase in accordance with the earlier adoption of a change in accounting for income taxes in both the quarter and 9 months.c-After a charge of $ 1,055,000 from cumulative effect of a change in accounting for postretirement benefits, a charge of $ 5,055,000, and an increase in net income of $ 4 million for a change in accounting for income taxes.

title: Mere 90 Minutes Dwarfed by Eight Years of War
description: For eight years they waged the longest conventional war of this century. For the last two weeks they have shared the same pool table and dining room.

title: SALOMON INC. (N)
description: Salomon Inc.'s $20 million third-quarter profit, announced yesterday, was lower than expected because of a $173 million pretax loss that its SaloBrothers unit had trading for its own account.

title: Art in Review
description: 'Ann Hamilton' 'Tropos' Dia Center for the Arts 548 West 22d Street Chelsea Through June 19

title: Daimler Raising $510 Million
description: Daimler-Benz A.G., which early this month became the first German company to list its stock on the New York Stock Exchange, yesterday priced $510.2 million of asset-backed securities for sale to the public.

title: Sherrard Listed As Satisfactory
description: The medical condition of Giants wide receiver Mike Sherrard was good yesterday. Doctors at the Hospital for Special Surgery in Manhattan, where Sherrard was being treated for a blood clot in his left hip, listed him in satisfactory condition.

title: The Victory Column Is Empty for Guzman
description: Juan Guzman had just lost his first World Series game, he had just lost the delicious chance to be remembered as the pitcher who had secured Toronto's second straight championship, but he still burst into a mammoth grin in front of his locker after the game. Why was this man smiling?

title: Zoo Story: A Q.-and-A. Stroll in Queens
description: MANY people love the zoo, but no one wants to see a bunch of disaffected animals stuck in tiny, dirty cages clearly wishing they were doing something else, like sprinting across the plains. I still think with horror about a zoo I visited a couple of years ago whose main features were a wrinkled, one-tusked elephant (he looked for all the world like the elephant who ate something bad and died in the Babar story) and some bedraggled, mangy bison lying in a heap.

title: Home Video
description: Studios are always looking for reasons to recycle old movies on videotape, especially big old movies. Usually a major anniversary will do, but this fall there is a fresh promotional theme for special editions: new tapes made from master prints that come from original film negatives.

title: More Signs of a Productive U.S.
description: Contrary to a widely held view that the United States is an industrial has-been whose productivity in manufacturing has been surpassed in some other countries, a new study concludes that for manufacturing as a whole, the United States still holds a significant edge over the presumed world standard-setters, Germany and Japan.

title: TV Weekend; A Vigilante Mayor for Rome, Wis.
description: Tonight at 10, CBS's "Picket Fences" returns for a second season and wastes no time showing why it won this year's Emmy Award for best drama. Initially somewhat flaky, as if hung over from too many rounds of "Twin Peaks," the series has gradually fastened on an astute mix of drama and low-key humor, cleverly draped around one family and a small Wisconsin town named Rome.

title: New Rules on Satellite Paging
description: The Federal Communications Commission adopted rules today under which it will license new satellite-delivered paging and message services.

title: Memorial for James Peck
description: A memorial tribute to James Peck, union organizer, pacifist and civil rights worker, will be held at 6 P.M. Saturday at the Friends Meeting House at 15 Rutherford Place in Manhattan.

title: Revolution in Lawyers' Fees: The Meter Is Being Shut Off
description: It has been the bedrock of the lawyer-client relationship for decades: the billable hour. Lawyers have charged for their services by the hour, many with little inhibition about the number of hours accumulated, and clients have paid, often without a second thought.

title: Review/Theater; Family Genetics With a Background of Wagner
description: "The Twilight of the Golds," Jonathan Tolins's calculatingly topical play, which opened at the Booth Theater last night, would like us to consider a multitude of big questions: eugenics, the true breadth of tolerance among self-defined liberals and the limits of family love. But the principal moral to be gleaned from it is of a different order altogether: If you're writing a small, facile comic melodrama -- which, in spite of its painfully lofty ambitions, is all this play is at best -- it's definitely not a good idea to drag in Wagner's "Ring" cycle as your central point of reference.

title: General Dynamics Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 1 million, or 3 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 651,000,000, or $ 20.59 a share, in the 9 months, which included $ 645 million net gain on sale of Tactical Military Aircraft business in March 1993.c-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 84 million, or $ 2.64 a share, in the quarter and $ 546,000,000, or $ 13.71 a share, in the 9 months, which included $ 358 million net gain on sale of Cessna Aircraft Co. in February 1992. The 9 months also included a gain of $ 7 million, or 22 cents a share, on disposal income.Sales represented net sales.

title: Man Is Shot to Death And 2 Are Wounded
description: A man was shot and killed and another man and a youth were wounded last night when an unidentified man walked up to a crowd on a Brooklyn street and started shooting, the police said.

title: Tax-Credit Financing to Aid In Building Housing Units
description: New York City should get enough money from a Federal tax-credit program to help build at least 6,000 new housing units for the poor over the next five years, housing advocates said yesterday.

title: Amoco Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a gain of $ 70 million from the sale of certain Canadian properties in both the quarter and 9 months; tax benefits totaling $ 57 million in the quarter and $ 60 million in the 9 months; a tax loss of $ 53 million in the quarter and a charge of $ 170 million from the writedown of certain African operations in the 9 months.c-Net lossd-Included a tax benefit of $ 42 million in the quarter and the 9 months included a charge of $ 924 million from accounting changes; before the effect of that charge, and a charge of $ 625 million - largely from restructuring - operating earnings were $ 927 million, or $ 2.57 a share.

title: In REM Sleep? You Missed All the R.B.I.
description: Never before had a World Series game taken so long to complete. Never before had so many runs been scored in a World Series game. Never before had a losing team scored 14 runs. Never before had so many emotional twists and turns been packed into one stadium on one drizzly, foggy night. Never before. Maybe never again.

title: Papers Show Greed, Calculation and Betrayal in Stew Leonard Fraud Case
description: To the world at large, Stew Leonard was the smiling face on posters at his Connecticut dairy store, the man who made sure customers got what they wanted and who sometimes roamed the aisles in a cow costume, giving them warm hugs.

title: Political Memo; Abortion and the Health Plan: Hard Questions in Both Camps
description: Abortion rights groups are finishing a season of legislative struggle on Capitol Hill that carries some grim omens for their next great battle: the attempt to have abortion services, for rich and poor alike, covered under a national health care plan.

title: NATO Favors U.S. Plan for Ties With the East, but Timing Is Vague
description: European defense ministers today embraced a Clinton Administration plan that offers former Soviet republics and East European countries closer cooperation with NATO but not early membership in the alliance.

title: Art in Review
description: Markus Lupertz Michael Werner Gallery 21 East 67th Street Manhattan Through Oct. 30

title: Abroad at Home; The Road to Panic
description: Of all the recent setbacks for American foreign policy, none is as damaging to President Clinton's credibility as the humiliation in Haiti. Events there raise urgent questions -- for him as for us -- about the quality of the advice he is getting, and of his own leadership.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball American League

title: Diner's Journal
description: Culinary Melting Pot

title: Perot Ad to Attack Trade Pact
description: United We Stand America, the political group of Ross Perot, said today that it had produced a half-hour television commercial criticizing the North American Free Trade Agreement that will be broadcast in large cities on Sunday. Only one station, in Chicago, has so far agreed to broadcast the advertisement, but negotiations have begun with other stations, the group said.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF Elkington Beats Daly Long-hitting John Daly threw his club after missing a five-foot putt on the first hole of the world match play championship yesterday in Virginia Water, England and sent a 5-iron approach over the green and out of bounds on 12 in losing, 5 and 4, to Australian Steve Elkington. In other first-round matches, five-time champion Seve Ballesteros lost, 7 and 6, to David Frost; Corey Pavin beat Peter Baker, 4 and 3, and Colin Montgomerie birdied the last two holes to top Yoshinori Mizumaki in 37 holes. (AP) Bogey Thwarts Morgan: A lapse on the last hole cost Gil Morgan sole control of the lead after the second round of the five-day Las Vegas, Nev., Invitational. Morgan's bogey-6 from the water dropped him into a share of the 36-hole lead with Bob Lohr, Keith Clearwater and Blaine McCallister. The mistake turned a potential 66 into a 4-under-par 68 and gave him a 132 total, 12 under par, with three rounds to go in the $1.4 million event. (AP) TENNIS John McEnroe Loses Second-seeded Richard Krajicek of the Netherlands beat John McEnroe, 6-4, 6-4, yesterday in justg under 90 minutes to advance to the semifinals of the Marlboro round-robin tournament in Hong Kong. (AP) Chang Survives in China: Top-seeded Michael Chang outlasted Shuzo Matsuoka of Japan, 6-4, 6-7 (3-7), 7-5, in a second-round match at the Salem Open in Beijing. Fourth-seeded Brad Gilbert beat Patrick Rafter of Australia, 7-6 (7-3), 4-6, 6-2. (AP) BOXING Gamez Gains Title Leo Gamez of Venezuela won the vacant World Boxing Association junior flyweight title last night in Tokyo by twice flooring previously unbeaten Shiro Yahiro of Japan and stopping him in the ninth round. (AP)

title: Czech Leader Pushes for Open NATO
description: In a sharp retort to what are regarded here as disappointing proposals by the United States for Eastern Europe's relationship with NATO, the Czech President, Vaclav Havel, declared today that associate membership in the alliance could not be a substitute for future security guarantees.

title: Cable Rates Have Risen For Many, F.C.C. Says
description: Preliminary results of a new Federal survey indicate that about one-third of all cable television customers saw their rates rise rather than fall after new pricing regulations went into effect on Sept. 1.

title: Gangs in Sarajevo Spread Terror, Unchecked by the Cowed Leaders
description: One evening this week, Swiss officials of the International Committee of the Red Cross, driving in a vehicle marked with the organization's distinctive red and white insignia, were followed through Sarajevo's darkened streets by a car carrying two armed men in the uniforms of the Bosnian Army. Outside the Red Cross's sandbagged headquarters, the gunmen robbed the Swiss representatives of their flak jackets and their two-way radios, then drove off.

title: COMPANY REPORTS; Times Company Reports Loss in Quarter
description: The New York Times Company said yesterday that it lost $3 million, or 4 cents a share, in the third quarter, down from a loss of $35 million, or 44 cents a share, for the comparable period last year.

title: Review/Film; A Child's Search for a World Where Blood Feuds Vanish
description: "Flight of the Innocent," an Italian film by Carlo Carlei, is about the desperate attempt of a wide-eyed, remarkably self-sufficient 10-year-old Calabrian boy named Vito (Manuel Colao) to escape his southern Italian heritage.

title: Conner Peripherals Has $372.4 Million Loss
description: Conner Peripherals Inc., the troubled computer disk drive maker, reported today a third-quarter loss of $372.4 million and said it was laying off 12 percent of its work force.

title: Don't Leap to Conclusions About Genius
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Le Nozze di Figaro'
description: The season's first performance of the New York City Opera production of Mozart's "Nozze di Figaro" is to take place tomorrow afternoon at 1:30 at the New York State Theater at Lincoln Center. In the cast are Michele Patzakis, singing her first Susanna with the City Opera; Jan Opalach, in his first appearance as Figaro with the company; Eduardo Del Campo and Christine Brewer in their City Opera debuts, as the Count and Countess Almaviva, and Gwendolyn Jones as Cherubino. Scott Bergeson conducts. The production is by John Copley. Tickets are $15 to $60. Information: (212) 870-5570.

title: Austin E. Smith, 81, Drug Firm Executive and Journal Editor
description: Dr. Austin E. Smith, the first president of the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association, vice chairman of the Warner-Lambert Company and editor of the Journal of the American Medical Association, died on Oct. 9 at his home in Fort Myers, Fla. He was 81.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: CHRONICLE
description: There ought to be enough de Menils assembled at the Pierre today to satisy admirers of the family of art patrons.

title: U.S. Peacekeeping Arrears Could Reach a Billion
description: The United States faces arrears approaching $1 billion for United Nations peacekeeping operations in the coming year after both houses of Congress passed a bill greatly reducing the budget contributions to the United Nations.

title: Enhanced Electronics Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Corrected from Saturday, Oct. 16, edition.

title: On My Mind; A President Like Us
description: Like all Presidents, Bill Clinton is just a human being, the same as the rest of us. The trouble is that he is acting like it.

title: Aftershocks of Verdicts Rumble Across the Nation
description: Far from Los Angeles, the verdict reverberated across the United States today, playing out like a Rorschach test of gaping racial divisions.

title: American General reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a charge of $ 30,044,000 from the Revenue Reconciliation Act of 1993 which increased the federal corporate income tax rate to 35 percent from 34 percent in both the quarter and 9 months, and the 9 months also included a charge of $ 36,680,000 from combined changes in accounting for income taxes and for postretirement benefits other than pensions.

title: Irish: Success, Injuries, Questions
description: From the instant the football left his right hand, Ron Powlus knew what was wrong. Last Sunday, in his first practice since breaking his right collarbone on Aug. 28, Powlus was throwing in a routine drill, without any contact, when he felt as if his right shoulder was temporarily too far ahead of his body.

title: Burlington Northern reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included $ 49 million charge from the effects of flooding in the and a $ 26 million non-cash charge to reflect higher corporate tax rate, as well as a $ 3 million increase in current and deferred income taxes. Combined, the two charges from the tax changes reduced income by $ 29 million, or 32 cents a share.c-Included $ 49 million charge from the effects of flooding in the third quarter, in addition to a charge of $ 7 to $ 10 million from flood-related expenses in the second quarter. Also included two charges that totalled $ 29 million from tax law changesd-After a net charge of $ 21,000,000 which included $ 11 million charge from cumulative effect of change in accounting for revenue recognition and a $ 10 million charge from cumulative effect of change in accounting for post-retirement benefits.The period also included impact of second quarter suspension of rail operations, which cut operating income by $ 17 million and a $ 47 million non-operating credit from a lawsuit settlement.

title: Scientologists Report Assets of $400 Million
description: The Church of Scientology, the secretive and combative international organization that recently won a decades-long drive for Federal tax exemption, counts assets of about $400 million and appears to take in nearly $300 million a year from counseling fees, book sales, investments and other sources, according to documents filed with the Internal Revenue Service.

title: BellSouth Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary loss on early repayment of debt of $ 7,800,000 in the quarter and $ 63,200,000 in the 9 months.c-After an extraordinary loss on early repayment of debt of $ 40,700,000 in both the quarter and 9 months.BellSouth said that the latest quarter net income also included one-time charges of 9 cents a share, most of which related to the year-to-date impact of the new higher corporate income tax rate.Year-ago quarter net also included a one-time charge of 8 cents a share related to debt refinancing.

title: Man Tied to Crime Family Is Shot to Death in Queens
description: A former union official whom the authorities described as a high-level boss in the Colombo organized-crime family was shot to death Wednesday night by several hooded gunmen in front of his house in Queens as he was returning from dinner with his nephew and future son-in-law.

title: Nynex Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included charges of 5 cents a share for higher corporate income tax rate in the quarter and 9 months, and 1 cent a share in the quarter and 3 cents a share in the 9 months, for debt retirement.c-Included gain of 5 cents a share on federal tax settlement.Year-ago periods' shares outstanding were restated for 2-for-1 stock split.

title: P.L.O. Moderate Shot Dead, Raising Fears on Pact
description: A leading moderate in the Palestine Liberation Organization was shot to death today in Gaza, intensifying fears that violence within the Palestinian movement could threaten the agreement to begin the transfer of authority in the occupied territories from Israel to the P.L.O.

title: 3 Are Injured In Wild Spree By Students
description: A violent midafternoon spree by students at feuding Brooklyn high schools spread from a schoolyard to two nearby subway stations and finally to a city bus yesterday, the authorities said.

title: Spectrum's 'Orderly' Session
description: At its annual meeting of shareholders at the convention center in Pasadena, Calif., Wednesday night, the management of Spectrum Information Technologies Inc. went over a selective menu of business items.

title: Franchise Swap Proposed To Owner of the Patriots
description: The owner of the New England Patriots wants to sell the team or, if that does not happen, perhaps move it. He is also a minority member of a group trying to get a National Football League expansion franchise for St. Louis.

title: MCDONALD'S CORP. (N)
description: The record third-quarter financial performance reported by the McDonald's Corporation yesterday was much stronger than the figures indicated, analysts said.

title: Market Place; Amid bleak quarterly estimates for I.B.M., some optimism.
description: WAITING for the turnaround at I.B.M. is going to take patience. And almost no one expects to see the evidence of a recovery on Tuesday, when the International Business Machines Corporation reports its third-quarter financial results.

title: Officer Cleared in Main Tailhook Case
description: The Marine Corps dropped all charges today against a Marine captain who had been charged with sexually molesting the admiral's aide and Navy aviator who first spoke out about the debauchery that occurred at the 1991 Tailhook Association convention.

title: Molitor Even Gets Hits After Games Are Over
description: Paul Molitor, the sizzling Toronto Blue Jays' designated hitter-turned-infielder, started out on a good note tonight even before stepping to the plate.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: Anxious Haitians Start Building Boats Again
description: Colbert St. Vil sat under a wooden boat with a chisel, carving the last touches on a vessel he said he was building to transport bags of rice and cement from ships docked at a nearby port to this coastal town.

title: Gene Tie to Male Violence Is Studied
description: Scientists have identified a tiny genetic defect that appears to predispose some men toward aggression, impulsiveness and violence, a discovery that is likely to rekindle the harsh debate over the causes of criminal and abnormal behavior.

title: Corrections
description: The caption yesterday with a photograph of Vice President Al Gore and Mayor David N. Dinkins listening to a speech misstated the circumstances. They were at the installation of the America-Israel Friendship Grove at Flushing Meadows Corona Park in Queens, not a meeting of the Jewish Community Relations Council. The caption also misidentified Abraham Hecht, the man sitting behind them. He is president of the Queens Jewish Community Council, not a member of the Jewish Community Relations Council.

title: Dickerson Is Finished
description: ERIC DICKERSON, the National Football League's second-leading career rusher, has decided to retire. "I know I'm not going to play again; I mean, that's obvious," Dickerson said from his California home Wednesday night.

title: Sports of The Times; The '93 Imperfect Classic
description: IF Don Larsen pitched a perfect game in the World Series, then the Blue Jays' 15-14 victory Wednesday night was the imperfect game. But they're equally memorable.

title: Somali Faction Leader Warns U.N. to Disarm Aidid, His Foe
description: The chief Somali rival to Gen. Mohammed Farah Aidid warned today that his faction could be forced to take up arms again if the United Nations did not press ahead in seeking to disarm General Aidid.

title: Body and Dreams Trampled, a Riot Victim Fights On
description: The verdicts in the Reginald O. Denny case are in, and this bruised city anticipates a new beginning. But for at least one victim of the mayhem at Florence and Normandie Avenues, who is now broke, sick and scared, the spiral of misery has no end.

title: U.S. Drops Test Plan at Bomb Waste Site
description: The Department of Energy abandoned plans today to put the first plutonium-contaminated bomb waste into underground storage in New Mexico to test the site's suitability. Instead, it will conduct laboratory tests of the project and seek further Federal review of its environmental merits.

title: Reassuring Eastern Europe, Christopher Praises Hungary's Reforms
description: Secretary of State Warren Christopher cast himself in the role of diplomatic booster today, praising Hungary's economic and political reforms in Budapest and signaling his staunch support for President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia.

title: Coleman Calls Off Talks Until End of the Season
description: Derrick Coleman, the Nets' power forward, said yesterday that he was breaking off contract negotiations with the club and would put them off until the end of the season.

title: Herbert Osborne, 96, Ex-Banking Executive
description: Herbert J. Osborne, an executive for more than 40 years with the bank that grew into the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, died on Wednesday at a nursing home in Mountainside, N.J. He was 96 and had lived in Summit, N.J., most of his life.

title: UNITED AIRLINES CONSIDERS SHIFTING ENGINE REPAIR WORK
description: United Airlines is considering moving the jet engine repair work at its operations in the San Francisco area as a way to cut costs. "That is one of the options we are looking at," a United Airlines spokesman, Anthony T. Molinaro, said. Of 19,000 United employees in the San Francisco area, 11,000 work at maintenance operations at San Francisco International Airport and Oakland International Airport. United is evaluating shifting responsibility for jet engine maintenance to the General Electric Company, Pratt & Whitney, Ryder System Inc. and other companies, The San Francisco Chronicle reported yesterday.

title: Reviews/Film; Drifting With a $20 Bill Among the Human Tides
description: Endre Bohem wrote his draft of the screenplay for "Twenty Bucks" in 1935, but it wound up on the shelf. It sat there for nearly 50 years, at which point Mr. Bohem turned the idea over to Leslie Bohem, his son. In the early 80's the younger Mr. Bohem was a bass player for the rock band Sparks, but he was in the market for a career change. So he picked up the abandoned script and made it the basis for Keva Rosenfeld's first dramatic feature, a charming, offbeat tale shaped whimsically by the hand of fate.

title: News Flash: McGaughey Loses One
description: A young filly named Shapely Scrapper not only won the 71st running of the Astarita Stakes at Aqueduct yesterday but also outran one of the prize young fillies trained by Shug McGaughey, and that's becoming a mark of distinction these days.

title: Legal Memo; Juries Lose a Lofty Aura In Glare of Instant Fame
description: In its day, no court proceeding was more celebrated or scrutinized than the espionage trial of Ethel and Julius Rosenberg. But the 12 ordinary New Yorkers who convicted the Rosenbergs blended back quietly and quickly into obscurity. Though any enterprising reporter could have tracked them down, years passed before they were ever debriefed.

title: Kasparov, Drawing, Wins the Match
description: Gary Kasparov won his world championship match with Nigel Short yesterday in London by making a draw in Game 20. He thus reaffirmed his ascendancy in chess, where for the moment he stands alone in his prime.

title: A Reluctant Parting With an Old Reliable; Competition Leads Goodwill Industries of Greater New York to Give Up Collection Bins
description: Goodwill Industries, which has relied for 40 years on charitable donations of used clothing to finance aid to the disabled, is reluctantly giving up its collection bins in the New York area.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The editors of Aufbau, the German language newspaper that served as the voice of the Jews who had escaped Nazism during World War II, could think of no better way to pay homage to their guiding light, Manfred George, than with his own words.

title: A.T.&T. and MCI Show Increases in Net Income
description: The nation's two largest long-distance carriers yesterday reported higher third-quarter earnings and revenues. But the MCI Communications Corporation, the No. 2 carrier, reported a stronger performance than A.T.& T., and analysts increased their earnings projections for MCI.

title: Restaurants
description: When you walk into the room, your first impression is warmth and laughter. All around the restaurant, people are huddled over grills, drinking and talking and gesturing wildly as great gusts of fragrant steam go billowing toward the ceiling. Men scurry about with buckets of blazing coals, replenishing the fires at each table, and waitresses walk past bearing trays laden with vegetables as bright as jewels. The air smells of smoke and sugar and chilies and garlic, and the whole atmosphere is so inviting that you are irresistibly drawn into the center of the room.

title: CATERPILLAR INC. (N)
description: Powered by an 18 percent jump in domestic sales, Caterpillar Inc. reported yesterday that its third-quarter net income from operations was $96 million, far ahead of the year-earlier quarter's $5 million and the $50 million to $65 million generally projected on Wall Street.

title: No Headline
description: "If he does not return, we'll take matters into our own hands. I don't mean on land; I mean the ocean. It's our only way out." -- COLBERT ST. VIL, building a boat on the Haitian coast, in referring to President Jean-Bertrand Aristide. [ A1:3. ]

title: No Settlement, or Deadline, For G.M. and Auto Workers
description: The delicate labor contract negotiations between the United Automobile Workers union, which is trying to preserve an industrywide pact, and the General Motors Corporation, which is pressing for concessions, have reached a strangely upbeat standoff with no agreement but also no strike deadline.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: A Joint Adventure?

title: Du Pont Reassigns Lycra Fiber Account
description: E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company said yesterday that it had consolidated its worldwide Lycra fiber account at Young & Rubicam Inc. in New York, which has handled the Spandex brand in South America. Billings were previously estimated at $20 million, but were estimated yesterday at $40 million.

title: Schools Pension Money Diverted, Auditors Say
description: The director of a Board of Education pension fund improperly diverted up to $1.2 million a year from a special fund to pay for the agency's operating expenses, including meals, air fare, parking and hotel costs, according to a confidential management audit.

title: Bernard Smith, 70, Ex-District Attorney And State Legislator
description: Bernard C. Smith Sr., a former State Senator and District Attorney for Suffolk County, died on Tuesday at Kingston Hospital in Kingston, N.Y. He was 70 and lived in Northport, L.I.

title: Big Board's Open Positions on Short Sales Drop
