description: General Motors gave its car assembly plant in North Tarrytown, N.Y., a brief reprieve yesterday, saying it would continue operating as much as a year beyond its scheduled 1995 closing date.

title: Two Charged With Burying Newborn Alive
description: Two months after Urbelina Emiliano told her new husband that she was pregnant with another man's child, the couple took the newborn girl and buried her alive in a hole in their backyard, the Nassau County police said today.

title: Betz Laboratories Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a $ 4 million charge for work force reductions in both the quarter and 9 months, and the 9 months also included a gain of $ 900,000, or 3 cents a share, from cumulative effect of accounting changes.Betz Laboratories said its latest third quarter earnings were reduced by 1 cent a share for foreign currency translations and 2 cents a share for the increase in the federal tax rate.

title: CHRONICLE
description: There were so many journalists at a party for ELLEN GOODMAN, the Pulitzer Prize-winning syndicated columnist for The Boston Globe, on Monday evening that EDWIN DIAMOND, New York magazine's media critic, was moved to remark, "This is the way to have a party: a bunch of journalists standing around and talking in a bar."

title: German Ex-Police Chief Is Guilty in 1931 Murders
description: The longtime chief of East Germany's secret police, Erich Mielke, was convicted today of the 1931 murders of two police officers and was sentenced to six years in prison.

title: Police, Not Troops, in Washington
description: Bill Clinton was right to reject Mayor Sharon Pratt Kelly's request for the power to call out the National Guard in Washington D.C., to cope with the District's soaring murder rate. Congress, which is considering the option, would be wise to follow the President's example.

title: U.S. Says Chretien Will Not Undo Nafta
description: President Clinton and his aides said today that they did not expect that the Liberal Party's victory in Canadian elections would hurt the prospects for approval of the North American Free Trade Agreement or lead to renegotiation of the pact.

title: Make His Day? The Modern Does Just That for Eastwood the Director
description: One night long ago, 17-year-old Clint Eastwood and his friends traveled from Oakland to Los Angeles to hear a jazz concert. Along the way, they happened to see horses running wild near Sunset Boulevard. So they helped corral the horses for the animals' owner, who thanked them and went home. Too bad: that was Mr. Eastwood's only meeting with Howard Hawks, one of the directors he most admires. He cites Mr. Hawks, along with John Ford and Anthony Mann, as an influence on his own career.

title: Wolverine Tube reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
description: b-Included a one-time after-tax charge of $ 1,441,000 for the write-down of fixed assets related to aluminum operations and a charge of $ 1,768,000 from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting for postretirement benefits.c-Included an extraordinary loss of $ 4,163,000 from a charge on debt refinancing.

title: Consolidated Edison Co. of New York Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Medical Schools Alerted About Intern With a Prison Record
description: Officials of the University Hospital here are warning medical schools and teaching hospitals nationwide to be on the watch for an intern they dismissed this month after learning that he had served two years in prison for feeding ant poison to six paramedics in Illinois in 1985.

title: ANB Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Vanguard Cellular Systems (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a charge of $ 3,715,000 from unamortized bank fees associated with the company's previous credit facility.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: METRO DIGEST NEW YORK CITY CONTENTS OF BOMB PLOT TAPES REVEALED

title: China Makes Trade Pact for Americas Urgent; Rethink the Agreement
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge BYL>By Alan Truscott; A less than perfect defense is unraveled much as the lowly winkle is untwisted.
description: A humble shellfish much favored by London cockneys is the winkle, which can be coaxed from its convoluted home with the aid of a pin. The bridge winkle is an equally convoluted creature that can be brought into the daylight by a skillful declarer without a pin.

title: Electric Rates To Be Frozen By Authority
description: The New York State Power Authority, trying to repair its tattered public image and fight off competition from independent energy suppliers, said yesterday that it would freeze electricity rates for the next three years for its government customers in New York City and Westchester County, which could save them as much as $110 million.

title: Dataflex Corp.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CABLETRON SYSTEMS INC., Monterey, Calif., and Novell Inc., Provo, Utah, will introduce a new piece of computer networking equipment next week. No details were provided. STANDARD FEDERAL BANK, Troy, Mich., has signed a definitive agreement to acquire Central Holding Co., Mount Clemens, Mich., in a deal valued at $21.3 million.

title: Core Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net loss and after a loss from discontinued operations of $ 24,874,000 and a charge of $ 1,674,000 from an accounting adjustment.The company said earnings in the latest quarter and year both included a pretax gain of $ 500,000, or 3 cents a share, from settlement of litigation.Fiscal 1992's income from continuing operations of $ 180,000, or 2 cents a share, included $ 6.4 million, or 66 cents a share, write-off of intangibles and other non-recurring charges.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * Brazos River and Sabine River Authorities, Tex., have tentatively priced $158.5 million of tax-exempt collateralized pollution control revenue refunding bonds for a Texas Utilities Electric Company project through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Co. For $50 million of bonds due in 2022, which are insured by Ambac Indemnity Corp., the yield is 5.50 percent, while $75 million of bonds with the same maturity date are insured by Financial Security Assurance and priced to yield 5.55 percent. The remaining $33 million of bonds also with the same maturity are insured by Capital Market Assurance Corp. and priced to yield 5.60 percent. All insured bonds are rated triple-A by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and Standard & Poor's Corp. * Illinois Health Facilities Authority is selling $55.1 million of tax-exempt revenue bonds for Children's Memorial Hospital initially priced to yield a maximum 5.50 percent for an issue due in 2022 through Goldman, Sachs & Co. Serial bonds with shorter maturities were priced to yield from 3.05 percent in 1994 to 5.15 percent in 2007, with another bond due in 2013 priced to yield 5.40 percent. Because the bonds are insured by the Municipal Bond Investor's Assurance Corp., they are rated triple-A by Moody's and S.& P.

title: Interstate/Johnson Lane reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary tax benefit of $ 795,000 in the quarter and $ 3,997,000 in the year.c-Included an extraordinary tax benefit of $ 622,000 and $ 2,992,000 in the quarter and year, respectively.

title: USX-MARATHON GROUP (N)
description: The USX-Marathon Group, the oil and gas company, reported a 25 percent increase in third-quarter net income even though sales fell by $400 million, to $3 billion. Per-share earnings also rose 25 percent, to 10 cents from 8 cents in the corresponding period a year earlier.

title: Process of Linking Blast Debris Begins
description: In a turning point in the World Trade Center bombing case, prosecutors began presenting evidence yesterday in their effort to link the four men on trial with the many bits of twisted metal that has been brought before the jury over the last two weeks.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: International

title: R.H. Park, 83, Media Executive And Promoter of Duncan Hines
description: Roy Hampton Park, who built a media empire from a fortune he made in the food business, died on Monday night at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 83 and lived in Ithaca, N.Y., the base of his enterprise.

title: Managing Award Caps Baker's Rookie Season
description: Hours after a second member of his starting infield declared himself a free agent, the news took a turn for the better for Dusty Baker yesterday. The Baseball Writers Association of America announced that Baker, rookie manager of the San Francisco Giants, had been voted National League manager of the year in his first year as a manager in the major leagues.

title: Amcast Industrial reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After a charge of $ 3,942,000 from an accounting adjustment.c-Net loss and after a loss from discontinued operations of $ 15,802,000 in the quarter and $ 17,827,000 in the year.

title: Jets Against the Giants: Big Names, Big Games
description: The Jets and Giants have met so rarely, only six times since 1970, that their matchups are more a novelty than a rivalry.

title: Review/Television; Shoe Pinches Other Foot In a Series
description: How's this for a quandary? Your dearest friend has just moved into the White House, and here you are writing and producing a weekly series poking fun at politicians and other assorted nitwits on the Washington power circuit. What to do? Well, Linda Bloodworth-Thomason and Harry Thomason, top-of-the-list F.O.B.'s, don't fool around. Their "Hearts Afire" show, shifted by CBS from Mondays to Wednesdays, has been yanked out of its now awkward Washington setting and plunked down in a small town in Middle America. The state is not identified, but Bubbas in good standing can cast a knowing wink in the direction of Arkansas.

title: Armstrong World Industries Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss and included after-tax restructuring charges of $ 95.2 million in the quarter and $ 99.5 million in the 9 months. The 9 months also included a charge of $ 172,600,000 from an accounting adjustment.Year-ago results are restated to include the effects of the comapny's adoption of SFAS 106, 109 and 112.

title: Personal Health
description: ALL too often, women who complain of chronic debilitating symptoms for which doctors can find no physical cause or cure are dismissed as crackpots or hypochondriacs and are shunted off to psychotherapists for treatment of ailments assumed to be emotionally based.

title: MTV Names Presidents
description: MTV named two women yesterday to be joint presidents of the cable channel. Sara Levinson, 43, will be the MTV president and business director, and Judy McGrath, 41, will be its president and creative director. Both women were promoted from executive vice president positions. The promotions were announced by Tom Freston, the chairman and chief executive of MTV Networks, a division of Viacom International that owns VH-1 and Nickelodeon, in addition to MTV. The position of MTV president has been vacant for the last few years.

title: AMC Entertainment Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss and included charge of about $ 6.5 million for early extinguishment of debt in the quarter and the 6 months included gain of $ 9.7 million on sale of assests and charge of about $ 6.5 million on early extinguishment of debt.

title: 'Anything Goes' Houston May Go the Limit: Zoning
description: In many American cities, the mental image of the landscape is set by something the city has. Seattle has the Space Needle, St. Louis has the Gateway Arch. Here in Houston, though, even with its famed Astrodome, the urban geography has long been noted for what this city does not have: any zoning regulations whatsoever.

title: Fidelity New York reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a charge of $ 245,000 for the closing of the last New York City branch in both the quarter and 9 months.c-Included an extraordinary tax credit of $ 2,440,000 and $ 3,873,000 in the quarter and 9 months, respectively.Year-ago per share results are not meaningful, as the bank converted from mutual to stock ownership on May 3, 1993.Year-ago results are not meaningful because the bank was operating under an Office of Thrift Supervision capital plan during 1992.

title: Term-Limit Foes Counterattack
description: As supporters of the referendum that would limit New York City's elected officials to two four-year terms continued an expensive television blitz, opponents began their counterattack yesterday with a rally of union and civic leaders on the steps of City Hall.

title: Hadareni Journal; Death Is a Neighbor, and the Gypsies Are Terrified
description: Charred remains of houses burned to the ground line the Transylvanian road between Tirgu Mures and Cluj, which passes through this village. They are visible reminders of the violence that ravaged it one month ago.

title: Anthony Industries Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago results are restated to reflect 5 percent stock dividend paid in December 1992.

title: Ex-Official Is Convicted In HUD Scandal of 80's
description: The executive assistant to former Housing Secretary Samuel R. Pierce Jr., who found herself at the center of the influence-peddling scandal during the Reagan Administration, was convicted today of 12 felony counts of defrauding the Government, taking a bribe and lying to Congress.

title: The (Russian) Empire Strikes Back
description: The hand-wringing that accompanied Boris Yeltsin's crushing of the neo-fascist uprising in Moscow this month deflected attention from an issue that really should keep U.S. policymakers awake nights: Russia's attempt to resurrect an exclusive sphere of influence across the former Soviet Union.

title: Massive Cabdriver Protest Of 35 Killings Snarls Traffic
description: Thousands of cabdrivers, angered and frightened by the seemingly unceasing string of killings and violent crimes against New York taxi drivers, formed a massive caravan and staged a mobile demonstration in Manhattan yesterday, bringing traffic to a standstill and creating chaos on several midtown blocks during the early evening rush hour.

title: French in Algeria Cautioned
description: The Foreign Ministry suggested today that many of the estimated 76,000 French citizens living in Algeria should consider taking the opportunity of a week's school vacation to leave the North African country after the kidnapping of three French diplomats and the killing last month of two French technicians.

title:
Caribbean Property;
Office Space At a Premium In San Juan
description: The newly constructed McConnell Valdes building is finding new occupants under an ownership format that is a departure in San Juan's financial district, the largest in the Caribbean.

title: Interactive TV Pact for Sony
description: Interactive Network Inc. said today that it had named the Sony Pictures Entertainment TV Group as the first Hollywood producer for its subscription-based interactive television service.

title: Graham Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a $ 648,000 pretax gain from the sale of real estate in the U.K. Before the gain and taxes, the company had an operating loss of $ 494,000, or 47 cents a share.c-Included a $ 5,484,000 pretax gain from the sale of real estate in the U.K. and a gain of $ 161,000 from changes in accounting principles. Before the gains and taxes, the company had an operating loss of $ 2,938,000, or $ 2.81 a share.

title: ALCOA JOINT VENTURE TO BUILD PLANT IN INDIA
description: The Aluminum Company of America said yesterday that it had signed a joint-venture agreement with the Associated Cement Company of Bombay, India, to manufacture alumina raw materials in India. Alcoa, of Pittsburgh, will own 60 percent of the venture, which will supply the refractory and ceramic industries in India. The new company will build a plant in Falta, West Bengal, by late 1994. Alcoa said the venture would be India's first domestic source of synthetic alumina materials, which are used in refractory products for the steel, petrochemicals, refining, fertilizer and cement industries. Alcoa will market the alumina products internationally and the venture will market Alcoa chemicals in India.

title: Washington Post Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 3
description: b-Included after-tax gain of $ 1.14 a share on the sale of the company's cable franchises in the United Kingdom, completed on Sept. 8, 1993 in the quarter and 9 months. The 9 months also included a one-time gain of $ 11.6 million, or 98 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of change in accounting principle for income taxes.

title: Food Notes
description: Discount Bread

title: Sharks Are Eating Cable TV Customers
description: To the Editor:

title: Auto Plant Closings in Japan
description: The Mazda Motor Corporation and the Nissan Motor Company said today that they would shut all or part of their operations for two days next month to reduce inventories and save money. Workers, however, will still get 90 percent of their pay for days they are idled.

title: Theater in Review
description: El Galan de la Telenovela (The Sexy Star of the Soap Opera) Gramercy Arts Theater 138 East 27th Street Gramercy Park By Diana Raznovich; directed by Rene Buch; production designer, Robert Weber Federico; production supervisor, Manuel Herrera; technical director, Rigoberto Obando; assistant to the director, Rene Sanchez. Presented by Repertorio Espanol, Gilberto Zaldivar, producer; Mr. Buch, artistic director. WITH: Ofelia Gonzalez, Ana Margarita Martinez-Casado and Ricardo Barber. With the voices of Lilia Veiga, Juan Villarreal and Rene Sanchez.

title: Bell Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $ 76,000 and a charge from an accounting adjustment of $ 830,000.

title: PRESIDENT TO LIMIT FEDERAL SUBSIDIES IN HEALTH PROGRAM
description: To control the cost of his proposal for universal health insurance coverage, President Clinton has modified it to limit Federal spending on subsidies for low-income workers, small businesses and early retirees, Administration officials and Congressional aides said today.

title: Rollins Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Reduced by 1 cent a share due to higher corporate income tax in both the quarter and 9 months.

title: Lawrence Kuskin, 92, Children's Fever Expert
description: Dr. Lawrence Kuskin, an authority on children's rheumatic fever, died on Thursday at St. Francis Hospital in Poughkeepsie. He was 92.

title: Edward Joseph Maude; Banker, 69
description: Edward Joseph Maude, a former chairman and chief executive of the United Mutual Savings Bank in Manhattan, died on Oct. 13 at his home in New Bern, N.C. He was 69 and had lived in Montclair, N.J., until 1987.

title: Wine Talk
description: IT was Christmas in London a few years back. Twenty or so Americans and a few British friends had gathered for dinner at a famous hotel.

title: Consumer Confidence Drops
description: The widely followed Conference Board consumer confidence index fell sharply this month, declining to 59.4 points in October from 63.8 in September. Although the business research group's survey rattled stock investors and knocked the dollar down, economists do not see it as a persuasive sign that consumers are about to retrench.

title: U.S. IN QUIET TALKS WITH NORTH KOREA
description: In unpublicized talks aimed at ending an impasse over international supervision of North Korea's nuclear program, United States and North Korean officials meeting in New York have discussed steps toward cancellation of war games conducted by United States and South Korean forces and the possibility of eventual American diplomatic recognition of the North, Government officials and private citizens say.

title: AT WORK WITH: Trip Hawkins; A Visionary On the Border Of Movies And Microchips
description: ON the day word got out that the Bell Atlantic phone company would buy the cable giant Tele-Communications Inc., offering a grand vista of a data superhighway coming to town around the turn of the century, a glimpse into that future was on display in a meeting room in a San Francisco hotel.

title: Northern Telecom Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included after-tax restructuring and other charges of $ 940 million.c-Net incomeYear-ago periods' results were restated.

title: Puzzle of Appointees
description: With a week before voters must choose between them, New York City's mayoral candidates -- Mayor David N. Dinkins and his challenger, Rudolph W. Giuliani -- steadfastly refuse to discuss appointees.

title: New Polish Premier Assumes His Office; Walesa Has Doubts
description: With a warning from President Lech Walesa not to squander the past four years of movement toward a market economy, Poland's new Prime Minister, the leader of a former Communist party, was sworn in today along with a 20-member Cabinet.

title: Christopher Praises Belarus on Nuclear Issue
description: Secretary of State Warren Christopher came to this capital of broad boulevards today and praised its leaders for taking "historic steps" to remove nuclear weapons from their territory.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Good Night for Lindros Eric Lindros capped a three-goal second period as the Philadelphia Flyers beat the Nordiques, 4-2, last night in Quebec. Josef Beranek scored his league-leading 10th goal and assisted on another as the Flyers won for the seventh time in nine games. Lindros was making his third visit to the Colisee since his trade to the Flyers, a deal prompted by his refusal to sign with the Nordiques after they selected him in the 1991 entry draft. (AP) Jets 5, Panthers 2: Nelson Emerson and Keith Tkachuk scored first-period short-handed goals to lead Winnipeg past Florida in Miami. (AP) Blackhawks 9, Blues 2: Jeremy Roenick, Kevin Todd and Joe Murphy each scored twice, and Ed Belfour stopped 24 shots as host Chicago beat St. Louis for its third consecutive victory. (AP) TENNIS Courier Tops Wheaton Jim Courier beat David Wheaton, 7-5, 5-7, 6-3, last night in his opening match in the $1.65 million Stockholm Open. Michael Stich came from a set down to beat Mikael Pernfors. Stich, a German seeded No. 4, won the second-round match, 6-7 (3-7), 7-5, 6-2, on the Globe Arena's carpet. Third-seeded Boris Becker, who also plays well in Sweden and is a three-time Stockholm Open champion, beat Aaron Krickstein, 7-5, 6-4, in his opening match. Becker will next play MaliVai Washington. (AP) BOXING Pazienza Wins Decision Vinny Pazienza went to 4-0 since returning to the ring after breaking his neck when he took a unanimous decision over Robbie Sims in a 10-rounder at the Foxwoods High Stakes Bingo and Casino last night in Ledyard, Conn. Pazienza, 30, improved his record to 35-5. The Cranston, R.I., native broke his neck in a car accident in November 1991. He began his comeback in December 1992 with a victory over Luis Santana of New York. (AP)

title: Greyhound Lines Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a charge of $ 690,000 for an accounting change.

title: National Commerce Bancorp (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Per share earnings were adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split declared Sept. 9.

title: Brush Wellman reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 3
Review/Music; Students and Stars With Joint Impact
description: The finale of the Fiddlefest concert at Carnegie Hall on Monday evening was a reminder that the professional music world, the parade of stars and contenders who tread the boards night after night, is only part of the picture. After two hours of performances by famous classical, jazz and country fiddlers, 14 students from East Harlem public schools shared music stands with their starry elders and collaborated on a heartwarming performance of a Bach concerto movement.

title: 2 Gang Leaders in Sarajevo Face Crackdown in Bosnia
description: After months of growing lawlessness and black-marketeering that had eroded morale here almost as much as Serbian bombardments, the Bosnian Government began a crackdown today on two reputed gangsters within its own armed forces, laying siege to their headquarters.

title: CLINTON SEES WAYS TO REDUCE COSTS
description: Reaching into a grab bag of leftover campaign promises, President Clinton today introduced legislation and signed executive orders that he said would cut the deficit, curb crime and streamline government.

title: Little Garnets Of Flavor, Pomegranates Are the Jewels Of Autumn
description: BY anyone's count, the pomegranate is really just a mess of seeds. Of course, there is the seductive exterior, the rosy, leathery skin and the rather corpulent body, topped off by what looks like a little crown of withered leaves. There is a certain appealingly sturdy quality to the fruit; it is large and commanding, a leader in the fall fruit bin. Socially, perfectly acceptable, but ultimately, can you take it anywhere?

title: Review/Dance; Waging War With Death, Loss and the Forces of Fate
description: The dancing was vigorous, yet the overall mood was elegiac when the Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company performed on Saturday night at the Joyce Theater. Mr. Jones concerned himself with mortality and loss, and showed people trying to master their fates, but finding themselves controlled by forces beyond them.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: THE scene: the Metropolitan Opera, a sold-out performance of "Tosca," starring Placido Domingo.

title: Man in the News; Canadian With Mandate: Joseph Jacques Jean Chretien
description: The Conservative Party derided him as "yesterday's man" because he faithfully served Prime Ministers Lester B. Pearson, Pierre Elliott Trudeau and John N. Turner.

title: Florio and Whitman Focus on Basic Themes
description: It is exactly one week before Election Day and the polls show the race for Governor could be close. But Christine Todd Whitman and Gov. Jim Florio could be vacationing in Hawaii for all the stress the two candidates are showing on the campaign trail.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Stratus Computer Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 3
description: b-Included a pretax charge of $ 3.8 million which reduced net income by 13 cents a share, to cover the costs of a 6 percent work force reduction to be completed in the fourth quarter.

title: CTS Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 3
description: b-After a charge of $ 4,614,000 from an accounting adjustment.

title: International Specialty Products Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included nonrecurring retroactive income tax provision of $ 2.9 million, or 3 cents a share, in both the quarter and 9 months.c-After a charge of $ 7,100,000 from cumulative effect of change in accounting for postretirement benefits.

title: A New Television Series Becomes Foreman's Food for Thought
description: "Lunch!" says the director, and the entire set is in a footrace for finger food.

title: Conciliatory Giuliani Asks City to 'Come Together'
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday struck a chord of conciliation, cooperation and hope. Moving away from the bitterness and vituperation that have dominated the mayoral race for months, he urged New Yorkers to "come together," to cast aside blind party loyalties, racial and ethnic stereotypes and labels of all kinds to usher in a "new era" in New York City politics.

title: Invacare Corp.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Visa International Is Set To Replace Top Officer
description: The longtime chief executive of Visa International, Charles Russell, will announce today that he is resigning from the credit card organization. He will be replaced by Edmund P. Jensen, a vice chairman of U.S. Bancorp in Portland, Ore.

title: Chicago & North Western Holdings Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $ 10,800,000 in both the quarter and 9 months.c-Net incomed-Net loss and after an extraordinary charge of $ 91,000,000 from from a recapitalization and a charge of $ 2,600,000 from an accounting adjustment.Latest quarter's income from continuing operations of $ 6,200,000, or 14 cents a share, reflects a $ 14 million pretax charge from the impact of midwest flooding, an iron ore miners' strike and a special charge for employee reductions and relocations.

title: In America; Violence in The State Of Denial
description: Altaf Quershi was a 27-year-old immigrant from Pakistan who was chasing the American dream in a yellow taxicab. He drove the cab to hustle money for his education, carrying passengers over the pocked and rutted roads of the outer boroughs, hoping eventually to go to law school, or maybe the journalism school at Columbia.

title: United Dominion Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 1,228,000, or 3 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 4,316,000, or 12 cents a share, in the 9 months.c-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 1,198,000, or 3 cents a share, and $ 2,427,000, or 7 cents a share, in the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and the 9 months also included a pretax gain of $ 2.1 million on the sale of a business.Preferred-share dividends were $ 1,211,000 in the latest quarter, $ 3,760,000 in the latest 9 months, $ 1,324,000 in the year-ago quarter, and $ 4,151,000 in the year-ago 9 months.

title: Cordis Corp.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 10,115,000, or 70 cents a share, from an accounting adjustment.

title: F.D.A. SAID TO RESUME REVIEWS OF PAR DRUGS
description: Shares of Pharmaceutical Resources Inc. surged 22 percent yesterday after the company said the Food and Drug Administration would resume reviewing new drug applications from the company's Par Pharmaceutical unit. The F.D.A. stopped reviewing applications of Par, a maker of generic drugs, about four years ago as a result of an investigation that led to the conviction of Par officers for falsifying research data and bribing F.D.A. officials to win Federal drug approvals.

title: Chemed Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 687,000, or 7 cents a share, and a gain of $ 1,651,000, or 17 cents a share, from adoption of FASB 109.c-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 1,400,000, or 14 cents a share, in both the quarter and 9 months.Latest 9 months' income from continuing operations of $ 13,100,000, or $ 1.34 a share, included gains of $ 3,865,000, or 40 cents a share, from sales of portions of the company's investment in Exel Ltd. and other investments.Year-ago 9 months' income from continuing operations of $ 11,069,000, or $ 1.13 a share, included gains of $ 1,899,000, or 20 cents a share, from sales of portions of the company's investment in Exel Ltd. and other investments.

title: Shopping and Banking With a $200 Telephone
description: The telephone industry, in its fever pitch to build the information superhighway, is hoping to get more mileage from the phone itself.

title: Hurdle for Mideast Talks: The Palestinians Abroad
description: For many Palestinians, it is one of the more emotion-laden among the many complex issues that have landed on the Israel-P.L.O. bargaining table. For many Israelis, it is a human time bomb waiting to blow up in their faces.

title: Harold Rome, 85, Writer of Socially Pointed Songs
description: Harold J. Rome, who wrote witty, often socially pointed songs for Broadway shows that included "Pins and Needles," "Wish You Were Here," "Fanny," "Destry Rides Again" and "I Can Get It for You Wholesale," died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 85.

title: Buffets Inc.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 6
description: b-Reflects charge of $ 183,000 from the increase in the corporate federal tax rate.

title: Cairo Gunman Kills 2 Americans and Frenchman
description: A gunman opened fire on foreign tourists in a luxury Cairo hotel late last night, killing two American engineers and a Frenchman and injuring three other foreigners, officials from the United States Embassy and the Interior Ministry said early this morning.

title: The Endless War
description: Bloody upheavals in Moscow and the Republic of Georgia have given outsiders a new appreciation of the lethal forces at play in the struggle to redefine the former Soviet Union. But such insights scarcely qualify as news for the people of Nagorno-Karabakh, where thousands have died in fighting since Soviet rule there began to collapse in 1988.

title: Debut of Railroad's Shares Roils Tokyo Stock Market
description: After months of careful planning by the Government, the stock market debut on Tuesday of JR East, the huge Government-controlled railroad, set off a speculative frenzy that nearly paralyzed the Tokyo Stock Exchange on Tuesday and again on Wednesday morning, while sending the overall market tumbling.

title: Short Sales Outstanding Set a Record on Nasdaq
description: While there are several reasons to sell a stock short, the usual one is to bet that its price will decline, enabling a speculator to buy it back later for less than its sale price. Some share prices have tumbled, providing profits for short-sellers, but more have risen. The Nasdaq composite index rose to a record high earlier this month.

title: Golden Poultry Co. (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 25
description: b-Included a tax credit of $ 166,000, or 1 cent a share, from the adoption of SFAS No. 109.

title: Chevron Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

title: A Bizarre Drug Tested in the Hope of Helping Drug Addicts
description: DRIVEN by a deep sense of frustration that efforts to cure drug addiction are going nowhere, Federal researchers are testing a bizarre, mind- altering drug called ibogaine as a possible new treatment for cocaine and heroin addiction.

title: Review/Music; Mystical, Minimal And Now Onstage
description: The most famous piece of art music in the world today is probably Henryk Gorecki's Symphony No. 3. It has been recorded at least three times, and on Elektra/Nonesuch the 17-year-old, hourlong work for soprano and orchestra has been the No. 1 classical album for much of this year, on British and American charts. It has also made its way onto the pop charts, and has sold over half a million copies. But this piece and others by this Polish composer have not been a major presence on the concert scene until now.

title: Islanders End Slump With a Scoring Flurry
description: The Islanders burst out of their slump tonight and ended a five-game streak without winning with an impressive 7-0 thumping of the Los Angeles Kings at the Coliseum. The Kings, a Stanley Cup finalist last spring, put on a lethargic display, losing for the third consecutive time on a grueling road trip.

title: The Zen of Cooking, Or Joy When Time Allows
description: FOR nearly a century, the food-processing industry has waged war against its bane, home cooking. Canned goods and cake mixes, frozen foods and microwavable meals are foot soldiers in the battle against domestic drudgery, ready to break the shackles that tie Mr. and Ms. Everyday to the home stove and to deliver everyone to a life of pleasurable leisure and ease.

Giuliani would be measuring the drapes at City Hall -- and both may well prove true after next Tuesday's election, which all the polls suggest remains too close to call.

Review/Film; East Berlin in Gloom-Tinted Glasses
description: Some of the most telling moments in Peter Kahane's film "The Architects," a somber, finely drawn portrait of life in East Berlin in the final days of the Communist regime, are long panning shots of the city's ugly, factorylike public housing. Shot from moving cars, these views of block after block of anonymous rectangular buildings evoke a joyless environment in which the imagination is systematically stifled and where people live in a state of chronic, low-grade depression.

title: Paramount Suitor Blasts Bell Atlantic's Cable Bid

title: Review/Pop; Earthy Epiphanies On Love, Love, Love, By Luther Vandross
description: A recurrent tableau in Luther Vandross's new show has him alone on the stage, singing nearly unaccompanied. He's a solitary figure talking about transcendental love, the sort of love that saves lives, at least in songs. These are pure Vandross moments. His voice quivers in the silence. Everything he does signifies passion. He sings of lost love so plaintively that one wants to help the poor guy. Then the audience goes crazy: the process of empathy banishes loss completely, and love returns, made as real as a stolen kiss.

Among its features are a two-story dome topped with an observatory, two curvilinear staircases and a cast-iron railing, an etched-glass solarium, a three-room master suite and seven additional bedrooms.

title: TRIZEC AGREES TO SELL ITS RETIREMENT HOMES UNIT
description: The Trizec Corporation of Calgary, Alberta, agreed yesterday to sell its Central Park Lodges unit to Integrated Health Services Inc. Under the terms of the sale, Integrated Health Services, based in Owings Mills, Md., will pay $86 million, repay about $50 million in intercompany loans and assume $46 million of debt. Trizec said the sale was expected to close on Dec. 21. Central Park Lodges operates 39 retirement and nursing homes in Florida, Texas and Pennsylvania. Shares of Integrated Health Services rose $1.125, to $27.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.

description: Perhaps the most interesting television advertisement in New Jersey's crowded political season has little to do with the main attraction, the race for governor.

title: Economic Scene; The earnings gap grows, within professions and among them.
description: IN 1990 the average take-home of the partners in the law firm of Cravath, Swaine & Moore exceeded the total salaries of all nine members of the Supreme Court. Chief executives of the Fortune 500 did pretty well that year, too, netting an average of $1.4 million -- roughly 40 times the average for public school teachers.

title: Suspect Killed And 3 Officers Are Wounded
description: A 63-year-old man shot and wounded two police detectives who came to his home in Queens yesterday, then hid with a neighbor whom he took hostage for four hours, and finally shot a third officer who tried to block his escape. The officer returned fire, the police said, and shot the man to death.

title: Aristide Has Long Posed Problem for Vatican
description: While Vatican officials have not publicly gone as far as the C.I.A. in trying to brand the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide as mentally unstable, the deposed Haitian leader has long been seen by Roman Catholic leaders as an advocate of political violence, a charge also leveled against him by the C.I.A. in Washington.

title: Everett's Starting String Will End at 87
description: T. J. RUBLEY will start at quarterback Sunday for the Los Angeles Rams at San Francisco, ending a string of 87 consecutive starts by JIM EVERETT.

title: CRSS Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss and after a charge of $ 8,575,000 from an accounting adjustment.CRSS Inc. said its year-ago quarter included severance and related charges associated with a cost-reduction program completed in fiscal 1993.

title: Walter F. Sheehan, 83, A Retired Headmaster
description: Walter F. Sheehan, headmaster for 25 years of the Canterbury School in New Milford, Conn., died on Saturday at the Candlewood Valley Care Center in New Milford. He was 83.

title: Nassau Candidates Dispute County's Present and Future
description: In a debate that presented two starkly different visions of Nassau County, the Democratic and Republican candidates for county executive clashed today over the state of the county's economy and who should be blamed for high taxes.

title: Meanwhile in Serbia, a Quiet Genocide Goes On; Attacks by Muslims
description: To the Editor:

title: New St. Louis Ownership Group Is the Subject of Expansion Intrigue
description: The ownership group from Charlotte, N.C., the only winner so far in the National Football League's expansion derby, went home happy today. The losers also went home, unsure whether they still have a chance for the remaining new franchise, unsure whether the owners of the N.F.L.'s 28 clubs have already settled on St. Louis.

title: Pop and Jazz in Review
description: Brian Setzer and His OrchestraThe Supper Club

title: Central Park Reservoir to Stay as Is; New York Is to Leave It Undeveloped, Home to Waterfowl
description: The Dinkins administration has come up with a plan for the soon-to-close Central Park Reservoir, which holds one billion gallons of water, cools Manhattan's muggy core on superheated days and has invisibly fed the island's thirst for 131 years.

title: Centerior Energy reports earnings for 12mo to Sept 30
description: Latest share earnings included 61-cent charge from the workforce reduction program.

title: Expert Tells Of Markings On Van Parts At Blast Trial
description: There was an insurance company expert on automobile theft, experts on Michelin tires, and another expert on Bridgestone tires as prosecutors in the World Trade Center trial inched ever closer yesterday to identifying the van that they say was used in the Feb. 26 bomb attack.

title: Aflac Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a gain from an accounting adjustment of $ 11,400,000, or 11 cents a share.Share earnings and shares outstanding have been adjusted to reflect the 5-for-4 stock split paid on June 15, 1993.

title: Control Data Systems Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
description: b-Net loss and after pretax expense of $ 14,900,000 from change in valuation of spare parts inventory and pretax restructuring expense of $ 114,900,000.

title: Emcon (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Richter Earns a Shot at Canadiens
description: This is what Mike Keenan expects of his goaltenders: Play as well or better as the man in the opposite net, and then let your teammates take care of the rest.

title: U.S. Returns 15 Refugees
description: A United States Coast Guard cutter docked here today and unloaded 15 Haitian refugees in front of a crowd of armed civilians similar to the one that confronted an American military vessel two weeks ago.

title: Yeltsin Moves to Give Farm Lands to the Farmers
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin signed a decree today to allow farm workers to own and dispose of land freely. Thus he lowered a major hurdle to reforming the Soviet system of large state or collective farms.

title: Westchester County Elections
description: The two most powerful positions in Westchester County are hotly contested this year. Here are The Times's endorsements.

title: Lawyer Ties Man's Coma to Intern Stony Brook Dismissed
description: A 60-year-old man lapsed into a coma this month after he was sedated by an intern who was convicted of poisoning six people in 1985, the patient's lawyer said today.

title: Clear Channel Communications Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BORDEN PREPARING A REVAMPING PLAN
description: Borden Inc. said yesterday that it would announce a plan for an extensive overhaul, including divestments, by the end of the year. As part of its reorganization plan, Borden, which has posted a string of earnings disappointments, said it would shed some businesses and focus its resources on businesses that have a No. 1 or strong No. 2 position in the market. The food giant did not say which businesses it would shed.

title: Essay; Ally for Sale
description: She's intelligent, personable and articulate. Turkey's new Prime Minister, Tansu Ciller, an economist trained in the United States, wowed 'em on television and in private meetings here on her recent visit to America.

title: Block Cutler's Role in a Retrial, U.S. Urges
description: Federal prosecutors have moved to prevent Bruce Cutler, who used to be John Gotti's lawyer, from representing an accused Gambino crime family member on drug smuggling and racketeering charges.

title: Polish Farmer Takes Power, Taciturn as Ever
description: The contrast was striking as the polished but battle-weary Prime Minister handed power to a fresh-faced, reserved young man who struggled to find the right words.

title: Utility Bonds Hit by Rating Threat
description: Utility bonds took a beating yesterday after the Standard & Poor's Corporation announced that several companies were facing a credit rating downgrading and that the outlook for a third of the industry was being switched from stable to negative.

title: ANHEUSER-BUSCH COS. (N)
description: Despite increases in sales and market share for its beer products, the Anheuser-Busch Companies said yesterday that it lost $75 million in the third quarter after a restructuring charge of $565 million.

title: Hasbro to Sponsor A Cartoon Marathon
description: Turner Entertainment Networks said yesterday that Hasbro Inc. had agreed to become the sole sponsor of an international cartoon marathon -- 84 hours of programming -- on six Turner cable television networks, including WTBS, the Cartoon Network and TNT.

title: Boston Scientific Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Sensible Changes in the Health Plan
description: The health care bill that President Clinton delivered to Capitol Hill yesterday preserves the major features, good and bad, of the plan leaked to the press last month. The modifications are mostly minor, generally for the good and almost always designed to mollify a boisterous constituency. The release of the 1,300-page legislation is less important for its new details than for the fact that Congress can finally begin serious debate.

title: Postmaster, Beware, A Revolt Is Brewing
description: To the Editor:

title: General Is Said to Take Blame for Raid in Somalia
description: The commander of the failed Oct. 3 Ranger raid in Somalia has sent a letter to President Clinton taking responsibility for the mission, Administration officials said today.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Oct. 20, about plans by Pfizer Inc., the American Cyanamid Company and the Upjohn Company to eliminate a total of 7,000 jobs, misstated the number of manufacturing jobs lost in New York City since 1987. It is about 94,000, not 270,000.

title: Beryl E. Menon, 50, Journalist and Traveler
description: Beryl Emmer Menon, a journalist who edited the staff newspaper of Unicef, the United Nations relief organization, and who traveled and wrote widely in India and the Himalayas, died on Oct. 19 at her home in Manhattan. She was 50.

title: U.N.'s Grim Documentation At a Massacre Site in Bosnia
description: Until about 3 P.M. on Saturday, this village in the mountains of central Bosnia was a haven from the war that has engulfed much of this former Yugoslav republic, a cluster of houses high in a valley where the immediate concern of the Muslim inhabitants was gathering in beets, potatoes and squashes before the snows begin.

title: Santa Anas: Weather Worthy of Satan
description: Some people think the Santa Ana winds are named for Satan, from the Spanish word 'satanas.' They are not, but as millions of Southern Californians know, they easily could be.

title: John W. Moxon, 87, Steel Company Head
description: John W. Moxon, the former president of the Carpenter Steel Corporation of Reading, Pa., who was active in philanthropy, local government and community agencies, died on Sunday at his home in Oley, Pa. He was 87.

title: Researchers Admit Study With Drugs Had No O.K.
description: Prominent cancer researchers in New York have confessed to doing what many researchers have often wanted to do -- skip the Government paperwork needed to carry out drug experiments on human beings and go ahead without telling the Government or getting any of the necessary medical approvals.

title: Dinkins Seeks Hispanic Forgiveness
description: In a close mayoral election in which the Hispanic vote is considered crucial, David N. Dinkins is trying to mend fences after four years in which many of his Hispanic supporters say they felt undervalued and ignored.

title: Badger Paper Mills Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a pretax charge of $ 3.4 million related to the planned closure of the company's Dayton Division.c-Net lossd-Included a charge of $ 649,000 from a change in accounting principle.

title: Earl D. Hanson, 66, Wesleyan Professor And Science Leader
description: Earl D. Hanson, the Fisk Professor of Natural Sciences at Wesleyan University and an academic leader who emphasized the role of ethics in science, died on Tuesday after he had a heart attack in his campus office in Middletown, Conn. He was 66.

title: Hopes Fade For Debate In Big Race
description: Five days before the election, a standoff between Mayor David N. Dinkins and Rudolph W. Giuliani is making it increasingly likely that for the first time in at least 32 years there will be no televised debates between the principal contenders for mayor of New York City, only sound bites passing in the air.

title: Care Enterprises Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Majors Is Marching In, Minus His Old Horses
description: The last time Johnny Majors brought a team into Giants Stadium was Aug. 30, 1987, for the Kickoff Classic against Iowa.

title: Dataware Technologies (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Clinton for New Station
description: President Clinton is to announce today that he supports a proposal to transform the General Post Office at 33d Street and Eighth Avenue into a new Amtrak railroad hub for New York City, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan said last night.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball American League

title: Durable-Goods Orders Up for a Second Month
description: More evidence that the economy is shifting into higher gear emerged today as orders for long-lived factory goods posted a second straight increase in September, the first back-to-back advance in nearly a year.

title: 'Paradise Lost' Inspires Meditation on Vampires
description: Whenever a film maker has a huge hit to his credit, plotting the next step calls for special care. So Neil Jordan, the writer and director of "The Crying Game," is making his next move under the influence of the poet John Milton and the mogul David Geffen, though not necessarily in that order.

title: Tapes Depict Proposal to Thwart Bomb Used in Trade Center Blast
description: Law-enforcement officials were told that terrorists were building a bomb that was eventually used to blow up the World Trade Center, and they planned to thwart the plotters by secretly substituting harmless powder for the explosives, an informer said after the blast.

title: Critic's Notebook; Up-to-Date Promotion For the Biblical 'Cave'
description: "The Cave" has come and gone at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, but rest assured: music lovers have not seen the last of it. This merger of video and music by Beryl Korot and Steve Reich has already cut its swath through one American city and four in Europe. Brussels is coming up, and hotly in pursuit are Lisbon, Rome, Turin, Hong Kong, again London and various points in Japan. The composer and image maker have explained the moment and the meaning of "The Cave" at the Whitney Museum and will do the same on Nov. 9 at the Jewish Museum. A recording will be released next year on Nonesuch, and a single-channel video is being vigorously pursued despite the costs.

title: NEW CANADA PARTY SURGES IN ELECTION
description: A new political party has come storming out of the Canadian west, riding some of the same gusts that Ross Perot rode as an independent candidate in last year's American Presidential election.

title: William Kochiyama, Japanese Advocate, 72
description: William Kochiyama, a founder of the Asian Community Center and an advocate of reparations for American citizens of Japanese descent who were interned in World War II, died on Monday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center of heart failure. He was 72 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Putting a Camcorder to Practical Use
description: WHEN I whip out a camcorder and tape my aunt Marge's visit next spring, it won't be just for a memento. It will also be to capture her 50-odd years of gardening expertise to help me get started as a suburbanite. Sure, I could take notes of what she has to say about which plants to prune, to fertilize and to weed out, but a video close-up of a leaf with her voice-over will be a lot more helpful than my rough sketches and hastily scribbled notes.

title: Now Hear This: More Free Software
description: Computer Associates, which created a marketing stir in June with its offer of free personal finance software, is back for an encore. This time it's free tax software.

title: J.C. Penney Push Features New Slogan
description: The J. C. Penney Company is getting ready for holiday shopping by introducing a $60 million marketing push featuring a new slogan, "J. C. Penney. Doing it right."

title: Louisville Accepts Bid to Liberty Bowl
description: Louisville, which has a 7-1 record but limited access to bowl games because it is not part of a coalition that guarantees its members a New Year's Day game, accepted a bid yesterday to be the home team in this year's Liberty Bowl in Memphis.

title: Candidates Debate Budget in Battle for Westchester Executive
description: As the race for Westchester County Executive enters its final days, even a strictly controlled League of Women Voters forum can turn into a rough-and-tumble debate, the incumbent, Andrew P. O'Rourke, and his challenger, state Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky, showed here tonight.

title: Super Bowl Set For '97 and '98
description: The National Football League's club owners ended a two-day meeting today by awarding the 1997 Super Bowl game to New Orleans and the 1998 Super Bowl to San Diego.

title: QVC Is Considering Its Next Move
description: The QVC Network took its fight for Paramount Communications Inc. directly to shareholders yesterday, but almost as soon as it did, it was considering replacing its $9.6 billion bid with a better one.

title: Whitman's Tactics Could Still Decide Race in New Jersey
description: Christine Todd Whitman is getting lots of advice these days. Whether she will take it is another question; the candidate has ignored plenty of back-seat driving so far this year.

title: Christopher, in Latvia, Presses for Russian Pullout
description: Secretary of State Warren Christopher used a visit to this medieval port city today to press Moscow to withdraw its Soviet-era troops.

title: CLINTON'S HEALTH PLAN: The Overview; CONGRESS IS GIVEN CLINTON PROPOSAL FOR HEALTH CARE
description: After nine months of brainstorming and politicking, President Clinton delivered to Congress today a 240,000-word proposal for universal health insurance. It represents the most complex, detailed legislative blueprint devised by any President.

title: Gunman Mentally Ill, Egypt Says
description: Egyptian Interior Ministry officials said today that the man who shot and killed two American engineers and a French jurist here Tuesday night was mentally ill and that they had no evidence linking him to any Muslim militant groups.

title: MICHELIN TELLS UNIONS ITS JOB CUTS ARE ON TARGET
description: Michelin, the French company that is the largest tire maker in the world, told unions yesterday that it was on target to cut 2,950 jobs in France by the end of 1994. Unions in the United States, meanwhile, are balking at job-cutting at Michelin's money-losing Uniroyal Goodrich subsidiary, while in Spain negotiations with unions to cut about 2,500 jobs are bogged down, union officials said. The layoffs are part of Michelin's plan to cut operating expenses by 3.5 billion francs, about $600 million, a year by 1995.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption on Oct. 18, about Rudolph W. Giuliani's visit with the leader of the Bobover Hasidic sect, misspelled the Grand Rabbi's name in some copies. He is Solomon Halberstam.

title: Dorothy Borg, 91, East Asia Scholar At Columbia, Dies
description: Dr. Dorothy Borg, a Columbia University historian of United States-East Asian relations, died last Thursday at her home in Manhattan. She was 91.

title: Next Mayor Faces Expensive Challenges on Basic Services and Repairs
description: The Series So Far

title: Small Effect Anticipated In Altered Shelter Rules
description: Dinkins administration officials said yesterday that they believed their new policy of turning away families who seek shelter but do not really need it would affect only a small number of people.

title: Trading in New Japanese Rail Stock is Halted on Deluge of Sell Orders
description: A day after a buying frenzy for the newly listed shares of the East Japan Railway Company created turmoil on the Tokyo Stock Exchange, investors reversed course and thrashed the stock with waves of selling today that choked the exchange's computers and left the overall market depressed.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: ABOUT a month ago, Keira Walsh, 11, was stopped by a classmate on her way to school in Madison, Wis. "He grabbed my bike so that I couldn't move," she recalled. "He cursed at me. He kept yelling in my ear. Someone had said something that he didn't like, and he was taking it out on other people."

title: Books of The Times; Why Bush Bombed (in the Election, Not the War)
description: Hell of a Ride Backstage at the White House Follies, 1989-1993 By John Podhoretz 249 pages. Simon & Schuster. $21.

title: Piazza Chosen N.L. Rookie of Year
description: He was chosen in the 62d round of the 1988 amateur draft, after 1,388 players were picked ahead of him. But yesterday Mike Piazza was way ahead of the field after being chosen unanimously as the National League rookie of the year by the Baseball Writers Association of America.

title: Christiana Cos.  reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Bottle Redemption Center Needs More Support
description: To the Editor:

title: Cablevision To Purchase TV Systems
description: Cablevision Systems Corporation, which is considered a prime target in the takeover wave sweeping the communications industry, turned the tables on speculators yesterday and announced that it would buy an additional three cable television systems for $463 million.

title: Fear of Immigrants Sounds an Old Theme
description: To the Editor:

title: Steuben? Is That You?
description: THEY are the parallel to what the fashion industry calls "bridge lines" -- more functional and affordable wares, often designed with a twist to appeal to a younger audience. And the new products prove that even Steuben, the venerable 90-year-old glass company best known for its status-conscious bowls ($310 to $12,000), crystal snails ($210) and apples ($340), is looking in a different direction.

title: ELECTRONIC DATA SYSTEMS CORP. (N)
description: The Electronic Data Systems Corporation said yesterday that the 14.5 percent gain in its third-quarter net income, to $191.6 million, was the result of slightly higher revenue and cost reductions.

title: Cuomo Is Questioning Dismissal Of Head of Staten Island College
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said yesterday that he had intervened in an effort to end the dispute over the dismissal of Dr. Edmond L. Volpe, the president of the College of Staten Island, by the trustees of the City University of New York.

title: Raymond Kravis, 92, Oil and Gas Consultant
description: Raymond Field Kravis, a philanthropist and oil and gas consultant whose clients included Joseph P. Kennedy and Chase Bank, died on Monday at his home in West Palm Beach, Fla. He was 92 and lived in Tulsa, Okla., and West Palm Beach.

title: Sports of The Times; The N.F.L. Should Go To 32 Now
description: ONE of football's oldest jokes involves the new coach who growls that his players are returning to fundamentals.

title: HOUSE PROUD
description: IF Kathy Kennedy has a design for living, it's living with design: 1920's and 30's vintage-print photography by Josef Sudek, Karl Struss, Andre Kertesz, and 40's and 50's furniture by Florence and Hans Knoll, George Nelson and others.

title: A Dangerous Year
description: Americans have waited a very long time for a national health insurance program. So what difference does it make that between President Clinton's address to Congress on health care reform in September and his presentation of the plan yesterday, the timetable for completing the phase-in has slipped from 1997 to 1998? After all, it is nearly half a century since President Harry S. Truman called for universal health insurance.

title: In British Hong Kong, Memorable Monikers
description: Britain's most indelible influence on the Chinese who populate this colony may be in name only. From the Hong Kong bank clerk with Canine on her name tag to the insurance broker who calls herself Neon, many Hong Kong Chinese choose English names.

title: Review/Dance; Movement and Sound In Fluid Collaboration
description: The works that Wichern/Wolfson Dance and Music offered on Sunday night at the Merce Cunningham Studio occasionally went awry. That didn't seriously matter. The group remained worth watching and listening to because of the close collaborative harmony between its directors, Lynn Wichern, a choreographer, and David Wolfson, a composer.

title: Book on Nazi Murder Industry Stirs French Storm
description: Jean-Claude Pressac, the local pharmacist in this village near Paris, is a singular man. Contrarian by nature, he is as obsessed by the technical specifications of Nazi gas chambers as others are by the human suffering that took place within them.

title: Thanks to an odd pitch, the Craftsman hammer can join Lenny (Nails) Dykstra in card collections.
description: "TRADE ya two Lenny Dykstras and a Joe Carter for a Sears Craftsman screwdriver and two Coca-Cola Santa Clauses!"

title: We Waste Half of Our Street Lighting
description: To the Editor:

title: Stand Up to Senator Packwood
description: Nearly a year after publicly confessing to wrongful sexual conduct over many years, Senator Bob Packwood clings to his office and party position, forcing a laborious ethics investigation. Now, in a new display of shamelessness, he has brought the Senate Ethics Committee to an impasse, insisting on his right to define and contain the committee's inquiry.

title: In Itty-Bitty Toys, Mega-Mega-Profits
description: WHAT a guy Mighty Max is. He slays the awesome Doom Dragon, melts the evil Ice Alien and thwarts the Mad Nuke Ranger's plan to blow up the world. All of this from a pencil-thin hero who, in his T-shirt and baseball cap, stands less than one inch tall.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ALLIED SIGNAL INC., Morristown, N.J., and the Dutch chemical concern Akzo have combined their European nylon carpet fiber businesses into one company that will be managed by Allied Signal. ESKIMO PIE CORP., Richmond, signed a letter of intent to acquire a privately held manufacturer of frozen dairy dessert products. It did not disclose the identity of the other company or the proposed purchase price.

title: A Tricky Business, but Often a Treat
description: Marc Beige has circles under his eyes this time of year, and he doesn't bother wearing a tie. Running a hand through his rumpled hair, he misses a strand of yellow thread caught there. As if he didn't have enough to worry about, he just got a last-minute order for 500 Arabian princess costumes.

title: Connecticut Biotech Concern Names Chief
description: The Neurogen Corporation said yesterday that it was naming Harry H. Penner Jr., an experienced pharmaceutical deal maker, as president and chief executive, effective Dec. 1.

title: PRUDENTIAL INSURANCE TO DROP SOME FLORIDA POLICIES
description: The Prudential Property and Casualty Insurance Company will be allowed to drop coverage for about 13,000 Florida homeowners, or 10 percent of its total in the state, as a result of an administrative order issued today, the Florida Insurance Department said. The order lets Prudential reduce its exposure in the state by a third, to $1 billion from $1.5 billion, a spokeswoman for Prudential said. All the policy cancellations will be in the Miami and Fort Lauderdale areas, she said. Prudential had sought to drop 34,000 customers.

title: U.S. MAY TIGHTEN EMBARGO ON HAITI
description: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 --

title: Bell Sports Corp.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
description: b-Included a gain of $ 700,000, or 11 cents a share, from an accounting adjustment.

title: GARDEN Q. & A.
description: Autumn Crafts

title: Back Bay Restaurant Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 26
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 42,000, or 1 cent a share, in the quarter and $ 152,000, or 4 cents a share, in the 9 months.c-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 70,000, or 3 cents a share, and $ 310,000, or 9 cents a share, in the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

description: Companies

title: Banta Corp.(NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding are adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split, effective April 30.

title: Cilcorp Inc. reports earnings for 12mo to Sept 30
AMP Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Belfast Observes a Day of Funerals and Fear
description: A solitary bagpiper marched ahead of a hearse, playing an Irish lament. The coffin inside was draped with the Irish tricolor, topped with gloves and a black beret, signifying that the deceased was a member of the banned Irish Republican Army. Not that anyone in Belfast didn't already know.

title: Gun Bill Is Unsnagged, Making Passage More Likely
description: A pivotal House chairman who opposes a bill that would enhance controls on the sale of handguns has nonetheless made its enactment far more likely by agreeing to strip it from a much larger anticrime package that has been stalled in Congress for almost two years.

title: Red Skies, Then Blackened Homes
description: Cinders shot across the Pacific Coast Highway in this exclusive beach town, and black smoke roiled across the surf as a fast-moving brush fire consumed more than 150 homes, along with their broad patios, swimming pools and tennis courts.

title: Bridge; In the production of books on championship matches, quality is up and speed down.
description: In one area of bridge, quality has gone way up and speed has gone way down. That area is the production of championship books. Six decades ago, Ely Culbertson published a book on an international match in England within a few days of its conclusion. He dictated notes on some of the deals between sessions, but his efforts were brief and often inaccurate.

title: The Past Gets in the Way of Big East's Future
description: Uh-oh. A new logo. You know what that means.

title: Catholic Bishops Proposing Active U.S. Policy Abroad
description: The nation's Roman Catholic bishops have drafted a statement calling for a more active American role on the world stage, including supporting the United Nations, expanding foreign aid and, when necessary, using military force for interventions intended to rescue people from hunger or mass violence.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-21 ATROCITIES IN A BOSNIAN VILLAGE Until Saturday, the quiet mountain village of Stupni Do had escaped the horrors of the Bosnian war. Now, many of its Muslim inhabitants have been slaughtered and the village has become a symbol of the nation's madness. A1

title: Frank Gehry's Courage
description: To The Home Section:

title: CLINTON'S HEALTH PLAN: Financing the Plan; The Difference 6 Weeks Make: Revisions in Costs
description: The biggest differences between the health care plan President Clinton invited Congress to ponder six weeks ago and the bill he offered today are financial, reflecting an effort to avoid a repetition of the huge cost increases that have characterized Medicare since its was enacted in 1965.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: New Music Consort Manhattan School of Music

title: C-MAC Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 3
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: CLINTON'S HEALTH PLAN: The Scene; At Capitol, Selling Health Proposals as Cure-Alls
description: It was a battle of medicine shows, Democratic and Republican, each led by cane-brandishing barkers of surpassing skill, each hawking competing cure-alls to crowds that, at least today, were in thrall.

title: 4 Win Columbia Prizes In Latin America News
description: Two journalists from the United States, one from Chile and a Caribbean news service have won the 1993 Maria Moors Cabot Prizes from Columbia University for contributions to inter-American understanding and the freedom of information. The prizes are to be awarded tonight.

title: Dow Drops 7.83 Points, Closing at 3,664.66
description: The economic news was encouraging yesterday, but investors apparently needed a little more convincing. They sent confused signals in a fragmented stock market, bidding up small companies while shunning some industrial powerhouses that might be expected to profit from a spurt in the recovery.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Costa Upsets Sampras in Sweden Carlos Costa upset Pete Sampras, the world's No. 1 player, last night, 7-6 (7-1), 2-6, 6-1, in the second round of the $1.65 million Stockholm Open. Sampras had seven double faults against Costa, a Spaniard ranked 30th in the world, who pounded 11 aces. In other matches, Stefan Edberg beat Swedish countryman Henrik Holm, 7-5, 6-1, in a serve-and-volley duel; Anders Jarryd dropped No. 7 Andrei Medvedev of Ukraine, 6-1, 4-6, 6-0. (AP) HOCKEY Drake Leads Detroit Past Los Angeles Detroit snapped the Los Angeles Kings' four-game winning streak at Joe Louis Arena as Dallas Drake had two goals and an assist in the Red Wings' 8-3 home victory last night. Drake's goals sparked a four-goal outburst in the second period for the Red Wings, who fought back from a 2-0 deficit. (AP)

title: Associates Corp. of North America reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $ 10,000,000 from cumulative charge from changes in accounting methods for income taxes and postretirement benefits.Associates Corp. of North America, part of the Financial Services Group of Ford Motor Co., said its consumer finance operation was led by receivables growth in both real estate-secured lending and personal loans; it said it also had significant growth in credit card receivables.

title: The Virtual Office Becomes Reality
description: IN the back of Peggy Roswell's 1992 Nissan Pathfinder sits a cardboard box full of family photos and other personal items that once decorated her office at Chiat/Day, the advertising agency that gave the world Apple's legendary "1984" Macintosh commercial and the Energizer bunny.

title: 7 Cases: What the White House Says
description: President Clinton yesterday submitted his health care legislation to Congress, accompanied by a report to the country summarizing the proposal. A series of hypothetical examples outline the current and projected costs of insurance coverage for a number of families or individuals in varying circumstances. Here are excerpts from the report, with White House's description and cost estimates. TWO-PARENT FAMILY YEARLY COST TO FAMILY NOW: Mary Sampson manages a small law office in San Jose, California. She makes $35,000 a year. Her husband, a minister, makes $30,000 a year. Today, they get their coverage through Mary's employer, who pays half their premium. They pay $2,940 a year, 8 percent of her salary, for their health care premiums alone, not including co-payments and deductibles. CLINTON PLAN: Assuming they choose an average-priced plan, the premium for Mary Sampson and her husband will be around $872 a year, or $73 a month. They could choose a higher cost plan, which would cost them more, or a 1ower cost plan, which would cost them less. COUPLE WITH PRE-EXISTING CONDITIONS NOW: Dennis and Barbara Rutherford, who live in Hannibal, Missouri have a combined income of $21,200. Dennis was laid off from his high paying job with a large manufacturing firm in late 1990. At that time, both Rutherfords lost their health care coverage. They have been turned down for other coverage because of preexisting conditions -- Dennis' high blood pressure and Barbara's history of breast cancer. Since then, they have been unable to afford the $9,000 a year ($750 a month) premium offered by the only plan that will accept

title: Chretien Says He Wants Changes in Trade Accord
description: Fresh from the stunning triumph of his Liberal party in Canada's general elections, Prime Minister-designate Jean Chretien said today that he wants changes in the North American Free Trade Agreement and may not implement the pact without them.

title: Dinkins Uplift, Giuliani Grit: 2 Advertising Schools Battle
description: David N. Dinkins opened his television advertising campaign with a "Heartbeat of America"-style commercial complete with rousing music. Rudolph W. Giuliani began with a grainy, low-key ad that looked as if it had absorbed its grittiness from the streets of New York.

title: Bonnett to Announce Another Comeback
description: NEIL BONNETT, who suffered a serious head injury in a 1990 wreck and then crashed again in a comeback bid this year, plans to drive in five races during the 1994 Nascar Winston Cup season.

title: New Haiti Road Could Be Anti-Embargo Lifeline
description: If most of Haiti lies almost dormant under the squeeze of international sanctions, the heavily laden trucks lumbering through this little border town make it a bustling exception.

title: BMC Software (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Pisa Journal; The Leaning Tower Loses a Tiny Bit of Its Tilt
description: It might be termed a triumph of physics and engineering over time and gravity. It might also be called something of an eyesore. But, however it is appraised, the gray 400-ton mass of lead ingots stacked at the base of the leaning tower of Pisa has achieved its goal: the tower has not, so far, toppled over.

title: Dole Food Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 9
description: b-Included charge of $ 2.5 million related to net deferred tax liability stemming from the higher U.S. corporate income tax rates in both the quarter and 9 months, and the 9 months also included $ 30,853,000 pretax gain from sale of 18 percent of common stock of a unit.c-After a charge of $ 49,492,000 from change in accounting for postretirement benefits.

title: Dudley's Blazer Contract Gets Final Approval
description: It took a favorable ruling by an arbitrator, three favorable rulings by a special master and one very favorable 30-page opinion by a Federal judge, but Chris Dudley has finally been cleared to pursue his potentially highly lucrative career with the Portland Trail Blazers.

title: Datascope (NMS) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Market Place; ICN Pharmaceuticals offers a double bet for investors.
description: INVESTING in ICN Pharmaceuticals Inc., currently the object of a proxy struggle between its incumbent management and Rafi M. Khan, a California stockbroker, is sort of like betting the daily double at the local race track. As where horses (or dogs) are concerned, the gamble does not pay off unless the bettor correctly picks the winners of two consecutive races.

title: Daily News Backs Giuliani
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday won the endorsement of the editorial page of The Daily News, his first from a major daily newspaper. Mayor David N. Dinkins got the support of the editorial page of the city's leading Spanish-language newspaper, El Diario-La Prensa.

title: Merck Plans Stock-Option Gift for Staff
description: Merck & Company, the world's largest drug maker, said yesterday that it would give each of its 37,000 employees an option to buy 300 shares of Merck's common stock at $32.50 a share. The stock could not be purchased until Oct. 20, 1998.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 21 about the Federal Government's decision to withdraw Pell grant assistance from 20 religious schools in New York State misstated the affiliations of some of the schools. While many are associated with the Satmar and Lubavitch Hasidic groups, some are associated with other Hasidic and Orthodox Jewish organizations.

title: Check the Oil, and the Octane
description: THEY'RE called Supreme, Super, Plus and Ultimate, and their advertisements suggest they'll help your car move with the smoothness and power of a jungle cat. But are premium-grade, high-octane gasolines worth the premium price?

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * AIM Management Group Inc., Houston, the mutual fund investment company, is selling $110 million of 9 percent senior unsecured notes due in 2003 at 100 through Merrill Lynch and Citicorp Securities. The debt is redeemable in five years and is rated Ba2 by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and BB by the Standard & Poor's Corp.

title: Play Down Differences
description: To The Home Section:

title: Borden Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss and the 9 months included a charge of $ 229,000,000 from an accounting adjustment.The year-ago quarter and 9 months both included an after-tax restructuring charge of $ 450 million.

title: At First, Frank Thomas Keeps On Succeeding
description: A day after he agreed to a four-year contract extension worth a guaranteed $29 million, Frank Thomas of the Chicago White Sox yesterday received the best average ranking at any position in baseball's ranking statistics.

title: Allied Signal Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss, which was after a net charge of $ 1,247,000,000, which included a $ 148 million accounting charge from the adoption of SFAS 109, and a $ 1,099,000,000 charge from the adoption of SFAS 106.The company said in the fourth quarter of 1992 it adopted Financial Accounting Standards Board Statement Nos. 106 and 109 effective as of Jan. 1, 1992. The 1992 numbers have been restated to include both the ongoing and cumulative effects of the accounting changes.Sales represented net sales.

title: Pop and Jazz in Review
description: Jimmie Dale Gilmore The Ballroom 247 West 28th Street Chelsea Through tonight

title: IPALCO ABANDONS ATTEMPT TO STOP UTILITY MERGER
description: Ipalco Enterprises Inc., based in Indianapolis, said yesterday that it had ended its attempts to derail a $29.1 billion merger between PSI Resources Inc. and the Cincinnati Gas and Electric Company. The three electric utilities agreed to drop lawsuits and not interfere in each other's operations for five years. In August, Ipalco abandoned a hostile tender offer to acquire PSI and derail the merger, but had kept open options to solicit proxies from the utilities.

title: Bombay Co.
description: Shares of the Bombay Company, a furniture retailer based in Fort Worth, rebounded yesterday after slumping in recent weeks. Analysts attributed the earlier decline to investors' cashing in on gains in the stock, which had been performing well because of the company's strong earnings.

title: Giants' Revived Defense Catches Carolina's Eye
description: Although former Washington Coach Joe Gibbs seems to be the leading candidate to coach the Carolina Panthers, the expansion team is covering all the bases during its search.
