description: In a traffic-choked town of short tempers and tall fines, it is a classic confrontation: The tow truck driver has just hooked an illegally parked car and is about to pull away. The hapless motorist runs up, moaning excuses, pleading for pity. The tow truck driver is unbending. Anger boils over, maybe violence.

title: Smith Barney Forces Out Ball
description: George L. Ball, the former head of Prudential-Bache Securities, has been forced out of his senior post at Smith Barney Shearson and is being investigated by Federal regulators for his role in the unfolding scandal at his former firm, Wall Street executives and people involved in the case said yesterday.

title: Thomas Fortuin, 48, Lawyer and Officer At Paramount Films
description: Thomas Mark Fortuin, a senior vice president of Paramount Pictures, died on Monday at Hoag Memorial Hospital Presbyterian in Newport Beach, Calif. He was 48 and lived in Laguna Beach, Calif.

title: Bonilla Is Available, If the Price Is Right
description: Trade Bobby Bonilla? It's an interesting proposition. It would be a great gamble. The Mets won't rule it out. And New York won't collapse in outrage if it happens.

title: CBS Cancels a Series 2 Days After Premiere
description: CBS bombarded the nation with promotional ads for its series "South of Sunset" for two weeks during the baseball playoffs and World Series, and the viewers apparently decided they had seen enough. In one of the fastest cancellations in television history, CBS waited just two days after the premiere of "South of Sunset" before declaring it dead on arrival.

title: SHIFT ON CAMERAS BY NORTH KOREANS
description: North Korea continues to block thorough inspections of suspected nuclear-weapons sites, but will allow the resumption of routine maintenance of surveillance cameras, international atomic-energy officials and diplomats said today.

title: Teachers Union Acts Shamefully to Mayor; Not Race Alone
description: To the Editor:

title: New Jersey NOW Divides on Endorsement
description: To the Editor:

title: Michael Now Knows He's Boss's Favorite
description: The agonizing wait about his future is over. Even if he does not know the details yet, Gene Michael's contract as general manager of the Yankees will soon be renewed for two years and he will even receive a raise. George Steinbrenner revealed the decision yesterday.

title: Californians Set For More Wind And New Blazes
description: Fire crews braced for new troubles today as weather forecasters predicted new Santa Ana winds starting tonight. But they reported substantial progress in containing or dousing most of the major wildfires in Southern California.

title: David M. Bick, 51, Expert in Real Estate
description: David M. Bick, president of Manhattan Capital Partners Inc. and an expert in real-estate investment and restructuring, died on Monday in Stamford Hospital in Connecticut. He was 51 and lived in Stamford.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 19 about the Hamptons International Film Festival misstated the role of Darryl Macdonald, its artistic director, in the founding of the Seattle Film Festival. He was a co-founder of the Seattle festival with Dan Ireland, not its sole founder, and they were co-directors of the festival from 1975 to 1986. Mr. Ireland remains an associate director of the festival and vice president of the board.

title: Business Digest
description: Companies

title: Observer; Now Perhaps To Begin
description: You get the impression the Clintons wish somebody -- anybody -- would step in and take this health-care thing off their hands. The press's polite way of saying this is that both President and Mrs. Clinton have "signaled flexibility."

title: Review/Pop; Australians With Roots Both Celtic And Gothic
description: Dead Can Dance may be the ultimate cult band of a certain somber type. The group, formed in Melbourne, Australia, in the early 1980's by Brendan Perry and Lisa Gerrard, has released six albums on 4AD, a London pop label specializing in music aswirl with a heavy Gothic atmosphere. And in concert at Town Hall, where the sextet sold out two shows on Wednesday and Thursday, the spectral mood of its music was reinforced by an artful, low-key theatricality. Thursday's concert also drew an intensely devout, ethereal-looking audience, with many people wearing black.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Leon Albert Williams Baritone Merkin Concert Hall

title: Durufle Organ Recital
description: Marie-Madeleine Durufle, an organist and the widow of the composer Maurice Durufle, is to play works by Bach, Franck, Vierne, Liszt and Durufle in a recital on Nov. 21 at 3 P.M. at the Church of the Ascension, Fifth Avenue at 10th Street in Greenwich Village. It will be Mrs. Durufle's first New York performance since a retrospective of her husband's works in 1989. Tickets are $10 to $25. Information: (212) 254-8553.

title: Jury Rules in Favor of Lockhart's Widow
description: A jury yesterday awarded $15.7 million to the widow of Carl (Spider) Lockhart, a former New York Giants defensive back, agreeing with her contention that doctors had failed to diagnose her husband's cancer when he complained about it in 1979.

title: Sherrard Will Miss Rest of Season
description: The Giants put wide receiver Mike Sherrard on the injured reserve list today, meaning he will miss the rest of the season, including the playoffs. Sherrard, who fractured his hip two weeks ago against the Philadelphia Eagles, is expected to remain on crutches for at least another six weeks and probably won't participate in any football-related activities until mid-January.

title: Penn State Can Keep Coalition Contented
description: As Penn State football fans continue to adjust to the subtleties of life in the Big Ten Conference (Let's see: If we beat Ohio State, and Michigan beats Wisconsin. . . . ), they have some company. The coach is figuring the possibilities, too.

title: The Running Man: Johnson Craves Role
description: With the Jets looking to control the clock and take some of the steam out of the Giants' defensive front on Sunday, this would be a perfect time for Coach Bruce Coslet to turn running back Johnny Johnson loose.

title: Ireland and Britain Offer Plan for I.R.A. Talks
description: The Prime Ministers of Britain and Ireland conferred today in Brussels on Northern Ireland and issued a statement promising that "new doors could open" for peace talks on the British province if the Irish Republican Army ended its campaign of violence.

title: Cost Curbs Help Macy Cut Losses
description: R. H. Macy & Company, which operates the Macy's, Bullock's and I. Magnin store chains, tripled its cash flow in September by keeping a tight rein on expenses, according to documents filed in United States Bankruptcy Court yesterday.

title: Back From the Edge; Promotion and Vindication for Officer Who Stood Alone
description: For years he wondered if he was the only cop fighting corruption. His superior officers shunted him aside. And when the Mollen Commission was established, he worried that he was being set up to take the fall for the Police Department's failure to police itself.

title: Advice for a Fraction of the Price of a Personalized Plan
description: Can't afford a financial planner? With planners' bills often reaching thousands of dollars, the problem is hardly rare. Luckily, alternatives exist.

title:
Review/Pop;
A Rapper Of Ideas Explores a Live Forum
description: Ice Cube is known for his intense style of "gangsta" rap music, but he provided only a few moments of it at the Palladium on Thursday night. Gangsta rap is fierce and complex when it questions and explores the idea of gangsterism as a means of vengeance and one of the few outlets for black male power. With the albums "AmeriKKKa's Most Wanted" and "Kill at Will," Ice Cube has been successful in investigating these ideas. But his set at the Palladium -- which came with his new album, "Lethal Injection," about to be released -- was flat with nonchalance. The fury he conveys on his albums was all but nonexistent.

title: With European Union's Arrival, Fears on Economy Cast a Shadow
description: This was to have been a day for the leaders of the European Community to celebrate finally the coming into effect of the Treaty on European Union. But instead, the summit meeting today was overshadowed by anxiety about growing unemployment and mounting welfare costs in their recession-stricken continent.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Ensemble Organum St. Mary the Virgin Church

title: Schott to Return Monday
description: Marge Schott, who was suspended from operating the Cincinnati Reds last March 1, will be permitted to resume control of the club Monday but will remain on probation for four months.

title: An Aggressive Prosecutor Who Plays to Win
description: In the restrained world of Federal prosecutors, where public demeanor usually ranges from guarded to grim and most traces of singularity are kept carefully hidden, Mary Jo White stands out like a pair of jeans in a closet full of pinstripes.

title: For Whitman, a Noisy Welcome to Florio's Turf
description: Christine Todd Whitman took her Republican campaign for governor into Camden, the heartland of Gov. Jim Florio's political fief, yesterday. The reception was raucous.

title: United's Talks With Unions Seen as Affecting Others
description: The outcome of the effort by United Airlines pilots' and machinists' unions to gain control of the carrier -- expected by industry analysts to either succeed or fail in the next few days -- will have broad implications for many carriers.

title: A First: Women in Ring
description: DALLAS MALLOY , 16, and HEATHER POYNER , 21, will meet in the ring at Edmonds (Wash.) Community College tonight in a boxing first. They will be the first women to compete in a sanctioned amateur boxing match in the United States. They will box three two-minute rounds. Malloy is a high school dropout from Bellingham, Wash. Poyner is a former high school cheerleader and volleyball player from Lynden, Wash. (AP)

title: Review/Pop; A Siberian Singer's Style Goes With New York Reeds
description: A typical traditional singer from Tuva, in southern Siberia, wouldn't arrive on stage with an LP cantilevered atop her hairdo, or wearing tights and ankle boots suitable for a Central Asian version of the B-52's. But Sainkho Namchylak, who performed on Thursday night at the Kitchen with Ned Rothenberg, no longer sticks to traditional music; she has joined the international improvising avant-garde. The concert was part of the Kitchen's Autumnmusic series, which ends tonight.

title: For County Executive in Nassau
description: Long Island's Nassau County is suffering the effects of a bloated, deeply entrenched political machine. Nassau's incumbent County Executive, the Republican-Conservative Thomas Gulotta, showed promise earlier in his tenure. He understood the intricacies of government and seemed to have a handle on the county budget.

title: Dummy Is on Ballot (He Isn't Seeking Office)
description: Along with school vouchers, sales taxes and city charter revisions, voters in San Francisco will decide next Tuesday whether to allow a veteran police officer to walk his beat with a ventriloquist's dummy.

title: Westchester Hospital Joins Health Group
description: United Hospital Medical Center, a 294-bed community hospital here, today affiliated with New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center in Manhattan as part of an alliance called the New York Hospital Care Network.

title: Q & A
description: Savings Bond Changes Q. Will the reduction in interest from 6 percent to 4 percent on series E savings bonds affect the original interest on a bond purchased 15 or more years ago? STANLEY LIKOFF, Bellerose, L.I. A. The original interest on your bond was not affected, but interest earned afterward may be. The change in the guaranteed minimum rate for United States Savings Bonds affects bonds bought after March 1 and bonds entering new extension periods after that date.

title: U.N. Extends Mission in Somalia For 2 Weeks as It Considers Shift
description: The United Nations mission in Somalia was extended today for two weeks while the Security Council decides whether to change its mandate by placing less emphasis on searching for Gen. Mohammed Farah Aidid, the Somali faction leader, and more emphasis on promoting political reconciliation among the warring clan-based factions.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Sahan Arzruni Pianist Merkin Concert Hall

title: Big Loss and Job Cuts for Amdahl
description: The Amdahl Corporation, the struggling mainframe computer manufacturer, reported a third-quarter loss today far in excess of analysts' already-pessimistic estimates.

title: Two Ways to Run a City; Mayoral Candidates Offer a Clear Choice Between Opposing Views of Government
description: Beyond the questions of competence and temperament, crime and race, the 1993 campaign for mayor of New York City has offered voters two candidates with sharply different philosophies of local government.

title: The Tunnel at the End of the Light
description: Once again we've got our priorities backward. And once again we are losing a precious hour of daylight at the very moment we need it most. For this we can thank the iron whim of Congress, which has decreed that clocks must leap forward in the brightening days of April and slip back to early darkness at the chill-end of October.

title: Let's Remember More Than the Maine
description: To the Editor:

title: U.N. Envoy Proposes Talks To End the Impasse in Haiti
description: The United Nations' envoy to Haiti called today for new talks with the nation's military leaders and renewed demands that they take steps to comply with a negotiated agreement restoring democracy in the next two days or face a rapid cutoff of trade.

title: Arabs End Objections To U.N. Seating Israel
description: Reflecting the improved political climate in the Middle East, the General Assembly agreed today to seat Israel at its session this year without an Arab challenge.

title: As Envoy to Tokyo, Mondale Takes a New Tack on Trade
description: When President Clinton named Walter F. Mondale as Ambassador to Japan earlier this year, Government officials here hoped for an updated version of their favorite envoy, Mike Mansfield, an elder statesman who rarely ventured into battles over trade.

title: Sports of The Times; Finding Way to Stop The Madness
description: THERE was no Midnight Madness at Duke University last night.

title: California's Experiment on Your Schools
description: From tofu to tax reform, California has traditionally been rich ground for cultivating ideas that eventually take root across the country. Now a ballot initiative intended to promote school choice here threatens to devastate our struggling public schools. Whether it wins or loses, it is the first battle in a campaign to promote similar mistakes across the country.

title: To Cigar Smokers, Proposed Tax Rise Is Latest Indignity
description: Cigar smokers have suffered the scorn of Americans who think their habit is vile. They have seen the steady disappearance of places where cigar smoking is acceptable. Now they are being told that the Federal Government wants to raise taxes on their cigars to help finance health care.

title: Mets Win Rights To Cuban Shortstop
description: The Mets, making the most out of being the worst, yesterday scored a rare and maybe remarkable triumph when they won the rights to a 21-year-old Cuban national team shortstop who defected to the United States during last summer's World University Games in Buffalo.

title: 3 Roars for Panthers
description: JERRY RICHARDSON vowed that the first thing he would do after he got a National Football League expansion team was thank all the people who helped him over the last 6 1/2 years.

title: Expect a Blushing Bride And a Breathless Groom
description: THE way Tom Young and Pam Kezios figure it, when they get married in two weeks in the middle of running the New York City Marathon, it should cost them about 10 or 12 minutes, but will be worth it.

title: Make Debates Mandatory
description: It looks as though, for the first time in more than 30 years, the principal candidates for mayor of New York City won't debate each other. Why? Because they can't agree on ground rules -- which really means that they don't want to agree, which also means they don't have high regard for what the voters need and want in the campaign.

title: Teachers Union Acts Shamefully to Mayor; Found Him Wanting
description: To the Editor:

title: Incentives of $31 Million Keep Kidder, Peabody in New York
description: In the latest high-priced deal to persuade a company not to move to the suburbs, Mayor David N. Dinkins said yesterday that Kidder, Peabody & Company, the Wall Street firm, had accepted $31 million in incentives and would move its headquarters from lower Manhattan to Rockefeller Center.

title: Not Exactly on the Air, Koch Airs His Views
description: In 1977, David Garth devised television commercials that helped make Edward I. Koch, a quirky Congressman from Greenwich Village, Mayor of New York. This year, he has figured out how to help Mr. Koch, now a one-man media conglomerate, help Rudolph W. Giuliani become Mayor, despite a clause in Mr. Koch's television contract that bars him from making political ads.

title: Westchester Sees Replay Of Challenge By Legislator
description: During six terms as an Assemblyman, Richard L. Brodsky developed a reputation as a zealous and often abrasive legislator.

title: Sightseeing Helicopter Makes Forced Landing in East River
description: It was a dream autumn day in Manhattan for four Paris tourists who set out yesterday afternoon on a short sightseeing ride by helicopter across the perfect blue sky.

title: Victim Disputes Cairo Attack Report
description: A man who was wounded in the attack that killed two American engineers and a French jurist in a Cairo hotel on Tuesday said the assailant was accompanied by someone who gave him instructions. The assertion contradicted official claims that the killer was acting alone.

title: Giuliani Ahead in Fund-Raising But Dinkins Says He'll Match It
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani had $900,000 more in the bank than Mayor David N. Dinkins earlier this week, according to campaign records filed last night. But officials of the Dinkins campaign said they are continuing to raise money and will be able to match resources with the Republican-Liberal candidate during the crucial last days of the mayoral campaign.

title: HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL REPORT
description: Scouting the Top Teams Here are scouting reports for this weekend's top high school football games in the Catholic High Schools Football League, the Public Schools Athletic League and selected Long Island and New Jersey games. Records are in parentheses. C.H.S.F.L. St. Anthony (6-1) at Chaminade (7-0), tomorrow

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Gotham Ensemble Merkin Concert Hall

title: Clinton Pushes Trade as New Frontier
description: Evoking the memories and language of John F. Kennedy to make a case for continued American involvement abroad, President Clinton said today that the United States cannot turn away from global economic commitments that he said constitute "our new frontier."

title: Methodist Leader Requests U.S. Curb on Human Cloning
description: A leader of the United Methodist Church has asked President Clinton to issue an executive order banning the cloning of human embryos at all federally financed institutions, the Religious News Service reported yesterday.

title: Judge Will Hear QVC Plea To Block Paramount Deal
description: A Delaware Chancery court judge has set aside Nov. 16 to consider QVC Network Inc.'s request to block the proposed merger of two media giants, Paramount Communications and Viacom Inc.

title: Confusion Over Policies Leads to Talk of Change
description: BUYERS of life insurance are entitled to descriptions of their policies and how they work. But the computer-generated tables supplied by insurance agents often show results that are just not realistic.

title: Back to Work as Coleman And Mahorn Rejoin Nets
description: Derrick Coleman had missed the Nets' last four preseason games because of wisdom-tooth extraction. Rick Mahorn hadn't played a game since bruising his kneecap in training camp. With the season opener next Friday, Coach Chuck Daly was glad that both players returned to practice today.

title: Fire Built for Warmth Spread Disaster
description: It had grown chilly before dawn on Wednesday, so Zhang Andres Huang, a 35-year-old transient living without shelter in a canyon near here, gathered some brush and lighted a fire. But there was a strong, dry wind that morning, and the fire spread out of control.

title: Two New Offerings for Varied Investing
description: Among a flood of new funds created to buy stock in utilities is Strong American Utilities Fund. Because utilities are mostly mature companies, paying high dividends, investors in these funds can reap a steady income while maintaining some exposure to the equities markets. The Strong fund has a 30-day yield of 5.46 percent. The fund, which can invest up to 25 percent of its portfolio in energy stocks as a hedge against rising inflation, is managed by W.H. Reaves & Company, Jersey City, which specializes in utilities stocks.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK CITY SHARP DIFFERENCE IN CANDIDATES' VIEWS Beyond the questions of competence and temperament, crime and race, the 1993 campaign for mayor of New York City has offered voters two candidates with sharply different philosophies of local government. Page 1.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: YACHT RACING Women's Entry Folds U.S. Women's Challenge, the only all-female entry in the competition, quit the Whitbread Round the World Race yesterday. A statement from the skipper, Nance Frank, cited lack of money as the reason for the yacht's withdrawal, although the entry was also said to have been troubled by disharmony among its 12-woman crew. On Thursday, the navigator, Adrienne Cahalan, of Australia, and the watch leader, Mikaela von Koskull of Finland, left the team. Their departure deprived Challenge of two of its most experienced sailors. Challenge finished 11th among the 14 yachts in the first leg, from Southampton, England, to Punta del Este, Uruguay. The boat was slowed by numerous technical problems, including a split mainsail and hardware and electronics failures. (AP)

title: Bulls Lose Williams
description: SCOTT WILLIAMS , who was expected to be the starting center for the Chicago Bulls, injured his knee in a practice session prior to the team's 110-94 victory over the 76ers last night and could be lost for the season.

title: Oh, You Know What I Meant
description: A bound document produced for holders of Paramount Communications stock last week came off the presses with a little glitch.

title: Olympians Pull Their Weight As Pros
description: Combined, Michael Carbajal and Oscar De La Hoya weigh less than Riddick Bowe.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball COMMISSIONER'S OFFICE -- Announced that Sal Artiaga has resigned as president of the Arizona Fall League. Promoted Steve Cobb, marketing director, to vice president of the AFL and announced he will assume full responsibility of all aspects of the league. Named Spec Richardson AFL consultant for the remainder of the season. Awarded negotiating rights for Reynaldo Ordonez, shortstop, to the New York Mets; Edilberto Oropesa, pitcher, to the Cincinnati Reds; and Jose Manuel Cuellar, catcher, to the Seattle Mariners. American League

title: Financial Planning: A Web of Credentials but No Regulations; The Search for Someone Trustworthy
description: When Thomas and Midge Bailey of Norcross, Ga., retired in the mid-1980's, they gave their financial planner clear instructions. "We told him we didn't want our retirement money in high-risk things," Mrs. Bailey said. "We wanted safe investments for the income."

title: Mayoral Agenda: A periodic report on key issues facing the election winner -- Education; Shaken School System Presents Major Challenges
description: From the day he takes office, the victor in Tuesday's mayoral election in New York City will have to take up the problems and the promise of the largest public school system in the country, in a major test of the future of public education in America.

title: Market Takes Breather As a Hectic Week Ends
description: A day after propelling blue-chip stocks to new highs, investors appeared to be groping for direction yesterday, sprinkling their orders here and there in a session of tentative trading.

title: In Burundi, Partition Can End the Bloodshed
description: To the Editor:

title: In Hollywood, a Former Vietnamese Star Rebuilds Her Career
description: For Kieu Chinh, acting out the most wrenching scene in the film "The Joy Luck Club" -- when her character has to embrace twin daughters one last time, then abandon them forever -- was reliving the greatest trauma of her own childhood.

title: My Mom, Bride of Dracula
description: Some kids pined all year for Christmas. Others longed for their birthdays. For me, the climax of the year was Halloween, and it was a family event.

title: MEDICAL CARE AMERICA REJECTS MERGER OFFER
description: Medical Care America Inc. said yesterday that it had rejected a $950 million merger offer from Surgical Care Affiliates Inc. and instructed its advisers to investigate its options. Surgical Care Affiliates made public its stock-swap offer on Monday. If combined, the companies would form the largest chain of surgical centers in the United States. Medical Care, based in Dallas, said its options included remaining independent, seeking strategic alliances, restructuring or combining with another business. Officials of Surgical Care, based in Nashville, were not immediately available for comment.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Another step forward for womankind? JEAN STAPLETON will play the role of Van Helsing, the vampire-hunting doctor in "Dracula," in a performance of the thriller on Monday at the Classic Stage Company, 136 East 13th Street in Greenwich Village. The show, an adaption by Mac Wellman of Bram Stoker's classic, is staged as a radio drama read from scripts.

title: MODERATE GROWTH IN SEESAW PATTERN SEEN FOR ECONOMY
description: The economy is showing more signs of life, but even third-quarter growth of 2.8 percent, announced on Thursday, is not likely to be the start of a prolonged period of smooth, strong expansion.

title: Tax Fairness for D.C.
description: With a population of nearly 600,000, the District of Columbia has more people than Vermont, Wyoming or Alaska. Yet its Mayor and City Council have limited power. And the District is denied a voting representative in the same Congress that rules on its affairs.

title: Brewer Revives a European Tradition in Texas
description: Pierre Celis is about to prove you can go home again. The 68-year-old Belgian brewer, who sold his brewery in Belgium to a giant brewer several years ago, has been making beer in Texas for the last year and a half. Now, he is going to sell beer in Belgium once again.

title: Teachers Union Acts Shamefully to Mayor
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Oct. 12 about a link between temporal lobe epilepsy and artistic achievement referred incorrectly to the behavior of Vincent van Gogh after he shot himself in the chest in 1890. Doctors found a letter in his pocket in which he said he had painted three canvases, but he did not do the work after the shooting.

title: Jean Ann O'Hare, C. R. Holladay Jr.
description: Jean Ann O'Hare, a corporate counsel for Pfizer Inc., the pharmaceutical concern, and Charles Randolph Holladay Jr., a partner in the law firm of Meilke & Holladay, both in New York, were married yesterday in Westport, Conn. Rabbi Charles Lippman and the Rev. James B. Wattley, an Episcopal priest and cousin of the bridegroom, officiated at Christ and Holy Trinity Church.

title: Stephen H. Whitmore, Lawyer, 39
description: Stephen H. Whitmore, a partner with the New York law firm of Berlack, Israels & Liberman, died on Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 39.

title: Mary C. Lawton, 58; U.S. Official Shaped Intelligence Policies
description: Mary C. Lawton, the Justice Department official in charge of foreign intelligence surveillance, died on Monday at her home in Bethesda, Md. She was 58.

title: Labor Official Retreats on Higher Minimum Wage
description: Under pressure from the White House, Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich said today that he would delay until next year his plans to recommend a higher minimum wage.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the groundbreaking for the New Jersey Performing Arts Center misstated the background of Lawrence P. Goldman, president of the arts center. He oversaw the renovation of Carnegie Hall, not Lincoln Center. Because of an editing error, the article also included an incomplete reference to Newark's Mayor. He is Sharpe James.

title: The Islands Russia and Japan Dispute
description: To the Editor:

title: Charlotte Pepe, Laboratory Head, 83
description: Charlotte O'Keefe Pepe, head of Chemicolloid Laboratories of Garden City Park, L.I., died on Thursday while attending a business meeting in Paris. She was 83 and lived in Garden City.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Your Money on Oct. 2 about Walter L. Morgan, a pioneer in the mutual fund business, misstated his relationship to the Vanguard Group. Mr. Morgan founded the Wellington Management Company, which ultimately became part of Vanguard. John C. Bogle established the Vanguard Group.

title: Review/Music; Abbado, the Berlin Philharmonic and Mahler
description: What a magnificent, eloquent, unpredictable and flawed organism the Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra is. On Thursday night in Carnegie Hall, the orchestra that once seemed an extension of Herbert von Karajan's gesturing arms gave the first of three New York concerts conducted by Karajan's successor, Claudio Abbado. It was the first time since 1982 that the orchestra had played in New York under its own music director (visits in 1986 and 1991 were led by James Levine and Bernard Haitink, respectively). And it was the first time New Yorkers could hear how Mr. Abbado has been shaping this great instrument since he became its caretaker and leader in 1989.

title: Jordan Says That Life In Retirement Is a Dunk
description: MICHAEL JORDAN , wearing his college basketball shorts under a dapper white suit and silvery vest, has told the television interviewer OPRAH WINFREY that he is happy in retirement.

title: Christopher Raises Level of State Dept.
description: To the Editor:

title: Six Accused in Killings
description: Six men suspected of being members of an extortion gang in the South Bronx that preyed on drug dealers were indicted yesterday on murder, kidnapping and weapons charges, the Bronx District Attorney said. The suspects face four counts of second-degree murder, including the killing of George Calderon, who was described by Robert T. Johnson, the Bronx District Attorney, as a significant heroin dealer.

title: Corrections
description: A headline in Business Day yesterday, about the possibility of civil suits by the Securities and Exchange Commission against at least five former and current executives of Prudential Securities, misstated the scope of the potential legal action in some editions. The enforcement staff of the S.E.C. has recommended civil action against only the executives; the securities firm has already settled with the commission.

title: Hillary Clinton Courts Four Senators Backing Rival Health Care Proposal
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton traveled 932 miles today to tell four Republican Senators they were in "the good faith camp" on health care and to minimize their differences with the President over how to pay for insurance coverage.

title: BRITISH COURT ALLOWS CANARY WHARF OUT OF BANKRUPTCY
description: A British court has allowed Olympia & York Developments' Canary Wharf complex to come out of administration, the British equivalent of Chapter 11 of the United States Bankruptcy Code. Canary Wharf's creditor banks agreed to appoint Peter Levene chairman of Canary Wharf Holdings Ltd., the reorganized property company. Mr. Levene was formerly the head of procurement at the Ministry of Defense and is the head of the Docklands Light Railway.

title: SHELL OIL CO.
description: The Shell Oil Company reported sharply higher third-quarter earnings yesterday, citing cost-cutting and higher profit margins for refined products and chemicals. But the increase -- to $187 million from $18 million in the third quarter of 1992 -- resulted partly from $76 million in special tax benefits.

title: Traffic Alert
description: TODAY STRYCKER'S/COLUMBUS AVENUE FAIR Columbus Avenue will be closed between 86th and 96th Streets from 11 A.M. to 6 P.M.

title: Teachers Union Acts Shamefully to Mayor; Voting by Color
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about Secretary of State Warren Christopher's visit to Eastern Europe and Central Asia mistranslated Almaty, the new official name for the capital of Kazakhstan, a city formerly known by the Russified name Alma-Ata. Almaty means Father of Apples, not City of Apples.

title: Making It Work; On the Garbage Team
description: IT was an ungodly 2:48 on a Wednesday morning when a yellow-and-black-striped heap of a subway train puffed and jerked into the station at 59th Street and Lexington Avenue. On the platform, a woman who seemed to have had a long evening, judging by her scowl and the wig that sat askew atop her head, began to yell.

title: New York Standard Time; Here Today, Gone Unaccountably
description: This is the weekend for turning clocks back one hour, a reversal that gets farmers and cows back in sync but is no big deal in New York, where time enjoys a weird life of its own regardless. While some things here go on forever - the Mets season, to take a ridiculously easy case - a more disturbing trick of New York Time is that it can make things vanish or materialize between midnight and 8 A.M. Many chicken take-out places have become tanning salons in just this way.

title:
Connecticut Q&A;: Representative Nancy L. Johnson;
Differing With Clinton on Health Care
description: NO sooner had President Bill Clinton unveiled his long-awaited health-care reform package -- one designed to provide insurance and universal access to all citizens -- did United States Representative Nancy L. Johnson, Republican of New Britain, let fly a fusillade of concerns.

title: Upstart Airline Staying on Course
description: IT is half past noon on a busy Monday at Newark International Airport. From his office across the road from the runway, Robert Iverson surveys the jets lining up for takeoff and consults his watch. It is almost departure time for Flight 9 to Orlando, Fla., on Kiwi International Airlines, the upstart airline he founded.

title: THE 1993 CAMPAIGN: The Ad Campaign; Dinkin's Ghostly Image of Giuliani
description: ON THE SCREEN

title: Streetscapes/The Ansonia; Changes for the Better, but Still a Long Way to Go
description: "BARBARIANS Rape Ansonia," ran the headline in The Village Voice in 1980, as the residents protested interior alterations on what was one of New York's most prominent and troubled apartment houses.

title: At Halloween, Unicef Faces Declining Collections in U.S.
description: Last year, at the Earth Summit conference in Rio de Janeiro, Jim Grant, executive director of Unicef, introduced himself to Al Gore, then a Senator from Tennessee. "Unicef?" said Mr. Gore. "What ever happened to those little orange boxes we used to go around with on Halloween?"

title: Jody Lanciotti and Christopher King
description: Jodean M. Lanciotti, the daughter of Jackie Lanciotti of Chicago Heights, Ill., and Frank Lanciotti of South Chicago Heights, Ill., was married yesterday to Christopher Q. King, a son of Seth and Mary King of Brewster, Mass.

title: TROUBLED WATER
description: The great water scare was brought to us by the Natural Resources Defense Council, the same group that perpetrated the scare that Alar in apple products created cancer risks. Same tactics: old, fully documented data sensationalized to look like an expose, coordinated release of material by a professional P.R. firm to print, radio and television, as well as a book by a freelance writer reviewed just in time. The incredible thing is that the news media went for the bait again. A. DAVID ROSSIN Los Altos Hills, Calif.

title: Oct. 24-30: A New Network; 'Star Trek': Yet Another Generation
description: Normally, Paramount Communications Inc.'s announcement last week that it planned a fifth national network would have sent an electric shock through the broadcast business. But coming in so turbulent a period in the industry's history, the announcement barely curled the toes in TV executives' Armani loafers.

title: When Collectors and Friends Help Mount a Major Exhibition
description: FLORENCE had the Medicis. Paris had Gertrude Stein, and Baltimore had the Cone Sisters as collectors and patrons of the arts. Now a group of collectors in Nassau County has gone beyond the usual role of patrons.

title: Of Love and Loneliness
description: ON Monday, in the gilded rococo dream of a living room of her Trump Tower triplex, Ivana Trump was chattering away at a cocktail benefit for the Muscular Dystrophy Association.

title: Senators Battle Over Foreign Broadcast Cuts
description: A plan to consolidate United States international broadcasting operations, touted by the Clinton Administration as a step toward streamlining the Government, seems to be coming apart.

title:
THING;
Fuzz Redux
description: CHENILLE, THE MEMORY: Chenille is a fuzzy-feely, cozy-cuddly fabric whose very name evokes waves of nostalgia in people old enough to remember Howdy Doody, Alben Barkley and bedspreads with rows and rows of cotton tufts that could be pulled out, systematically, by bored kids until all that was left covering them was a thin cotton rag. Mothers who had made it through World War II had to endure this compulsive behavior in the 1940's and 50's.CHENILLE, THE FASHION PHENOMENON: Sweaters made of another kind of chenille (and we'll get to that shortly) are pouring out of Manhattan stores, enveloping the island in a sea of fuzz. At Barneys New York, where it is possible to spend from $150 to $340 on a chenille sweater, "chenille's selling faster than anything else," said Suzie Welton, a vice president at Barneys. The two Barneys stores together are selling chenille sweaters at a rate of 350 pieces a week. At Eileen Fisher, the rate is an impressive 20 a day per store.WHY NOW: Chenille sweaters are post-modern security blankets, said Valerie Steele, a professor at the Fashion Institute of Technology. "In the old days, you felt secure if you were well dressed," she continued. "Now people are bringing out more eccentric security blankets." Made by Donna, Ralph or Azzedine.MORE NOSTALGIA: At the Lucy Anna Folk Art and Antique Quilt store in the West Village, Karen Taber is selling a slew of old chenille bedspreads to people who remember playing with toy cars between the tufted lines in their bedspreads.

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York

title: Manager's Profile
description: KENT SIMONS Fund: Neuberger & Berman Selected Sectors, $575 million in assets. Co-manager since 1988. (Sponsor: Neuberger & Berman Management, New York City). Born: May 13, 1935, Detroit. Education: B.A., Princeton University. Last Vacation: One week in July, visiting Bermuda with his daughter. Fund Performance: One year, through September: +24.4% (all growth funds: +18.9%). Five years, annualized: +16.1% (+14.4%)* Stock Market View: Neutral (self-rating). Stock Pick: First Fidelity Bancorp, Newark, N.J., because of its "low P/E relative to its prospects; the company just announced a buyback, so they must agree." Current Strategy: Looking for "stocks whose current P/E ratio does not reflect their superior financial characteristics and/or outlook." (*Source: Morningstar Inc.)

title: Societies at Hyper Speed
description: Why doesn't America know where it is going? U.S. foreign and military policy is swerving like a drunken driver without a map. It shows no clear grasp of out vital short-term national interests. - let alone an understanding that the old world map is obsolete - that the global system would be in revolutionary upheaval even if the Soviet Union still existed. We are undergoing the deepest rearrangement of global power since the birth of industrial civilization.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in the Neighborhood Report last week gave 1992 crime statistics, rather than the 1993 figures, for the 68th Precinct in Brooklyn. A corrected version appears today on page 10.

title: Hitler's Handmaiden
description: To the Editor:

title: Squaring The Circle
description: To the Editor:

title:
The View From: White Plains;
Now a Season in Itself, Halloween '93 Is Coming to an End
description: IT has its roots in ancient festivals honoring the spirits of the dead and has metamorphosed into a night for costumed youngsters to crunch through leaf-strewn streets calling, "Trick or treat."

title: Alfie, Oh Alfie, What Can We Do With Ye?
description: To the Editor:

title:
Wyckoff Journal;
And on the Seventh Day, Residents Argued About Shopping
description: WANT to buy a sweater or rent a video here on a Sunday? You can't, and whatever the outcome of the Bergen County referendum on Tuesday to repeal the county's blue laws, this township intends its stores to remain locked up tight on the Christian Sabbath.

title:
UNIVERSITY PRESSES;
Seeking Sainthood
description: THE TEMPTATIONS OF ST. ED & BROTHER S By Frank Bergon.305 pp. Reno:University of Nevada Press. $18.95.

title: The Imaginary Woman
description: LIAISON By Joyce Wadler. Illustrated. 321 pp. New York: Bantam Books. $22.95. DAVID HENRY HWANG'S 1988 Broadway hit, "M. Butterfly," and the movie based on it were inspired by a sensational 1986 trial in France. When a diplomatic clerk, Bernard Boursicot, was convicted of espionage, it was revealed that he had been motivated by his infatuation with a male performer in the Beijing Opera, Shi Pei Pu, whom he had met in Beijing in 1964 and helped get to France. Mr. Boursicot had believed, for 20 years, that Pei Pu was a woman and also the mother of a teen-age son he thought he had fathered.

title: In Times Square, Turning Profits From 'Gin Mills'
description: AT 9 A.M. in Rudy's Bar, Ernest Schroeder sits on a stool counting money. There are many $100 bills, rolls and rolls of quarters, and everything in between. The cash, around $12,000, represents the weekend take from his four Times Square bars.

title: CURRENCY

GOLF;
Frost's Consistency Is Good For a Two-Stroke Margin
description: When Jim Gallagher Jr. shot a course-record eight-under-par 63 at the fabled Olympic Club on Thursday to give himself a five-shot lead after one round of the $3 million Tour Championship, no one in the elite field of 30 gave it very much thought.

title: Hitler's Handmaiden
description: To the Editor:

title: David Gergen, Master of THE GAME
description: On Nov. 9, 1960, the day after John F. Kennedy defeated Richard M. Nixon to become the 35th President of the United States, a reporter for The Washington Daily News and a reporter for The Associated Press dropped by Nixon's house in Washington, looking for a interview with the loser. The Vice President answered the door himself, and standing on the front stoop, the three men settled into a polite routine of questions and answers. Suddenly, Pat Nixon appeared. She was angry and, it was clear, not in control of her emotions. She damned the reporters and their colleagues for favoritism toward Kennedy that she said cost her husband the election. Nixon calmed her and led her away. When he returned, he said nothing about his wife's outburst, and the reporters resumed their inquiry as if nothing unusual had occurred. Neither reporter ever wrote about Mrs. Nixon's behavior; it wasn't news.

title: Kristin Barrett, R. L. Selvala Jr.
description: Kristin Anne Barrett, an associate in corporate finance at the Chemical Banking Corporation, was married yesterday to Richard Lee Selvala Jr., a senior analyst in the treasurer's office of the General Motors Corporation. Both work in New York. The Rev. Michael Lindvall performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in Ann Arbor, Mich.

title: Term Limits Drive the Talented Out of Politics; Aid to Orderly Change
description: To the Editor:

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: THE DIVINERS By Margaret Laurence. University of Chicago, $12.95. This Canadian author's fifth novel, originally published in 1974, is the story of a middle-aged writer who sees her young daughter, whom she's raised alone, preparing to separate from her. Our reviewer, Marge Piercy, called the book "ambitious and compelling."

title:
TRAVEL ADVISORY;
Hungary Puts Old Symbols Out in a Park
description: Many symbols of Hungary's Communist period have vanished from that country -- the Parliament has even outlawed the hammer and sickle and red star -- but one collection of mementos from the era has just been put on exhibit in Budapest.

title: Residents Fight Plan for North Hempstead Dump
description: WHEN the Town of North Hempstead sold the 26-acre Denton Avenue Landfill to the Spring Rock Golf Course on Oct. 1 for $8 million, town officials thought that they were finalizing a good deal.

title: UNIVERSITY PRESSES -- IN SHORT: FICTION
description: POEMS AND STORIESSAANII DAHATAAL, THE WOMEN ARE SINGINGPoems and Stories.By Luci Tapahonso.University of Arizona; cloth, $19.95; paper, $9.95.

title: Oct. 24-30: Cloning Humans; A Genetic Experiment Ignites a Bioethical Debate
description: Scientists who want to try genetic engineering, the insertion of genes into human cells to cure disease, must go through endless red tape. But, as the public learned last week, two scientists who wanted to try the ultimate genetic experiment, cloning human embryos, needed approval only from their hospital's ethics advisory board.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: JAPANESE LANTERNS

title: Fight Fiercely, Ruben Navarrette Jr.
description: A DARKER SHADE OF CRIMSON Odyssey of a Harvard Chicano. By Ruben Navarrette Jr. 270 pp. New York: Bantam Books. $21.95.

title: A Stroll Up the Ramp With Roy Lichtenstein
description: Painters are legendarily fuzzy when talking about their work. Not Roy Lichtenstein. So Diane Waldman, curator of the Lichtenstein retrospective at the Guggenheim Museum and a longtime Lichtenstein friend and admirer, persuaded him to help her conduct the Acoustiguide tape-recorded tour of the exhibition.

title: County To Buy Mt. Vernon Stadium
description: UNDER a plan developed by Mayor Ronald A. Blackwood of Mount Vernon and County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke, this city's aging Memorial Field Stadium will be renovated and made available for both countywide and local sporting and entertainment events by the spring of 1996.

title: Melissa Moore, Richard Abate
description: Melissa Moore, a doctoral candidate in politics, and Richard R. Abate, a doctoral candidate in American studies, both at New York University, were married yesterday. The Rev. Dr. Alfred A. Moss performed the Episcopal ceremony at the University Club in New York.

title: Also Inside
description: MAKING IT WORK 3 Each night, Vera Kitt and six fellow travelers board an outcast train. Their mission: to clean the subway tracks. NEW YORKERS & CO. 4 Amid loud music and cheap beer, a bar owner prowls his empire, where everyone knows his name. PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD 15 North Carolina in Gramercy Park; the Far East in Flushing Meadows. MOVIE CLOCK 16 What's showing at the local movie houses, today through Thursday. GOOD EATING 18 Ethnic Pleasures, Elmhurst to Astoria: when you crave a good parrillada, a tasty taramosalata, or a vibrant hummus. SOAPBOX 21 Four ordinary New Yorkers discuss the mayoral candidates, the issues and life in the city. Plus, "Eye of the Beholder."

title: Societies at Hyper Speed
description: Why doesn't America know where it is going? U.S. foreign and military policy is swerving like a drunken driver without a map. It shows no clear grasp of vital short-term national interests - let alone an understanding that the old world map is obsolete - that the global system would be in revolutionary upheaval even if the Soviet Union still existed. We are undergoing the deepest rearrangement of global power since the birth of industrial civilization.

title: Dancing With Professors: The Trouble With Academic Prose
description: IN ordinary life, when a listener cannot understand what someone has said, this is the usual exchange:

title: Neighborhood Report: Central Park; A Rebirth For Upper Park
description: It was like an outing at a romantic 19th-century English lakeside home: on a recent weekend afternoon, visitors sunned themselves on the terrace while taking in a concert by the Harbor Jazz Ensemble. Others sat on newly installed benches overlooking the lake. Nearby, toddlers clambered around the swings and slides in the playground, opened last year.

title: Magnet School's Magnet: Preschool
description: Shanicqua Gant, 3, of Bridgeport and Laura Kantorowski, 4, of Fairfield sat at a small table eating their snacks and giggling.

title: A Voluble Presence in the World
description: BERTRAND RUSSELLA Life.By Caroline Moorehead.Illustrated. 596 pp. New York: Viking. $30.

title: Peter Quennell, a Man of Letters And Man About Town, Dies at 88
description: Peter Quennell, a dashing English man of letters who also wrote about the celebrities he socialized with, died on Wednesday in London. He was 88.

title: A Menu Newcomer: Manchurian Dishes
description: A RESTAURANT that stamps itself Asian, Eastern or Oriental is making a statement. It is saying that its cuisine is a mixture. Usually that means two-thirds Chinese dishes, one-third Japanese and a sprinkling of something exotic, often Thai.

title: De La Hoya, Floored, Stills Wins in Round 1
description: Oscar De La Hoya moved his scripted career in the ring forward tonight. And in the process, he showed he was not just another pretty face.

title: ARNOLD GLIMCHER AND HIS ART WORLD ALL-STARS
description: Arne Glimcher's West Coast adventures were a lively read. I'd like to add that, in addition to selling one-of-a-kind works, Pace Editions, the gallery's prints division, pioneered the multiples market by making limited series of signed lithographs available to a new generation of potential collectors at an affordable price. AMY SLOANE-PINEL Paris

title: Corrections
description: An article on Oct. 10 about bagel shops around New York misstated the address of Atlantic Bagels in Brooklyn. It is at 177 Atlantic Avenue, at Clinton Street.

title:
ART;
Contemporary Works, Meant to Be Lived With
description: A COLLECTION of contemporary art has a different emphasis from one of Old Masters or porcelains. It brings together art that is encountered every day. Instead of being prized for having what is scarce, it can be a clear picture of an era.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in the Neighborhood Report last week gave 1992 crime statistics, rather than the 1993 figures, for the 68th Precinct in Brooklyn. A corrected version appears today on page 10.

title: Neighborhood Report: Washington Heights; Editor's Apologies Quell Fury Over Article
description: An article about Hispanic culture, children and sex abuse that appeared in the first issue of a new neighborhood newspaper in Washington Heights hit a raw nerve with so many readers that the editor dedicated much of the second issue to apologizing for the furor.

title: Tech Notes; Keeping Tabs on Postal Workers
description: THE Postal Service may not be able to tell you where your letter is, but it will soon know what time each collection box is emptied. "We'll be able to determine any early or missed collections," said Lou Eberhardt, a Postal Service spokesman. "This will really help us smooth our collection schedule out."

title: Hope Polinsky, David Taragin
description: Hope Polinsky, an account coordinator for Tribune Broadcasting in Manhattan, was married on Thursday to Dr. David Lee Taragin, a resident in neurology at the Albert Einstein Medical Center in the Bronx. Rabbi Gedaliah Anemer officiated at the Sands Country Club in Atlantic Beach, L.I.

title: UNIVERSITY PRESSES -- IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: WRITERS AND THE LAND THE ROADS TAKEN Travels Through America's Literary Landscapes.By Fred Setterberg.University of Georgia, $24.95.

title: No, It's Not a Dirty Song
description: LOUIE LOUIE The History and Mythology of the World's Most Famous Rock 'n' Roll Song; Including the Full Details of Its Torture and Persecution at the Hands of the Kingsmen, J. Edgar Hoover's F.B.I., and a Cast of Millions; and Introducing, for the First Time Anywhere, the Actual Dirty Lyrics. By Dave Marsh. Illustrated. 245 pp. New York: Hyperion. $19.95.

title: QUEBEC BLOC SET FOR OTTAWA ROLE
description: Gilles Duceppe, a former labor organizer who won a seat in Parliament for the Bloc Quebecois, is now packing his bags for Ottawa along with 53 other Bloc victors -- teachers, lawyers, economists, small business operators, a baker -- to become the official opposition to Prime Minister-designate Jean Chretien's Liberals.

title: Kathryn George, William Tyree
description: Kathryn Carolyn George, a deputy manager in trade finance, and William Brophy Tyree, the manager of the treasury department, both at Brown Brothers Harriman & Company, the private bank in New York, were married yesterday. Msgr. William McKeevor performed the ceremony at St. Agnes Roman Catholic Church in Key Biscayne, Fla.

title: The View From: Waterford; A Stalled Repair Plan Takes Its Toll at Harkness Park
description: THE golden autumn sun shone on the broad lawns, Italianate mansion and historic gardens of Harkness Memorial State Park in Waterford. Just beyond the grounds, Long Island Sound sparkled. But Diana McMasters took little note of sun and sparkle. She eyed the mansion's cracked masonry and rotting sills. She pushed aside dense overgrowth in one garden and pointed out a boarded-over pond in another.

title: Phoenix Dining: Rising Expectations
description: SUDDENLY Phoenix is bursting with good restaurants. Even as recently as five years ago, for anyone interested in great food this humming desert oasis provoked little more than a yawn. A favorite of retired America, it was also the capital of white-bread America. There was Vincent Guerithault's and then . . . not much more.

title:
ON LOCATION;
Spice and Sass to Go With the Pizza
description: A little song, a little dance, a little pesto on your pants.

title: The Ultimate Used Car
description: With much fanfare, the White House has announced its intention to build a car with triple the fuel efficiency of current models. Auto makers, meanwhile, have been quietly pursuing their own idea of the dream green vehicle: a car designed expressly to be taken apart. It's detachment sans irony -- they've embraced recycling, fitting the latest models with parts that, once removed and reconfigured, can live on almost indefinitely.

title:
Viewpoints;
How to Get, and Keep, Foreign Capital
description: DOES the United States need money? Few questions are easier to field. Even schoolchildren can tick off plenty of items -- from health care to the budget deficit -- that cry out for capital.

title: 'Big Bird' Eases Chaos At Airport in Tokyo
description: FORM is supposed to follow function throughout Japan, so it is no surprise that the country's newest and most desperately needed air terminal, at Haneda Airport in Tokyo, is called Big Bird. And from the air it looks exactly like that -- a bird about three football fields long, its wings spread .

title: Stigmatized Treatment
description: To the Editor:

title: Look Who's Saving Elm
description: Without question, the dinkiest plant in my garden these last few seasons has been the American elm tree my father-in-law gave me three years ago. I realize that "dinky" is not a word often attached to elm trees -- "graceful" or "venerable" or even, in recent years, "dead" are a lot more like it. But there is no getting around the fact that the leafless, 14-inch chopstick that arrived in the mail from the Elm Research Institute in Harrisville, N.H., was a poor excuse for a tree. Swaddled in a sheet of The Manchester Union Leader, it had not even a single branch -- just a couple of bud-eyes at one end and a straggle of root hairs at the other.

title: Tigers Slip And Slide One Step Closer
description: It will be as big as Florida State-Notre Dame. That's what the Ivy League folks are saying, anyway.

title: Neighborhood Report: Morrisania; An Officer's Eyes and Ears
description: This summer, Jeff King, a community police officer at the 42d Precinct in the South Bronx, was finally overwhelmed by his beat: nine square blocks of apartment buildings and cavernous housing projects too sprawling for one person to handle.

title: Touche
description: To the Editor:

title: Motorola Will Be Just Fine, Thanks
description: GEORGE M. C. FISHER flunked one major test of chief executive leadership last week: that of managing a graceful transition of power. Motorola Inc., its customers and competitors, and Wall Street were all stunned by the announcement Wednesday that the 52-year-old scientist-turned-manager was leaving the prospering electronics giant immediately to take over the helm at the embattled Eastman Kodak Company.

title: Chamber Groups Vie With Folk
description: CHAMBER and folk music are prominent in the musical scene this week, beginning today at 3 P.M., when the clarinet-piano duo of Jean Kopperud and Cameron Grant bring Brahms, Bernstein, Vaughan-Williams and Gershwin to Wave Hill in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. For driving directions, the number to call is (718) 549-3200.

title: Conversations/Paul A. Samuelson; The Man Who Wrote the Book Suggests Econ 101 for Presidents
description: ASK Paul A. Samuelson how he came to win a Nobel Memorial Prize in Economics, and he begins by talking about his teen-age years during the Great Depression, not far from the steel mills of Gary, Ind.

title: Waiver Language
description: To the Editor: My wife and I had a nearly identical experience to that of Dan and Sylvia Larsen in the Practical Traveler ("Waivers: More Than a Warning," Aug. 22) when we signed up for a rafting trip last June in Denali National Park, Alaska.

title: Shari Stumacher And Philip Kwait
description: Shari Beth Stumacher, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Stumacher of Forest Hills, Queens, was married last evening to Dr. Philip S. Kwait, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Kwait of New York. Rabbi Robert Benjamin performed the ceremony at Temple Emanuel in New Hyde Park, L.I.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE MOLES AND THE MIREUK A Korean Folktale. Retold by Holly H. Kwon. Illustrated by Woodleigh Hubbard. Unpaged. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $14.95. (Ages 3 to 7) SIR WHONG AND THE GOLDEN PIG Adapted by Oki S. Han and Stephanie Haboush Plunkett. Illustrated by Oki S. Han. Unpaged. New York: Dial Books for Young Readers. $13.99. (Ages 4 to 8) THE KOREAN CINDERELLA By Shirley Climo. Illustrated by Ruth Heller. Unpaged. New York: HarperCollins Publishers.

title: Sports of The Times; Giants-Jets: Logos, Fans And a Plane
description: JOE the Jet fan had come home too late once too often. His roommate, Elizabeth, was steaming.

title: An Eclectic Mix of Antiques in a Festive Mansion Setting
description: THE mansion setting, with rooms that are works of art themselves, distinguishes the 17th annual antiques show at the Lockwood-Mathews Mansion Museum in Norwalk next weekend. This year there will be additional distinctions -- a new manager, new dealers and an appealing historical exhibition.

title: Hitler's Handmaiden
description: To the Editor:

title: UNIVERSITY PRESSES -- IN SHORT: FICTION
description: SHORT STORIES STORYHOOD AS WE KNOW IT And Other Tales. By Jack Matthews. Johns Hopkins University; cloth, $32.50; paper, $12.95.

title: Paul M. Froelich, Meg M. Kruizenga
description: Meg Mulder Kruizenga, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Richard J. Kruizenga of Irving, Tex., was married yesterday to Paul Montgomery Froelich, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Don Froelich of Dickinson, N.D. The Rev. Dr. Melvin Hill, a Baptist minister, and Lee Willard Autrey, a Christian Science practitioner, officiated at the John's Island Beach Club in Vero Beach, Fla.

title:
Viewpoints;
No-Frills Flying: You Ain't Seen Nothin'
description: THE silent, wistful-looking businesswoman's laptop pressed harder and harder against my thigh as we leaned as far away as possible from the straining underarm of the oaf in the "See Weehawken First" T-shirt who was reaching above us to get a grip on the looming, bulbous carry-on article he had earlier managed to cram into the compartment over our heads along with someone else's down-filled coat, which drooped more and more voluminously onto our heads as the oaf stretched and tugged.

title: Where Dinner Is a Scream
description: NAME: D. R. Finley. IDENTITY: Mr. Finley, 31, owns three horror-theme restaurants: Jack the Ripper Pub, 228 West Fourth Street; Jekyll & Hyde, 91 Seventh Avenue South, and the Slaughtered Lamb Pub, 182 West Fourth Street. And he is preparing to open the Jekyll & Hyde Club early next year at 1409 Avenue of the Americas, near 57th Street.

title: Terrorize A Child, Pull a Crowd
description: At the end of "The Good Son," two of the world's most valuable child actors are dangled off the edge of a cliff -- for real. This stunt may be the latest cultural symptom of how quickly children are growing up. Macaulay Culkin, as a murderous little boy, and Elijah Wood, as the good-seed cousin who spots his crimes, were suspended high above the ocean, just like macho adults who insist on doing their own tricks.

title: This Week's Numbers
description: Last Consensus Period Estimates (I.D.E.A. INC.) Monday Construction spending, Sept., pct. change -1.1 0.8 Purchasing managers' index, October 49.7 51 Tuesday Leading indicators, Sept., percent change 1.0 0.4 New-home sales, thousands, ann. rate 616 650 Wednesday Auto sales, late Oct., millions, annual rate 7.8 7.0 Thursday Weekly jobless claims, thousands 347 345 Factory-goods orders, Sept., pct. change 0.9 0.8 Nonfarm productivity, 3d qtr., pct. change -1.3 1.5 Friday Unemployment, October, percent 6.7 6.7 Theis Week's Developments Tuesday French-German summit meeting Wednesday Federal Reserve releases beige book

title: Don't Call The Oilers Insensitive Bosses
description: "Oh, baby!"

FOOD PATCH -- the letters of the second word stand for People Allied to Combat Hunger -- has just bought a new refrigerator. That would not be the newsworthy event, except that Food Patch, in Millwood, is a nonprofit food bank that stores and distributes 1,000 tons of food each year to 120 soup kitchens, food pantries, shelters and other hunger-relief organizations and agencies in Westchester.

title: What's Good For the French . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: Synagogue Dispute In a Shore Community
description: Perhaps the most enlightening aspects of the Sept. 19 article on Deal, "Syrian Jews and Town at Odds Over Synagogue," are the parts that were not said. There is mention of the Catholic church a few blocks from the proposed synagogue; St. Mary's is a magnificent edifice, complete with bell tower and a crucifix high above, along with an announcement board facing Richmond Avenue. What is not mentioned is that the Synagogue of Deal on the main thoroughfare has no identifying marks.

title: In the Region/Westchester; 73 Estate Homes (Maybe); Golf Course Is Included
description: WHEN Jack Nicklaus dug a shovelful of dirt at a recent groundbreaking for a residential-golf-course development in Purchase, he quipped that the hole should be filled in immediately, "otherwise, it might be declared a wetland tomorrow."

title: New Jersey Q & A: John J. O'Brien; Staying on Top of Newspaper Trends
description: JOHN J. O'BRIEN, the executive director of the New Jersey Press Association, has come a long way since his days of sweeping the floors in the press room at the weekly Hunterdon County Democrat in Flemington 28 years ago.

title: Bitter Contest For Nassau Executive Enlivens Vote
description: BRINGING a final cease-fire to an election season marked by fiercely fought negative campaigns, Long Island voters will cast ballots on Tuesday to fill top elected positions and dozens of lesser posts in Nassau and Suffolk.

title: Raising the 'New Daughter'
description: MOTHER DAUGHTER REVOLUTIONFrom Betrayal to Power.By Elizabeth Debold, Marie Wilsonand Idelisse Malave.299 pp. Reading, Mass.:Addison-Wesley Publishing Company. $22.95.DAUGHTERS OF FEMINISTSBy Rose L. Glickman.192 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $19.95.

title: A Surprise Winner Of a Brilliancy Prize
description: THE pretourney favorites, Elena Donaldson of Mercer Island, Wash., and Irina Levitina of Teaneck, N.J., shared first prize in the 34th United States Women's Championship in August at the McLean County Arts Center in Bloomington, Ill. The two former Soviet team members scored 7-2 in the round-robin invitational competition and each was awarded a $1,500 prize.

title: Photography Review | Smithson's Ways of Looking at the Land
description: Two cameras are installed as reverently as saints' bones in a vitrine near the entrance to "Robert Smithson: Photo Works," the wide-ranging show of images by the pioneering earthworks artist now at the International Center of Photography. Despite this respectful treatment, the cameras, which belonged to Smithson, testify to the artist's less-than-reverent attitude toward photography: both are Kodak Instamatics; one fancier than the other, but amateur models nonetheless.

title: UNIVERSITY PRESSES -- IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: HOLOCAUST MEMOIR TO TELL AT LAST Survival Under False Identity, 1941-45. By Blanca Rosenberg. University of Illinois, $19.95.

title: Carmen Torruella, Jarvis Slade Jr.
description: Mr. and Mrs. Radames A. Torruella of San Juan, P.R., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Carmen Beatriz Torruella, to Jarvis James Slade Jr., the son of Alice Patterson Slade and Mr. Slade, both of New York. A December wedding is planned.

title: Luisa J. Orto, W. F. Symmans
description: Luisa Jane Orto, a daughter of Jane Orto of Westfield, N.J., was married yesterday to Dr. W. Fraser Symmans, the son of Dr. and Mrs. W. Ashley Symmans of Hamilton, New Zealand. The Rev. William R. Forbes performed the ceremony at the Presbyterian Church at Westfield, N.J.

title: Wall Street; Fighting It Out Over Arbitration
description: IN 1987, the Supreme Court upheld provisions in brokerage house contracts with investors stipulating that claims against brokers must be resolved by arbitration, and not in the courtroom. Since that decision in Shearson/American Express v. McMahon, the number of arbitration cases filed with major exchanges has roughly doubled.

title: Mutual Funds; Customs That Bewilder Investors
description: CERTAIN tricks of the mutual fund trade can leave an unwary investor feeling quite mistreated.

title: Hitler's Handmaiden
description: To the Editor:

title: A Game That Offers Coslet a Much-Needed Showcase
description: As Jets Coach Bruce Coslet looks across the field this afternoon, he will see Dan Reeves, the Giants' coach. And although he will have a number of different things to think about today, no doubt Coslet's mind will flash to how well the new coach is doing in his first season in New York.

title: Richard Glosser, Catherine Hoffman
description: Catherine Anne Hoffman, a daughter of Anita V. Hoffman of New York and David L. Hoffman Sr. of Greenwich, Conn., was married last evening to Richard Marc Glosser, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul L. Glosser of Johnstown, Pa. Rabbi Bert Siegel officiated at the St. Regis Roof in New York.

title: Rangers Burn Whalers as Patrick Fiddles
description: James Patrick sat in the press box in his suit and his tie, leafed through the press notes, watched the Rangers' goals as they were replayed on television and didn't play hockey. Again.

title: THE GUIDE
description: FILM FESTIVAL

title: POSTINGS: Solving a Style Conundrum; Museum's Addition Is Designed To Reflect a View of the Future
description: In designing an addition to the Museum of the City of New York, James Stewart Polshek & Partners found itself in a contextual sandwich. To the west, on Fifth Avenue, was the original museum, a neo-Georgian structure with red bricks and pediments. To the east, running from 103d to 104th Streets, was the Patrick Henry Preparatory School, a gabled and yellow-brick building modeled on a French Renaissance town hall.

title: Channel Tunnel List Is Opened to Americans
description: Americans who want to be among the first to ride through the Channel Tunnel on trains connecting England, France and Belgium can now sign up with Britrail Travel International. The tunnel is scheduled to open May 6, carrying trainloads of officials in 3 hours between London and Paris and 3 hours 15 minutes between London and Brussels.

title: Kyle A. Belford, Matthew Platnico
description: Kyle Alexandra Belford, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd E. Belford of Fall River, Mass., was married last evening to Matthew Eric Platnico, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Platnico of St. Louis. Rabbi Peter Rubinstein officiated at the Waldorf-Astoria in New York.

title: ARNOLD GLIMCHER AND HIS ART WORLD ALL-STARS
description: The 11 artists pictured on your cover look like an aging football team and the art gallery owner, Arnold Glimcher, a B-team coach. And perhaps this is the point, with the headline "Arnold Glimcher and His Art World All-Stars." Is art now a sport where gallery owners lure the best-selling artists from other galleries for a higher price? And is this the 90's? Women were better off in the 1930's, when photographs of artists gathering together included at least one woman, perhaps Georgia O'Keeffe. MARGIE LEE Portland, Ore.

title:
UNIVERSITY PRESSES;
Mozart Comes to Leadville
description: OPERA IN AMERICA A Cultural History. By John Dizikes. Illustrated. 612 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $35.

title:
In the Region/Long Island;
New Opportunities For First-Timers
description: AFTER 14 years of renting a one-bedroom garden apartment in Rokonkoma, Jerry and Susan Maher will move into a three-bedroom, two-bath ranch in Middle Island at the end of next month. The 1,600-square-foot house, on three-quarters of an acre in a development called Twin Ponds Estates, is costing them $126,000; without a basement it would have cost them $119,000.

title: Arthur D. Greenleigh, 90, Expert On Welfare Issues and Refugees
description: Arthur D. Greenleigh, who led Federal and private programs to help victims of the Depression and World War II and later founded a consulting firm on welfare issues, died on Friday at home in Manhattan at the age of 90.

title: And in the West, There's No Clear Favorite
description: Everything is more wide-open out West, from the style of play, to the race for the top spot.

title: Anita Hendricks, Robert Buckman
description: Anita Marie Hendricks, a daughter of Robert W. Hendricks of West Orange, N.J., and the late Mary U. Hendricks, was married yesterday to Robert Buckman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Karl R. Buckman of Toms River, N.J. The Rev. Victor Kennedy performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in West Orange.

title: HAITIAN MILITARY CONDEMNED BY U.N.
description: Still hoping that a solution can be brokered in Haiti, the Security Council condemned the Haitian military today for blocking the return of President Jean-Bertrand Aristide but stopped short of even repeating its warnings of a tighter trade embargo.

title:
UNIVERSITY PRESSES;
Antic Longing
description: MOTHER ROCKETStories.By Rita Ciresi.144 pp. Athens:The University of Georgia Press. $19.95.

title: Penn Wins Big at Yale To Set Up Title Game
description: Penn trounced Yale today, 48-7, in the cold and rain at the Yale Bowl for the undefeated Quakers' seventh straight victory this season. It was the most decisive Yale loss to an Ivy opponent since the league began competition 37 years ago.

title: Bigfoot the Lexicographer
description: SAFIRE'S NEW POLITICAL DICTIONARYThe Definitive Guideto the New Language of Politics.By William Safire.930 pp. New York:Random House. $35.

title: On The Road to Nowhere
description: THE MEXICAN TREE DUCK By James Crumley. 247 pp. New York: The Mysterious Press/ Warner Books. $19.95.

title: The Brotherhood of Vampires
description: ANNO-DRACULABy Kim Newman.359 pp. New York: Carroll & Graf Publishers. $21.

title: Corrections
description: A headline on the Wall Street page last Sunday about a class action suit against Prudential Securities misstated the company's potential liability. The total of the Prudential Utility Fund's assets is $5.3 billion; there was no estimate of liability in the lawsuit, which contends that some investors were charged excessive fees.

title: Not Quite On the Fringe
description: To the Editor:

title: Michele Oxman, Steven R. Boal
description: Michele Lee Oxman, a daughter of Dr. Herbert Oxman and Lynn Oxman, both of Mequon, Wis., was married last evening to Steven Robert Boal, a son of Dr. Bernard Boal and Pamela Boal of Great Neck, L.I. Rabbi Mordecai Waxman performed the ceremony at Congregation Shalom in Fox Point, Wis.

title: Russia Ties New Libyan Sanctions to a Loan
description: Russia is threatening to veto new Security Council sanctions against Libya for refusing to surrender two suspects in the bombing of a Pan American World Airlines airliner over Scotland five years ago unless the United States, Britain and France give it an interest-free loan to cover a $4 billion debt Tripoli owes it.

title: 7 DIE, 11 WOUNDED IN ULSTER ATTACK
description: The wave of sectarian violence that has accelerated in Northern Ireland in the last eight days continued Saturday night when two gunmen shot and killed at least seven people in a bar in a village in the western part of the British Province, police said.

title: LAST CALL
description: I am approaching 44 and have gone through the same reckoning that so many of us have (Hers: "Last Call," by Elizabeth Berg, Oct. 3). The tracts about passages to new stages -- to a freedom to relinquish the burden of fertility and maternity -- are interesting but not felt.

title: A Flop With Many Firsts
description: To the Editor:

title:
ART;
Jazz, Painting, Photographs And Regional History in 3 Shows
description: Bernard Cully and Jackie Peters-Cully

title: ARNOLD GLIMCHER AND HIS ART WORLD ALL-STARS
description: The implication in your article that Arne Glimcher is in any way ashamed of his Jewishness was offensive. I have always found him to be comfortable and proud of his Jewish identity. His name was not changed from a "WASP-ish" Arne to a Hollywood-pandering "Jewish" Arnie. His credit on "The Mambo Kings" is the same Arne that he uses everywhere. Further, the notion that he would cultivate important relationships with the Jewish community for purely personal gain is grotesque.

title: Traffic Alert
description: TODAY

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD: Red Hook; Dancing Along the Way
description: Red Hook Arts, a multimedia youth group, has teamed up with Dancing in the Streets, which specializes in site-specific performances, to create a production that stretches along several blocks of Red Hook.

title: Dining Facing Grand Central
description: To the Editor:

title: Train to the Plane: Will It Ever Fly?
description: When the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey first proposed a light rail system that would finally link New York City's airports to Manhattan by sleek, quiet electric trains, people cheered. But now that the plans are nearing completion -- with a proposal to put the Manhattan terminal in one of the worst traffic spots in the city -- rumblings of opposition are surfacing.

title: Boy, 11, Shot and Killed In a Queens Beauty Salon
description: Bullets flew through a Queens beauty salon window yesterday, killing an 11-year-old boy inside who had taken a piece of birthday cake from an upstairs neighbor's party to his mother at work in the salon, the police and neighbors said.

title: Sculptor's Work to Grace the Channel Tunnel
description: WHEN Carl LeVotch, a sculptor, visited the site of the future 31-mile Channel Tunnel, which will connect Britain and France, earth movers were rumbling, dust was flying and the incisions of bulldozers were raw in the earth. But Mr. LeVotch remembers feeling inspired by the scene he encountered in the summer of 1991. "It had a certain beauty to me, a kind of raw power," he said.

title: Miss McAnaney, G. D. Molinsky Jr.
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward G. McAnaney 2d of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter Kathleen Glennon McAnaney to George Donald Molinsky Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Molinsky of Kettering, Ohio. An August wedding is planned.

title:
CLASSICAL MUSIC;
The Crises of Tomorrow Are Here Today
description: There is much unease today among those who head America's orchestras. Statistics show that audiences are aging, and the collapse of arts education in public schools makes it difficult to find new listeners among a younger, more ethnically diverse urban population. The repertory has grown stuffy and predictable, and daring ventures tend to alienate old, reliable subscribers. Finances are shaky in all the arts, but orchestras, which lack any cachet of trendiness, are particularly vulnerable. And increasingly in the realm of abstract music, which once maintained a lofty immunity to the problems of society at large, political and cultural concerns intrude.

title: Julie L. Strauss, Matthew Russman
description: Julie Lynn Strauss, an assistant district attorney in Manhattan, and Matthew David Russman, an associate at the New York law firm of Simpson Thacher & Bartlett, were married last evening. Rabbi Martin Freedman officiated at the Marriott Financial Center Hotel in New York.

title: Skinheads a Growing Cause for Concern
description: "ALL the media knows is that all skinheads are racist, and that bothers me," said Mars T., a 24-year-old who works for a pesticide company in Passaic County and plays in a heavy-metal band. "It isn't true. There are different kinds of skinheads with different beliefs, and we shouldn't all be labeled as the same. When you're younger, you're more idealistic and anarchistic."

title: Peter A. Smul and Debra J. Rudich
description: Debra Jill Rudich, a daughter of Joel and Phyllis Rudich of Columbus, Ohio, was married last evening to Peter Allen Smul, a son of Sandy and Vicki Smul of New York. Rabbi Herschel Schacter officiated at the Stouffer Westchester Hotel in White Plains.

title: SUNDAY, October 31, 1983; RELATIVITY
description: Albert Einstein is universally associated with genius and personal nobility. He won the Nobel prize and worked for world peace.
